TEXT:
poor wifi at food court
Ridiculous
The queue for hours feels like an old-school airport

My recent experience at Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) was nothing short of frustrating. From the airline to the moment I arrived, the service was abysmally slow, and the staff was unhelpful. Immigration staff, in particular, were rude and disrespectful, making an already stressful experience far worse.

The flight was plagued with significant delays, and constant gate changes, making the entire experience chaotic. The in-flight safety video was unprofessional and disturbing, especially for young passengers. This attempt at engagement was tasteless and unnecessary.

Additionally, the constant gate changes and flight delays created confusion and anxiety throughout my entire time at the airport. Having to take a bus between terminals was highly inconvenient and only added to the frustration.

What really stood out was the slogan displayed upon arrival: ‚ÄúWe hope you‚Äôve enjoyed our Malaysian Hospitality.‚Äù Frankly, this felt more like an empty promise than a reflection of the experience I had. A service should speak for itself, but in this case, it was clear that overcompensating with slogans only highlights the gap between what is advertised and what is actually delivered.

Given this experience, I will never fly with Malaysian Airlines or visit Malaysia again and I certainly won't be encouraging my friends or family to visit.

Very slow immigration service at depature and arrival times
Knowing everyone has flight to board still they have very few staff which also take alot of time
Gate C is too far away, and the security check in front of the gate shortens the time spent at the airport, so it's hard to enjoy it.

I‚Äôve traveled through KLIA countless times, and it has always impressed me with its cleanliness, smooth check-in process, and efficient security checks. The architecture, inspired by Malaysian, Islamic, and natural elements, remains a stunning highlight. But what truly made KLIA special was its balance of international and uniquely local offerings- something that now seems to be fading.

With the recent KLIA1 renovation, I have to give credit where it‚Äôs due- the new bathrooms are a huge improvement! Well designed, good ventilation, clean and dry. But the retail and dining experience has taken a disappointing turn. Many local options have disappeared, replaced by foreign goods. And once again, alcohol and tobacco seem to dominate the retail space‚Äîwhy so much of it? I was shocked to find just one shelf of Malaysian food products in the entire terminal 1. Malaysia is a food paradise‚Äîwhy isn‚Äôt KLIA celebrating this? Instead, the vibrancy of local flavors is being replaced by the bland sameness of foreign coffe chains, croissants, and cakes. More AUTHENTIC local options would be a delight!- especially for those leaving home and craving one last nasi lemak or kuey teow or teh tarik or curried roti?

Once, travelers could enjoy authentic Malaysian dishes like kaya toast, prawn noodles, and teh tarik. Now, the F&B scene is overrun by global chains like Starbucks and Gloria Jean‚Äôs. Surely, KLIA can do better by making space for homegrown eateries that showcase Malaysia‚Äôs rich culinary diversity?- take a page out of Jakarta or Singapore airport.

To add to the frustration, the monorail is still out of service (I‚Äôve lost count how long I‚Äôve waited), forcing travelers to rely on slow and inefficient shuttle buses. And when I asked an ‚ÄòAsk Me For Help‚Äô staff member for food recommendations, she barely looked up from her phone. Customer service should be better than this!

KLIA, let‚Äôs do better! Support local businesses and bring back the authentic Malaysian experience to travellers.

P.S. if you‚Äôre ever at the Satellite building of KLIA terminal 1 (after the shuttle service), I highly recommend visiting the Jungle Boardwalk - a small beautiful green forest in the middle of the building üòÑ I always look forward to visiting it if my Gate is located there. üå¥üå≥üå¥

Edit:DO NOT USE GRAB ehailing, especially advance booking. You'll get the most greedy and unfriendly driver ever.

Use BOLT.
Your welcome for cheaper ride.

bypass airport expensive surcharge by using trains. Use the ERL and drop off at Salak Tinggi. And you can get cheaper ehailing ride.

Dear traveler, do NOT use "taxi" that waiting at the airport. They "offer" you a ride for rm300-400. You should only get a ride via ehailing service, I recommended BOLT. A ride from airport to Kuala Lumpur should not exceed RM80, MAX. If a 4 seats it RM50 MAX. If you book an ehailing, driver can't ask more money from you. Pay what in the app. If driver ask for more money, record them & car number plate, and go to police station to submit a report. Those driver who doesn't use the app / ask for more money is the betrayal to Malaysia.
uncomfortable chairs. should add a mcdonald my sister says. too many bones in the chicken i ate. why don‚Äôt you just remove the bones????:(
AK278 L1 missing flights give me one star

Slow process to check in! Checked in online without any check in bags/luggage but still have to wait in line! Frustrating!

Overflow line for Emirates economy.
The roads, around KLIA buildings, are lighted very dim. The exits and entrances to building parking ramp are poorly lighted.

My flight was delayed by 2 hours and that wasnt even the worst part. I missed my flight because they didnt announce that the plane was leaving (i was at 7/11 eating because i was hungry) so when i went back to check, there was no one there.

So bad 1 people check in 30 minutes
The staff works very slowly
Made me miss my flight and unable to check in even though I went to check in 2 hours before

It is a world famous airport, and has multiple connectivity to go to different countries. But very normal( or less) facilities and without Money Transfer store at L10-L20 gates. I was very disappointed with these at these gates. There should be improvement.

inside are allllll ok but the outside sucks especially the arrival hall. some cars parked without drivers on the left lane and causing traffic jams to the other two lanes. please do something to cars that park on the left lane. so selfish. tolong la tunggu kat tempat lain dulu. security only ask to go foward to the other two lane but did not ask left lane to move foward.  üëéüèªüëéüèªüëéüèª

not convenient to collect luggage if travelers are at the international flight building, as travelers have to take train to domestic flight building to retrieve their luggages which felt wasting of time, it should have a better solution and design to combine for both the domestic and international travelers.

A five-hour break costs 1,700 yuan, so I‚Äôd better just eat a 23-yuan bowl of instant noodles.
The cannellini noodles and fried rice inside are both very hard, so don‚Äôt be offended.
Only the curry chicken with white rice is the best, the others are just fine.

To Entrance to Boarding Gate you have to walk a lot..And A bit difficult to find ways

I had the worst experience in this airport for travelling.  This looks fancy but very old school.
Restaurant not enough air con at night time. Sweating when eating

Very confusing direction or procedure. I was required to transferred here from overseas to KKIA (domestic) i was not required to take my lugguage while I gone through the customs here. Then walked all the way from international to domestic from the international building. But then I was required to "enter" the Malaysia border again while I was in KKIA (I took domestic) with my checked in luggage and scanning my index fingers
When i went back from KK to KL, I only required to go thru the custom once at KKIA. I was expecting to go thru the domestic building so I can get some local products.
Then my hand luggage was required to go thru x ray just at the gate. My flask was full of water. But it was not required to empty out. And no airline staff at the gate just b4 boarding to check the boarding priority.

As I thought I can walk thru, so I followed the sign. I realised I couldn't walk thru after 5 mins later. Then I walked back and realised the sign was directed incorrectly neat gate G section. One pointing left and the other sign pointed right. I saw few customers including aircrew staff were confused and didn't know which way to go.

Further, the staff was staring at me while was brusing teeth at the washroom at 6am. I realised she's waiting to clean my spot after I finished brushing. She either come back rather than just staring at me. I felt so unconfmy and I was the only passenger there.

I went other less modern airport like ho chi Ming city or in Istanbul. Where still have better experience than in Malaysia

I would like to give 0 out of 5 stars but cannot give to it.The toilet staff in KLIA 1(malay lady) besides costa coffee make me feel mad.A cleaner there,Hope that can fired she.I am a travelers and when I using toilet she mcm marah marah tak mau kerja.if u don't want to work better u stay at home right?

We went to terminal 2 to get our flights, very disappointed with Air Asia, they weren‚Äôt helpful at all! Despite having kids, still we were made to wait for so much time to check in our luggage, they kept directing us towards self check in but that wasn‚Äôt working! When we addressed our issue to the staffs they weren‚Äôt friendly , we were made to wait for more than 45 mins just to check in 3 luggages! It wasn‚Äôt crowded also! Also they charged so much if there is extra luggage! Very dissatisfied and Very poor Organization! Despite reaching the airport very much in advance, because of the inefficient Air Asia team, we were so delayed. Finally by the time we cleared immigration and security checks we barely had 15 mins before they closed the gates, we literally had to run all the way to bay L16 while carrying our kids and carry-on bags to catch the flight. Please don‚Äôt book Air Asia if you happen to have extra luggage, better choose it only if you have carry-on bags less than 7kg, totally not kid friendly and not customer friendly as well!

It's a gigantic airport, but unlike other mega-airports, it's not easy to find your way around. Fortunately, the police and airport staff are very friendly and helpful. But you have to be prepared for time and take things slowly. To board a domestic flight from an international airport, it took us almost an hour, including the transfer (by bus), then the elevator, then reprinting the boarding pass (because the previous one no longer worked), then finding the domestic flight exit, then going through carry-on baggage control (you have to remove all electronic devices from your backpack, unlike at other airports where they are checked inside your luggage). In a word, take your time and take your time!

Actually, it shouldn't even get a star. The immigration queue is very long. Only a few counters are open and very slow. Almost missed the flight even though there was another hour before boarding time. The airport layout is also terrible and complicated.

On the way there, I had to take a bus from the terminal building in the middle of the airport to the main passenger building. The wait was long and the walk was very far.

The bathroom was dirty and smelled bad. The baggage check point in front of the gate was slow and unorganized.

Exhausting.. you need to have at least a year of airport work experience to just transit through this airport. It took nearly 2 hrs from landing to sitting down at our gate. So much is automated, and very few staff members to help, so when something goes wrong - like when the self bag-drop off machine stops working.. with one of our bags halfway through the conveyor, we were left for ages, not knowing what to do. So many more hurdles to jump such as filling in an MDAC, yes, we were asked to fill it in on-line at Siem Reap, but thought it couldn't possibly be for us as so many 'mandatory' boxes were irrelevant to us. However, at the airport, they insisted we filled it in with a bunch of false information, i.e. the address where we would be staying (had to put in an they address provided.. which was the airport's address) a waste of time, as we felt we could miss our connecting flight. We also had to create our own baggage tags, then TWO separate baggage screenings - so unnecessary. So many options of queues without clear instructions, so many people, so much walking - it just seemed chaotic. It's not my favourite airport. If we weren't so tired.. we had been travelling all day, I would have said a pretty average airport.

To be very frank. I just came from Singapore airport and back to malaysia. It is heaven and hell comparison. Why the management took for long to upgrade the train? I paid premier for MAS and I got s*** service from start to the end. I gotta wait 30 mins for my bus ride to the main terminal. What a joke.

Average airport, but pricey. Coffee, sandwich, travel necessities - be prepared to pay more. 2 coffees plus 2 sandwiches equaled almost RM120. At least there are some dispensers for free water.

Boarding is very slow due to extra security checks at the gates.

Plan at least another 30-40 minutes (the difference between the boarding time on your ticket vs the actual boarding time) for this second and very slow check.

Once you‚Äôre through this gate security check, there‚Äôs a waiting area with no toilets and no water. So please take care is your needs BEFORE queueing for the gate security check.

Second, the gate security check is hyper sensitive. My wife‚Äôs passport - which she held in her hand - triggered it. They make you take off shoes and belts if those contain small metal bits. My empty laptop backpack went through the scanner twice and I have no idea why‚Ä¶ ü§∑üèº‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è
Who knew that you have to take a bus to C gates    give yourself enough time
It is usually tiring to transfer you by bus from one hall to another and you may make a mistake and you will be back outside because there is only one and two

(Emerites specifically from KL).. KL is a beautiful airport, super clean, very convenient with English signs everywhere- with many options for drink and food land side before security - coffee, mcdonald‚Äôs, taco bell and high end malaysian restaurants. NOTE: the few Emirates flights that leave from here, despite what you may read, have NO bag drop, have no kiosks to print your bag tag or boarding pass, and if you are checking a bag you have to stand in the forever line with people going to Dubai with 5 giant suitcases. Not having an Emirates bag drop or kiosk is ridiculous. NOTE: Terminal C gates - the entire terminal stinks of cigarettes and the none care security has for looking at carry on‚Äôs is terrifying. Many didn‚Äôt even look at the screens, they were too busy dillydallying.
Smoking area only in building C.

You go through 2 securities and end up in area that says duty free. Bought 4 waters thinking i could bring on the plane (which were overpriced) and just before the gate there is another security and they say your not allowed to bring water through. Then you end up in a area with 1-2 shops with little option to buy drinks.

Honestly, if I could give this airport a -1, I would. Very slow, very disorganised, awful attitude. Very lazy. Very rude and disrespectful.  Will never return, nor use such airlines again! Absolutely disgusting!
Cannot cope the capacity
Beautiful but very far from the city, which you can reach by express train (about ‚Ç¨11) or by taxi/grab (there is no Uber in Malaysia)

This was our arrival airport in Malaysia from Paris and our departure airport for Langkawi. It's about an hour from downtown Kuala Lumpur.
I find that there are some areas where there aren't enough flight display screens.
There aren't enough seats/chairs in the boarding areas, which makes it crowded.
Everything is done differently from other well-known airports, and not for the better.
Good internet connection but very limited and friendly staff and there is limited seats for the people to sit. Sorry but an international airport should have enought seats
Not enough chairs near the gates before security check. Food is unusually expensive and of so-so quality.
Have to take shuttle bus to get to my gate. No water dispenser after security gate. Have to wait until you get on the plane.

This airport needs water dispensers after every security screening. If you must insist on screening at the gate, you must allow people to access free and drinkable water.
I have been coming here for 20 years and still yet to see this small uplift.

Worst airport I‚Äôve ever been at. When I landed I stood in line for 1,5 hours at immigration!! Landed in terminal 2 and my next flight was from terminal 1, the shuttle bus took 20-30 minutes. After I checked in for my next line I had to stand another hour  to get thru immigration??? I almost missed my flight, my layover was 3,5-4 hours and I still had to run to the plane when it was boarding!! People working at the airport are not helpful. Very ineffective airport!!
They need to get more people at work.
Get out of the plane, hand over everything that security wants for themselves, and get back on the plane.
The road from the apron to the airport is too far.
Looks like a lot of construction going on in the terminal, that makes it feel chaotic. But overall it is a smooth experience from gate to taxi.

Unfortunately, my experience at Kuala Lumpur International Airport was disappointing. Here are a few points that struck me negatively:
1. Strict baggage control, but not consistent:
My hand luggage was accurately weighed, and even though it was only slightly over 7kg, I was told to pay extra. At the same time, the Malaysian woman in front of me, weighing almost 8 kg, was allowed to walk away - that felt unfair.
2. Poor Signage:
Some gates had no numbers, which was extremely confusing. It was difficult to find the right path.
3. Lack of seating:
There were no seats at the gate, which made the wait unnecessarily tiring.
4. Inadequate Toilets:
The women's restrooms were a mess - I waited in line for over 30 minutes and when it was finally my turn, they were dirty. The men apparently had enough toilets as there were no queues.

Unfortunately, the airport was the worst I've ever been to.

The first time I came here, I felt very bad. I didn‚Äôt expect to enter the country because I didn‚Äôt speak English very well. I was called a fool by the immigration staff at the airport, and the staff was very impatient. I thought it was such a solution, but they didn‚Äôt help us solve it in the end. They just asked us to leave and go somewhere else. The attitude was very bad and unfriendly.
Non cooperative attitude.
Coming back to KLIA 1 after so long. As usual very crowded

Most idiotic system I've ever heard of which warrants this airport getting a one star from me. So you go through initial security and I totally understand why you aren't allowed liquids. However, after doing initial security, we filled our refillable water bottles at the designated stations in the airport outside of our gate and then had to go through a second round of security to get into the waiting area for our gate. We were made to empty out our water bottles........no justification. This is the most stupid thing I've ever heard. You might say oh but you can get just get little water bottles on the airplane but what's the point if I've got 1L of water already on me. Way more convenient, not to mention better for the environment by avoiding unnecessary plastic. KL Airport run by total idiots.
The airport with the worst service during my travels..the staff are not friendly and do not solve problems quickly.
My departures gate changed 4 times in 3 hours, and the disorder of the gate number very complicated things in that matter

You lose a fully paid vacation day, including a taxi, because their system reports errors in your passport or visa that don't exist. It's a shame I've never seen before. The number of people who have encountered these "errors" and waited HOURS in line without the opportunity to use the bathroom or buy food or drinks makes you realize the problem isn't with the travelers, but with the airport. Extremely long lines with only one person checking passports.
A disgrace.

I've used it several times for travel/transit.
For some reason, liquids are confiscated at the boarding gate (just before boarding the plane) instead of at the first gate! ! Drinks and liquids purchased at the airport, as well as water filled at water points at the airport, will also be confiscated! Are you going to take care of me? üòíThat's why I can't bring drinking water on the plane...that's weird! üôÇ‚Äç‚ÜîÔ∏è
Take care~üòá

I hate it why do I have to even say this customer service is bad like no business they are treating us like we are slaves. Staffs so rude and won't let me even go to the lounge as when I wanted to check in she shouted on me like I killed her family and she took my passport and she hurt my hand injury in the plane is bad they didn't even do anything.

Since the sale of cigarettes and tobacco is legal in the country, there should be smoking areas at every Terminal. Smoking is Legal and it would be a good thing, in 2025, not to make smokers who travel feel ghettoized. You cannot make them spend hours in front of the gates without ensuring a smoking area. It is embarrassing for a world capital. Those who smoke in designated areas do not cause any harm to non-smokers: following and pursuing these embarrassing policies is only harmful.

Inside KLIA airport, there are no toilets at the last gate for departing passengers and there are very limited seats in front of the gate. Passengers have to stand for a very long time to enter the last gate.

The shopping area here is great, with plenty of options‚Äîespecially restaurants. However, the transit experience could be much more comfortable. After arriving from one flight, passengers who need to connect must exit the terminal, take a shuttle bus, and endure a long walk. Not the most traveler-friendly setup. As for the immigration officers‚Ä¶ let‚Äôs just say the atmosphere felt quite intimidating.
Poor immigration

Terrible in everything. Baggage management simply embarrassing. From the moment you leave the main airline like Emirates and end up in the hands of their Air Asia the goal becomes to make you pay for extra baggage, do self check in, board your own baggage and they are also rude.
Last trip to Asia

Exactly about a week ago, when I was returning to my country from KLIA 1, I had an unpleasant experience with the X-ray staff at the gate, who had no manners!

During immigration and security checks, I threw away my little brother's water bottle because I knew that international flights don't allow drinks exceeding 100ml.

After that, I saw a water dispenser before entering the gate.
I filled it up there...
But as I was about to enter the gate, the unmannered officer yelled at me and told me to throw the water in the toilet, using a rude tone!

And even worse, when I threw the water in the toilet, my mother was also scolded by the X-ray staff... Crazy, they really have no manners towards their elders!

If drinks aren't allowed in the waiting room, please provide them in the waiting room... Are your airport staff going to take responsibility if we get thirsty? The airport has the worst and strangest regulations I've ever visited... So different from Singapore, Indonesia, and Thailand! EuwwwwwwüôÑüôÑ

Unfortunately, there are still no 0 stars on Google!

Most of the staff were very friendly, only the ladies at C15 for boarding today's TK0061 were the worst! Rude and mean.

The fact that a proper security check only takes place immediately before entering the gate is completely pointless and simply stupid. There are no longer any opportunities to refill your water bottle or buy anything for a long flight at the gate itself.

Whoever came up with this system will hopefully pay for it. Especially since it's many times more expensive to have staff and equipment at every gate.

Regards!

KLIA2 is by far the most disappointing terminal, starting with the immigration service, which completely kills any desire to ever return here.
We‚Äôve been to Malaysia many times, arriving through KLIA, but we‚Äôve never seen such chaos. Over 300 people in line, and only 8 counters open - and working incredibly slowly! We waited in line for 1.5 (!) hours.
What‚Äôs the point of filling out the online arrival form if immigration officers still spend 4-7 minutes on each tourist?
After standing in line for over 1.5 hours and watching how the officers worked, we were left very disappointed. Even worse was how immigration officers treated Asian travelers with darker skin - their gestures were so disrespectful, it was truly unpleasant to witness.

Ah, yes! And before departure immigration process took 30 minutes at 6:30am.

A reasonable processing time at passenger-respecting airports around the world is 15‚Äì20 minutes.
But not at KLIA2 - here, the staff act like they‚Äôre doing you a favor by letting you enter or leave the country.
What a shame!

Layout is confusing and staff are horrible, especially the immigration staff. We were directed to join the family line, only to be told by the immigration officer in the rudest manner, that only one adult could accompany the baby, and the rest of the family had to queue up normally. I have never experienced this at any airport before, and it happened twice! It's no wonder that tourists from the Gulf no longer like to visit Malaysia if this is how you treat guests.

Horrible experience!!!  This is the worst airport I have been to. There is no seating area before immigration. The way the flight schedule is displayed is not user friendly. Announced in the terminal 2 building are inaudible, the flight schedule is so dispersed and no power outlets for chatting only USB type A. Airline kiosk staff is sassy . I missed my flight because of severe logistic issues. Had to stay is all night at the airport to catch h the next flight. No flights schedule displayed at  terminal H10 . It was like a ghost town. I never want to come here again. I was at the airport from 2:00pm and have to leave at 7:04 am just because of poor planning and communication.

It's still a great airport that meet the customers demand, but there are some run down facility and hardware, such as rugged carpet in the arrival, some run down toilets with dim lamps. However the immigration section is seems to improve
Too bad there's no autogate

This is Malaysia's largest airport and main gateway for overseas visitors to enter Malaysia. At peak times, be prepared to wait a very long time for your checked in luggage to come out. The aerotrain connecting the terminals is still out of order.

Extremely hot and poor ventilation. Definitely feels like a developing nation's airport. Somehow I thought it got better, once Malaysian has proven the fact that we are consistently continuing from one poor management to another poor management. Big guys involved just ask WIIFM, while management are of similar mentality.
Unclear markings

They have the worst airport ground crew staff quality, particularly the staff in charge of the flight to Danang at Gate 2 on 26 Sept 2025 abiut 11:00 am. All three Malay female staff shouted at passengers as if the passengers are prisoners.
Airport look worn down.
Immigration is the worst. The slowest in the world I think.

My recent experience at Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) was nothing short of frustrating. From the airline to the moment I arrived, the service was abysmally slow, and the staff was unhelpful.

The immigration officers are rude and disrespectful, making an already stressful experience far worse. To be honest, it felt like the staff were completely uninterested in their job, and some even seemed to resent being there.

When my family arrived at the immigration counter, the officer seemed confused when we asked whether he wanted to see our MDAC or passports first. He glanced at our passports and then repeatedly said, "You don‚Äôt look British." When we asked why he was being rude, he flew into a rage and yelled, "What do you mean I am being rude! You‚Äôre not welcome here. Go back to where you came from."

At first, I thought I could be overreacting, but as the situation unfolded, it made me wonder if this could be a case of racial bias, especially toward darker-skinned people. It‚Äôs hard not to perceive this as racism when the treatment felt so harsh and unwarranted. But then, a white female tourist recounted her own experience, and she was visibly shaken, nearly on the verge of tears. She too had been yelled at and bullied by the Malaysian airport staff. To make matters worse, I also witnessed an Indian woman being denied entry to the bathroom just to retrieve her bag. After numerous attempts she managed to get them back.

This made me realize that it wasn‚Äôt just about skin colour‚Äîthough it was hard not to make that connection‚Äîbut rather a broader issue with the staff‚Äôs attitude toward tourist and travellers. The customer service here has drastically declined. This used to be a place where visitors were welcomed with warmth and respect, but unfortunately, that‚Äôs no longer the case. It‚Äôs a shame to see such a decline.

In Malaysia, government jobs, including those at airports prioritize ethnic Malays over Indian and Chinese Malays. As a result, some government positions, such as immigration officers or airport staff, may be filled based on ethnicity rather than merit or qualifications. Due to this, individuals in these roles might lack the necessary qualifications or passion for the job, which can sometimes be reflected in their job performance and attitude.

What really stood out was the slogan displayed upon arrival: ‚ÄúWe hope you‚Äôve enjoyed our Malaysian Hospitality.‚Äù Frankly, this felt more like an empty promise than a reflection of the experience I had. A service should speak for itself, but in this case, it was clear that overcompensating with slogans only highlights the gap between what is advertised and what is actually delivered.

Given this experience, I will never fly with Malaysian Airlines or visit Malaysia again and I certainly won't be encouraging my friends or family to visit. Avoid countries that do not respect and appreciate tourist coming to help their economy!

After 2 weeks of trip in Malaysia, I headed to KLIA terminal 2 for my next destination.

Due to the unexpected flight delay, I had to wait 7 hours, outside of security check points. I was quite surprised that this big international airport doesn‚Äôt have a single seat for public who have to wait for flights. Only way to find seats were eating or drinking in the restaurant. It was very disappointing experience.

I wish KLIA terminal 2 make seats for public outside of the security check points, so tourists who couldn't check-in yet can take some break before they check-in.

I have nothing good to say about Kuala Lumpur. Never recommend going through this airport. We had a 2 hour lay over coming back from Thailand to Perth. The plane left 1 hour early no emails no messages nothing to let us no. We go to the terminal no one was there. I then asked 4 different security, workers at the airport for help even the ones that could speak English didn‚Äôt want to help us at all. We walk around with tears for more than an hour trying to find where to go. Instead they sent us to the wrong area told us x1
The route to baggage claim upon arrival is quite confusing. When leaving the country, your baggage will be inspected twice, so it's a good idea to keep this in mind and hurry up a bit.
Ordinary airport

Electronic passport control on arrival doesn't work properly for international flights arrivals. Result in constant ques in the airport in immigration 2 hours standing in a que. I have noticed that it is working on arraval from Airasia terminal only.

Well, this airport is so outdated and crappy. All the staff are very slow, I barely missed my flight because of them. They are just like lazy dogs or hate their jobs. They should be trained to be more efficient.

Perhaps KL staff management could explain why passengers transferring who've already been through security at Heathrow airport need to go through additional security at the gate. And if you're going to take water off people, why don't you at least provide water at the gate so people can refill their bottles. Have you tried a 13-hour flight with no water? Try being a customer on your own service and see how it feels. Customer experience level 0.

This is the worst airport in the world. The check-in system often crashes, the staff are arrogant, and many security channels are not working. Due to the backwardness of the airport, there are frequent delays. However, AirAsia still takes off. I suspect it's really a primitive tribe.

Dear Airport Authority,

I am writing to formally express my disappointment regarding my experience at KLIA 2 on 28 January 2025 at 3:38 AM while waiting for the departure hall to open.

One of your customer service staff (a Chinese male) informed us that the hall would open at 3:00 AM. However, when the hall was still closed at 3:10 AM, we asked another staff member (a Malay female), who then told us it would open at 4:00 AM. When we mentioned that her colleague had stated an earlier opening time, her response was:

"Then you ikut apa yang dia cakap lah."

When we further inquired about the actual opening time, she dismissively said:

"Then you tunggu hall buka lah."

I find this attitude highly unprofessional and unacceptable, especially for airport staff who are expected to assist passengers courteously. Providing inconsistent information and responding rudely to simple inquiries only creates confusion and frustration.

I urge you to look into this matter and ensure that staff are properly trained to handle customer queries in a respectful and professional manner. Additionally, clear and accurate information regarding the departure hall opening time should be provided to avoid unnecessary inconvenience for passengers.

I appreciate your prompt attention to this issue and look forward to your response.

This airport made me never want to come back to Malaysia. Who designed this place?!

First, the walk from the plane to immigration and baggage claim was unbelievably long. I‚Äôve traveled through many large airports, but I‚Äôve never had to walk this much just to reach my luggage. I could overlook that‚Ä¶ but what came next was even worse.

After collecting our bags and passing immigration, we were forced to walk through (GET THIS!) A MALL to get to the exit. Yes, a literal mall where every airport in the world you'd be checking your transportation to finally leave. After a long flight, the last thing anyone wants is to be dragged through a maze of stores just to leave the airport. It felt like a cash grab, not a travel hub.

We finally made it out and were relieved to see Grab was available (we‚Äôre used to it from Thailand). But when we booked a ride, the wait time was 35 minutes! There was a huge, overcrowded Grab waiting area with screens showing incoming car plates, clearly, demand was way beyond what the airport could handle.

Tired and frustrated, we gave up on Grab, hoping to catch a bus instead. But we weren‚Äôt allowed to buy tickets until exactly 12 AM, which was also the listed departure time of the bus, because it's too late now to buy tickets (15 minutes ahead). We were told the bus would leave even after 12. The whole thing felt disorganized and unclear and the wait time seemed same as the Grab and the destination station is not even close to the hotel.

In the end, we paid over double the Grab fare to take a regular taxi, just to get the hell out of there.

Oh and did I mention that the airport wifi is not available once you finish immigration? I had such a hard time to book the Grab and check information and chat with my airbnb host because there was no wifi after immigration, because there's a freakin' mall between the airport and the exits!!!

This airport is a logistical mess and a terrible first impression of Malaysia. I've never thought an airport would affect my will to visit a country but here we are.

Overall ok.

I don't know if I can't see it, but I'm at the Gate B4 domestic departure, and I can't find a rubbish bin to throw my trash. I see a few rubbish laying around, I assume they also can't find a rubbish bin. Please have this in all your gates, and all around the airport. People don't want to litter, but there's not enough rubbish bin around. Will update more.

Everything is nice and new, but they make you throw away any liquid at the gate just before boarding the plane.
Disgraceful.
Staff don‚Äôt have a clue and it‚Äôs not particularly clean
Terrible toilets condition.  Long que at immigration

I rarely give 1-star reviews, but this airport truly deserves it. The boarding process is poor. The security machines are outdated and the taxis are old and dirty, showing no signs of improvement in decades. Even the so-called premium taxis are worse than budget taxis in many other countries. After a post-COVID renovation, they still use manual water taps. Isn‚Äôt contactless supposed to matter after COVID? Hard to believe this place gets 4 or 5 stars.
The transit train is still not ready. The bus driver who drove between satellite and main terminal are reckless.

Very large airport. Efficient check-in, immigration and security clearance. However the waiting area is the worst compared to other international airports I the region. There are not enough seats and restrooms near the gates after security. It doesn't seem they want tourists to come back

Immigration took a long time, the queue was very long, the connection was intermittent, the officers were mean and angry, it was not clear, the gate took a long time to open, there were very few seats, many people sat on the floor, very inappropriate, very disturbing to my activities and other people's activities, the connection was very bad, often disconnected, everything is complete at this airport, really annoying

It's a gigantic airport, but unlike other mega-airports, it's not easy to find your way around. Fortunately, the police and airport staff are very friendly and helpful. But you have to be prepared for time and take things slowly. To board a domestic flight from an international airport, it took us almost an hour, including the transfer (by bus), then the elevator, then reprinting the boarding pass (because the previous one no longer worked), then finding the domestic flight exit, then going through carry-on baggage control (you have to remove all electronic devices from your backpack, unlike at other airports where they are checked inside your luggage). In a word, take your time and take your time!
If u fly domestic u will have difficulty to refill water at KLIA2
Not enough counter, always long queue to check in.

Very badly organised, you go trough security twice and ac barely working. People cutting in lines all the time. Of course not enough place to sit in gate, hard to fin a charging spot and you are greeted by rude Air Asia staff enforcing payment for every possible gram beyond limit.

1. Airport (specially departure area) has limited food options/vendors, resulting in high prices of available food items compared to market.
2. Flights of Air Asia and Gatik Airlines (Malindo) intend delayed without timely inform8ng passengers resulting in un-necessary waiting time

An irritating airport experience at KLIA1. Making people pour away water due to security right at the gate, then providing no refill stations after security is ridiculous.

The whole terminal experience is irritating from start to finish.

Provide refil taps.

The airport is constantly under construction, but it's easy to navigate, and the staff is helpful. However, the immigration counters are very meticulous, and it sometimes takes up to an hour to be admitted. Unfortunately, the digital arrival form, which must be completed prior to entry, doesn't speed up the process at the counters.

This airport made me never want to come back to Malaysia. Who designed this place?!

This airport is a logistical mess and a terrible first impression of Malaysia. I've never thought an airport would affect my will to visit a country but here we are.

KLIA is an international airport that always feels like a poor budget airport that is falling apart. Ironically, it is overstaffed by an army of smiling greeters.

On Sunday, 22 June 2025, we saw water dispenser stations broken and unrepaired. "Free drinks" stations abandoned, unmanned.

The only smoking room in the airport is a filthy room covered in black soot: incredibly smelly, no ventilation systems, piles of ash, trash, and butts all over. Warning: Enter at your own risk.

The aerotrain was being repaired, and although bus services were provided, no signs were available to passengers on where it is. Bus services from the sub terminal to the main terminal were not easy to find.

Tragically, the contrast between KLIA and KLIA2 (the latter an actual budget terminal that's well designed, modern, clean, and efficient) has never been clearer.

Once touted as a modern design airport with state of the art facilities, this has fallen far where maintenance has taken a back seat.   The train which services between the terminals has not run for 2 years at least, the air-conditioning is either turned to a low level or not functioning cos I was sweating profusely while waiting in line (check in).   There's more to add to the list of woes, but anyway,  it is a point of transit, and it works.     Could really do with sprucing up. After all, it's the first impression of our country for millions of visitors.
Don't get a transfer flight here. It is a joke. Bad signage and the terminals are incredibly far apart.
Be sure to confirm the location of the terminal where you are flying. . Otherwise, the distance between the first flight and the second flight is really far enough...

The airport use to be one of the best airports around some countries.

Since 1998 the airport management has not even changed the fans in some of  the smoking rooms , very dirty very bad condition,  one of the worst around the world.

The train has been taking more it should to be renovated.

The First impression to KLIA is 1/10

Malaysia is tourism country and the airport doesn't help that.
The immigration line up ( in and out ) is really  a mess .. I seen many time people missing the flights due to the long line ups.

I wish it's solved ASAP.

Awful, terribly outdated experience. Queues and a complete lack of speed at every turn, from initial check in, passing through security, waiting in line for immigration, then again through customs and final baggage checks prior to getting on the plane. Allocate 3-4 hours if you want a less stressful experience. KLIA + airline management, what do you actually do? Are you sleeping?
Best Airport, but immigration is very slow.
Very limited dining restaurant inside KLIA 1 international departure hall.... not even comparable to thier neighbour countries airport

The airport is very nice, but it's too far from the city and not well signposted, so it's easy to get lost. The staff is very friendly and helpful, but keep in mind that you have to leave well in advance, especially if there's traffic. There are many security measures inside, but if you want to buy something, you have to leave and go through security on the way back.

The airport itself is pretty decent, but the helpline and hospitality staff could use some work. They weren‚Äôt very friendly or helpful. And most of the lounges don‚Äôt even serve alcohol, which is a bummer since Malaysia is a popular tourist destination.

This was by far the worst and most unacceptable experience I‚Äôve ever had with any airline. At the Batik Air baggage counter in Kuala Lumpur before flight OD171 to Denpasar, I was shouted at, threatened, and pressured into paying a baggage fee of 650 MYR, with the amount changing several times without explanation. First it was more, then less, then suddenly 650 ‚Äì it was chaotic and clearly unprofessional.

The staff member at the baggage scale used aggressive language, raised their voice, and intimidated me in front of other passengers. I felt unsafe and coerced. This was not a normal excess baggage fee ‚Äì it felt like extortion. I complied because I felt I had no choice.

This is absolutely not the standard I expect from any airline, especially not from Batik Air, which previously had my trust. I have filed a formal complaint with the airline and am awaiting a refund and investigation.

I strongly warn other travelers: If you‚Äôre flying from Kuala Lumpur with Batik Air, be cautious at the baggage counter. Keep records, film interactions, and don‚Äôt let yourself be bullied.

I arrived at T2 on a late-night flight. I missed the last train and looked for Glab, but the sign said it was in a restricted area. It was raining, so I had no choice but to take a taxi. Glab was 78 ringgit, but the driver said he would take me to the hotel for 100, so I got in, but when we arrived, he wanted me to pay 100 dollars. I later looked online and found that there was a Glab stop nearby. Don't get into touted taxis, as they will scam you.

This is Malaysia's largest airport and main gateway for overseas visitors to enter Malaysia. At peak times, be prepared to wait a very long time for your checked in luggage to come out. The aerotrain connecting the terminals is still out of order.

The KLIA T2 airport is new, but design and service are not international standard. First of all: there are at least 4 checks after check in: first security check is to check your passport and boarding pass, then first (preliminary) baggage check. Then you go for normal immigration check. Don‚Äôt relax there as closer to your gate wing there is a proper security check. The wings are very very long, so is 8000 steps by the time of boarding. There not enough female toilet: queue in each of 2 in my wing were 20+ females. If you arrive to terminal 2 there is another issue, they don‚Äôt allow trolleys from the plane arrival gate to the exit from the airport, I had to change trolley twice: I e I used 3 trolleys. Immigration queue - 1 hour. There is no green and red corridor in customs, all luggage goes through screening. All shopping split in zones between all these 4 checks. Flying via KL is cheap but service is cheap too

Quite a long distance to departure hall...
The only advantage is that KLIA2 offer free buggy services for elderly etc. But I didn't see any on the departure level...
There is still room for improvement...

checked in at terminal one and my gate is also at terminal one but I need to walk to G1 to take the shuttle bus to opposite of terminal one. Really not very convenient and confusing. Other than that it's an ok airport.

17 Feb 2023. The airport is in dire straits. At the main terminal, all lounges are closed except for Malaysia airline lounge. Wifi can be connected but no internet connection. Dual flight sharing gates and when 1st flight is delayed, passenger for 2nd flight cannot check in the gate (see photo), Starbucks, Old town white coffee are crowded and full, e-scooter (service personnel) zipping around in the airport at high speed, insufficient seats at some area and passengers have to sit on the floor. Even Rolex shop is closed. Airport is at least 50mins away from KL/PJ! Hope this airport will be improved in my next trip.2nd photo
My next trip arriving into KLIA. Luggage collection. Wait 45mins to 1 hour.

To get between T1 and T2, you can take the bus or KLIA.
Be aware that there aren't many buses.

Few seats/ places to sit/charge devices / activities for those transitioning to intl flights. Zero vegan food (only vegetarian options and most of them are not suitable for vegans, and the staff doesn‚Äôt understand what vegan is). At least they had plant milk for coffee but it‚Äôs expensive. The staff at security checkpoints doesn‚Äôt help with anything (not even ensuring the luggage line runs smoothly). It‚Äôs clean and but that‚Äôs about it.
Very slow service
Less comfortable
The airport is so big that you might get lost.

Ok the man in k row on Friday night was lack of patience i asked him and his answer was unpolitly almost screaming at my face my question was where is saudi Airlines and he snapped at me and his eyes got bigger..all of this for just on question while he is preparing the tape lines ver bad behaviour and this may reflect on the airport reputation,  you have to patience with t4avellers even though was overwhelmed

The area around Gate L is very poorly organized. All the people are in the hallways when the rooms are closed, creating unnecessary congestion. The smell of food is unbearable, and there aren't enough bathrooms.
The free airport wifi was so free that it ran away.
Very inconvenient for senior citizens and children. Have to walk a long up and down zigzag corridor to reach immigration check point. There is undue delay at the

Cold and unhelpful staffs. Not everyone's Malaysian so be more accommodating for foreigners instead of laughing at them for making mistake due to the airport misinformation. Worst airport, slow, boring. I hate coming here.

It's a step backwards. The tram in the airport has not been repaired yet. Today I still have to queue up to go downstairs to wait for the bus shuttle. It's been a whole year since the last time I came. What are the relevant employees doing?
Beautiful but services slow

Remove that Piano for goodness sake ‚Ä¶ I got migraine listening to all the people banging it

The immigration customs was extremely slow, which proved that we had indeed arrived in Southeast Asia. This slow customs officer took an average of nearly five minutes to trouble each passenger. He was a bit arrogant, which was quite annoying.

Terrible! The signage is confusing. I landed in Terminal 2 and had to take the shuttle over to Terminal 1. This was supposed to be the shuttle, but we stopped at the Long Term Parking Lot. That was where the driver decided to take a lunch break, so we stopped there for a while before moving on.

The airport layout is very confusing. There are no clear signs, and it was extremely difficult to find the lounge. I don‚Äôt understand why there are so many checkpoints to go through. Had a very unpleasant experience. The staff insisted I pour out my liquids in the toilet, even though the sign clearly stated to dispose of them in front of the scanner. Additionally, there was no water dispenser available in the waiting area.

The quality of the airport ground crew was appalling, particularly the staff assigned to the flight to Danang at Gate 2 on 26 September 2025, at around 11:00 a.m. All three Malay female staff members shouted at passengers as though they were prisoners, which was completely unacceptable and unprofessional.

The most important thing to people in this world right now is connectivity. To their phones, family & friends, social media, data and most importantly while traveling remote work.

This airport is beautiful and has a great process of getting through. The mall is mind blowing but all of that goes down the drain and significantly impacts your rating when while inside I can‚Äôt connect to the internet long enough to send an email because the server or signal is soooo bad. Fix it please‚Ä¶.

The only airport in the world i know, where you are not alloid to bring your refilable water to the gate. Security control is right at the gate and inside the small waiting room is no refil possible. Thats not sustainable. The only possibility is buying something at the shops

Worst airport ever experienced! The attitude of Batik Air Malaysia staff and all the staff present at the airport were poor, unable to support passengers at all! Batik Air Malaysia staff had a bad attitude! They told passengers like this: ‚ÄúCLOSED! NONE OF MY BUSINESS‚Äù when passengers only had 1 hour to board the plane and refused to print the boarding pass for the passengers, and responded with the worst attitude possible!!

Such a bad airport to leave via. Takes ages to get to some gates, multiple security checks and all the shops are before security so you can‚Äôt buy water for your flight. The immigration process needs to improve immediately. It took me so long every time  I‚Äôve visited. Approximately more than 1 hr.

I had an extremely disappointing experience at Malaysia‚Äôs Airport Terminal 2. It was overcrowded with long lines, and the staff was not only unhelpful but also rude. One of the officers took my Dior and Chanel perfumes, which were under 100ml and purchased from duty-free, claiming they were not allowed. He kept them in his pocket without any proper explanation.

In addition, he confiscated all of my expensive purchases and seemed greedy and unprofessional, as though he had never seen such items before. He even pressured me by asking, ‚ÄúDo you want to catch your flight or not?‚Äù This made me feel very intimidated, especially since I was traveling alone.

Furthermore, although I was allowed 7kgs in check-in, the lady at the counter charged me approximately 130 RM for an extra weight charge, despite my prior allowance. I tried explaining the situation, but she ignored me.

I would not recommend anyone visit Malaysia based on this experience. The way they treat tourists is appalling, and I felt threatened and mistreated.

Shame on Malysians !

The worst airport that I have ever visited in this 2025 from over 10airports. How that possible that flight landed at 9am but now 11am I still don‚Äôt pass through the immigration. I‚Äôm talking about 2HOURS on queue. SO PLEASE FIX THIS especially the 35-37counters. Work SO SO SO SO SLOW while other like 31-33, those who came after me already gone!!!

Malaysia, I visited it a lot. Kuala Lumpur Airport is considered one of the worst airports, as I have seen in the staff's dealings with travelers, no respect or appreciation for the visitor.

The worst, most confusing airports (2) no clear signage, overpriced, unhelpful staff, poor food selection, business lounges offer nothing, miles to walk - Avoid it if you can

I am writing to provide feedback on my recent experience flying to KLIA via Singapore Airlines. While I generally appreciate the quality of service on Singapore Airlines flights, I was disappointed with the airport experience at KLIA, especially considering this was not a budget flight.

Although the airport is large and packed with many shops and eateries, there are a few areas that could be improved to facilitate smoother transit for arriving passengers. These include clearer directional signs and more readily available information.

Upon arrival, after disembarking from the plane, we were directed by a staff member to go to C15 for a transfer to the arrival hall. The signage for this transfer was unclear, and it took us a while to find the area just to queue for a feeder bus. Would also suggest considering adjusting the volume of the announcement speaker with loud and clear information in English, Chinese, and Malay. Since this airport is named as an international airport, wouldn‚Äôt it be better to have basic international ‚Äústandard‚Äù too?

The situation worsened upon arrival at the arrival hall. The area was extremely crowded,people are in queue of 2 -3 lines in a row....resulting in a queue of over an hour just to clear immigration.
Very disorganized and messy, no one was there to direct the human traffic which leads to all these mess.
After clearing immigration, locating the correct baggage belt was challenging. The area was crowded, and there were only three to four luggage belts where you needed to walk near the belt to check on the medium-sized monitor screen showing which flight these belts are meant for. The screen flashed so fast with so many people trying to catch a glimpse of the information, which was rather frustrating, especially when everyone was looking for the right belt for their luggage. Literally, many passengers were visibly struggling to find their luggage, moving up and down, left and right.

We only found our luggage outside the luggage belt area, where there was a sign with the Singapore Airlines logo on the floor. Quite a handful of luggage was located there, which obviously most of those taking the same flight were still stuck in immigration. Imagine the time taken from the moment we disembark from the plane and just to get out until our luggage was left outside and not at the belt.

Navigating the airport area to find a Grab was also confusing due to the signage much of which was in Malay.
This can be rather challenging, especially after a series of such "events" we went through. We thought maybe this is common for arrival passengers to encounter, who knows we must go through the same things going back.

On our return flight, we were once again required to take a short bus to the departure hall.
Furthermore, there were no water dispensers available after passing through the inspection gate, which was inconvenient.We have to endure our thirst till our flight take off.

As a tourist, I don‚Äôt enjoy it if I have to go through so much hassle just to travel.
Who doesn‚Äôt want hassle-free travel?
For the sake of everyone, I hope this feedback will be taken into consideration for future improvements.

I have nothing good to say about Kuala Lumpur. Never recommend going through this airport. We had a 2 hour lay over coming back from Thailand to Perth. We walk around with tears for more than an hour trying to find where to go. Instead they sent us to the wrong area told us to go to y15. The airport is constantly under construction, but it's easy to navigate, and the staff is helpful. However, the immigration counters are very meticulous, and it sometimes takes up to an hour to be admitted. Unfortunately, the digital arrival form, which must be completed prior to entry, doesn't speed up the process at the counters.

The airport is spacious and beautiful, but the staff work really slowly. I arrived more than three hours before my flight, yet I only made it just in time for boarding and had no chance to eat or shop. There was a long line at the departure passport control, but only two officers on duty. I spent two hours just waiting in line to drop off my baggage and to go through passport control / exit procedures.

Incredible that the aerotrain to C gates in KLIA 1 isn't operational during ASEAN Leaders Summit. Taking buses from main terminal is out of step with the image of a country aspiring to be a major regional player.

Way too few autogates.

Many power outlets broken.
The immigration queue time at this airport is quite frustrating! There are no restaurants in the terminal after immigration. This airport is supposed to be one of the best!
Cold and unhelpful staffs. Not everyone's Malaysian so be more accommodating for foreigners instead of laughing at them for making mistake due to the airport misinformation.

I had the worst experience in this airport for travelling.  This looks fancy but very old school.
Restaurant not enough air con at night time. Sweating when eating

Very confusing direction or procedure given.
I was required to transferred here from overseas to KKIA (domestic) i was not required to take my lugguage while I gone through the customs here. Then walked all the way from international to domestic from the international building. But then I was required to "enter" the Malaysia border again while I was in KKIA (I took domestic) with my checked in luggage and scanning my index fingers
