This airport is terrible. I was there in transit and although the terminal looks good with that rain forest garden in the middle, it is completely disfunctional.
1) Extremely hot
2) Not enough seats in the common departure area
3) No power outlets whatsoever
4) You can only pass security about 1h before your flight
5) NO TOILET AT THE GATE. This is the most absurd‚Ä¶ you have to exit the security area and bring your passport and boarding pass to use the toilet.

If you can avoid it, don‚Äôt use this airport!!!
They will charge you additional tax for Duty free cigarettes or tabbaco.  Any amount, and no visible signs stating this.

We flew with batik air. Check-in and the security checkpoint took minutes. Be aware that batik air seems to weigh your carry-on before boarding, and some people were stopped presumably to pay extra money for going over the maximum weight.

Interestingly enough, even though we also went over our limit, they let us pass without paying.

It feels inefficient for each gate to have its own security checkpoint, and it was confusing on whether we were boarding or not.

Honestly, if you are of African, Chinese, Philippines, Indian, Bengali, Nepalese, any south or south east Asian country think twice before boarding a plane to tour Malaysia or to transiting at Kula Lumpur airport. If you had a good time at this airport, great. If you didn't, avoid it in the future.

The officers that work here are nothing more than poor uneducated people given jobs because they are Muslim Malays. If you are travelling alone they will judge you based on your colour and ethnicity.

I have learnt that a lot of bullying and physical assualt are subjected to people of Bengali, Burmese, Nepalese or sub continent backgrounds. This was specifically from a foreign worker and have verified a lot of similar cases from trip advisor.

I had a friend who witnessed a group of 3-4 female Malaysian officers trying to steal the bag of an Indian girl of Aus/US/UK (can't tell the exact accent) nationality.

I have also seen people get shouted and others being hit! Like what the hell! I have never seen such uncivilised behaviour at an international airport, and I have been to numerous airports across Asia and the middle east.

A lot of Malaysian officers are also thieves. Be careful. I have heard of several incidents where they target individuals travelling alone, in pairs or in small groups getting pulled aside, physically hit and having money taken unlawfully from them.

Though I'm not surprised. It's a Muslim majority country. Usually these people tout about honesty and peace but actually are the polar opposite rude, violent and openly steal.

Like I said, if you are from an African, south or south east Asian background (note specifically not nationality but background) don't bother even going through the airport let alone holidaying here. Spend your hard earned money elsewhere.
bad toilet staff and experience not worth for a international airport
What a backward country, the customs quality is very low! He also steals things from passengers.

Very nice airport with good facilities too. Kind of getting old cuz it ready way back in 1997. It‚Äôs time to improving it. The saddest part is the aero train that connect the terminals have yet to be ready. It has been down for years.

If you are taking a business bus to the arrival hall, fast track is available at immigration checkpoints 49 and 50. Klia has good guidance, but the bus has to go to the station, not the tour. There is a lack of guidance.
The departure terminal has a rather traditional design with no distinctive boarding gate experience and a limited number of stores, although prices are reasonable for an international airport.

Edit: bypass airport expensive surcharge by using trains. Use the ERL and drop off at Salak Tinggi. And you can get cheaper ehailing ride.

Dear traveler, do NOT use "taxi" that waiting at the airport. They "offer" you a ride for rm300-400. You should only get a ride via ehailing service, I recommended BOLT. A ride from airport to Kuala Lumpur should not exceed RM80, MAX. If a 4 seats it RM50 MAX. If you book an ehailing, driver can't ask more money from you. Pay what in the app. If driver ask for more money, record them & car number plate, and go to police station to submit a report. Those driver who doesn't use the app / ask for more money is the betrayal to Malaysia.

This airport made me never want to come back to Malaysia. Who designed this place?!

First, the walk from the plane to immigration and baggage claim was unbelievably long. I‚Äôve traveled through many large airports, but I‚Äôve never had to walk this much just to reach my luggage. I could overlook that‚Ä¶ but what came next was even worse.

After collecting our bags and passing immigration, we were forced to walk through (GET THIS!) A MALL to get to the exit. Yes, a literal mall where every airport in the world you'd be checking your transportation to finally leave. After a long flight, the last thing anyone wants is to be dragged through a maze of stores just to leave the airport. It felt like a cash grab, not a travel hub.

We finally made it out and were relieved to see Grab was available (we‚Äôre used to it from Thailand). But when we booked a ride, the wait time was 35 minutes! There was a huge, overcrowded Grab waiting area with screens showing incoming car plates, clearly, demand was way beyond what the airport could handle.

Tired and frustrated, we gave up on Grab, hoping to catch a bus instead. But we weren‚Äôt allowed to buy tickets until exactly 12 AM, which was also the listed departure time of the bus, "because it's too late now to buy tickets" (15 minutes ahead). We were told the bus would leave even after 12. The whole thing felt disorganized and unclear and the wait time seemed same as the Grab and the destination station is not even close to the hotel.

In the end, we paid almost triple the Grab fare to take a regular taxi, just to get the hell out of there.

And also, the airport wifi is not available once you finish immigration! I had such a hard time to book the Grab taxi and check information and chat with my airbnb host because there was no wifi after immigration, in any airport that's when wifi is needed!! But here there's a freakin' mall between the airport and the exits!!!

I've never had this much hastle and wasted time to manage to exit an airport.

This airport is a logistical mess and a terrible first impression of Malaysia. I've never thought an airport would affect my will to visit a country but here we are.

Good one. Water dispensers are messy as water spillage due to overflow. Difficult to operate. For hot water, please take in four cups, else you will burn your fingers. Currancy exchange counters offer different rates. Good food.
The scanning security method takes some time in boarding gate even if you are transit passenger only should adjust yourself.

The worst airport ever, from the staff working to the airport itself... organization is absolutely zero... they locked us in a small room to wait for boarding time without water, without a toilet, when we asked where we could buy water they told us there was no water, that it was not allowed, that we should have drunk water outside...

Disgusting airport. Upon arrival you are dropped off in the departure area and not in the arrival area, then you go out and go to check the arrival area, in order to pick up your luggage you need to complete a quest. Find a bus that will take you around the field and bring you back to another door. Then you go out. You come to customs control, there is one person sitting and a huge line.

Kalau punya rencana perjalanan ke malaysia lewat KLIA,.perhatikan waktu nya, kalau ada yg mendesak atau pindah pesawat usahakan beri waktu lebih minimal 2 jam karena proses custom nya sangat lama, bisa memakan waktu 1 jam untuk antri dan selesai pemeriksaan, counter petugas yg di buka untuk satu section hanya 2 saja n antrian nya panjang sekali...

Untuk proses check in juga jgn mepet, siapkan minimal 2 jam lbh awal karena sekali lg proses nya sangat lama.

Untuk airport nya sendiri cukup bagus, proses pindah terminal dengan kereta juga bagus.

Fasilitas semua ok, hanya catatan untuk custom aja kalau bisa di tambahkan petugas yg jaga dan di sesuaikan dengan antrian nya

Semangat berbenah.
Been here many times. Horrible immigration processing. Will be dozens of people in line and only 1 officer per lane. Expect long wait times.
Immigration staff is working very slow.
The standard of the airport is lower than all the airports I have been to (Japan, Korea, Taiwan, Australia). Our baggage belt also changes without notice.
Horrible service in immigrations. Staff were chatting with each other instead of tending to a massive queue building up. Was stuck in the line for an hour and a half
The experience was good until you reach the gate where it smells like a smoking room almost unable to breathe.
Din Tai Fung is so expensive. It‚Äôs my first time traveling abroad and I didn‚Äôt know I had to pay for water.

A poor excuse for an international airport..an absolute shambles of a place. Unfortunately for me I had two visits to this dump on what was supposedly short layovers and both times my onward flights had long delays. The staff seem to operate like the airport only opened this morning, avoid any lay over here.
Inefficient and lack of proper planning causing unnecessary queue even before entering the immigration. People, system and infrastructure all should be improved!

Bad attitude and rude for the officer ( male ) at the gate C24

The gate is open at 13:40, we have arrived at on time and the officer say‚Äù get out get out 3 times in Malay ‚Äú we asked why, the gate is already open and the announce also, they said the time is wrong and don‚Äôt know‚Ä¶ really !!!!!

If the time is wrong and gate is open already, don‚Äôt be rude officer, we are not late at all, we do come on time.

Hopefully its not happen work your career

( i did not take any foto due to regulations)

Someone who travelling to malaysia for the 1st time had to write this here .here are the most unfriendly rude ground staffs i have seen..the whole process was so confusing..staffs in thw customer care should work for the welfare of the customers..not to talk rude and show attitude.
The worst free wi-fi ever. Only google search works ((

Awful airport, one of the worst I‚Äôve ever visited. Poor selection of food or drink. Confusing signage. Dirty toilets. We had to do two unnecessary bag security checks where officials weren‚Äôt even paying attention. Overcrowded gates, two flights boarding at once and no system to queue or organise boarding groups. Confusing bag check in for AirAsia, around 40 bag drop counters with no sign or board to tell you which to use, we had to find a member of staff to ask. Only 1 bar with two small beers costing 20USD.
It's easy to get lost. Little or no information. Unfriendly staff.
Bad experience during transit in KLIA, the staff are not helpful, the passengers flow are unorganized, confusing.
bad attitude üôèüèª

I‚Äôve traveled through KLIA countless times, and it has always impressed me with its cleanliness, smooth check-in process, and efficient security checks. The architecture, inspired by Malaysian, Islamic, and natural elements, remains a stunning highlight. But what truly made KLIA special was its balance of international and uniquely local offerings- something that now seems to be fading.

With the recent KLIA1 renovation, I have to give credit where it‚Äôs due- the new bathrooms are a huge improvement! Well designed, good ventilation, clean and dry. But the retail and dining experience has taken a disappointing turn. Many local options have disappeared, replaced by foreign goods. And once again, alcohol and tobacco seem to dominate the retail space‚Äîwhy so much of it? I was shocked to find just one shelf of Malaysian food products in the entire terminal 1. Malaysia is a food paradise‚Äîwhy isn‚Äôt KLIA celebrating this? Instead, the vibrancy of local flavors is being replaced by the bland sameness of foreign caf√© chains, croissants, and cakes. More AUTHENTIC local options would be a delight!- especially for those leaving home and craving one last nasi lemak or kuey teow or teh tarik or curried roti?

Once, travelers could enjoy authentic Malaysian dishes like kaya toast, prawn noodles, and teh tarik. Now, the F&B scene is overrun by global chains like Starbucks and Gloria Jean‚Äôs. Surely, KLIA can do better by making space for homegrown eateries that showcase Malaysia‚Äôs rich culinary diversity?- take a page out of Jakarta or Singapore airport.

To add to the frustration, the monorail is still out of service (I‚Äôve lost count how long I‚Äôve waited), forcing travelers to rely on slow and inefficient shuttle buses. And when I asked an ‚ÄòAsk Me For Help‚Äô staff member for food recommendations, she barely looked up from her phone. Customer service should be better than this!

KLIA, let‚Äôs do better! Support local businesses and bring back the authentic Malaysian experience to travellers.

P.S. if you‚Äôre ever at the Satellite building of KLIA terminal 1, I highly recommend checking out the Jungle Boardwalk üòÑ I always look forward to visiting it if my Gate is located there. üå¥üå≥üå¥
Terrible. Shuttle bus service didn't come at the time exactly like on the timetable.
There are many counters, but only 1 officer is available (each counter should be 2 workers). How can the queue not pile up, especially during the holiday season :)

The customer service are horrible here. I know you guys don‚Äôt speak English because that‚Äôs not your first English but it‚Äôs so rude the way you guys talked to me. I have seen bad reviews about this airport and Malaysia airline. Wish I didn‚Äôt use Malaysia airline so I didn‚Äôt have to come here to transfer‚Ä¶. I would never come to Malaysia again anyway!

One of the worst airports I've ever been to.
The staff is incredibly nonchalant, more busy checking their phones than helping passengers in difficulty.

We arrived 30 minutes before boarding, but the agent at the counter categorically refused to let us through. He didn't even bother to call the gate to let us know we were there or try to find a solution.
I know you have to arrive 1 hour before check-in and 30 minutes before boarding, but this was truly exceptional.

Background: Our first flight (with Air Asia) was delayed by 1 hour, which left us only 45 minutes to check in for our second flight (with Malaysia Airlines). And in those 45 minutes, we had to: exit immigration, fill out immigration paperwork, take a taxi (because the train between the terminals was closed), go through customs again in the other terminal, and then take another bus to get to the plane, which is impossible to do in 45 minutes.

Changing terminals was a real nightmare: the train connecting the terminals was out of service, so we had to retrace our steps to catch a taxi, which we had to pay for ourselves at a reception desk‚Äîwhere, once again, the staff seemed more engrossed in their phones than in their work.

After the first agent refused, we tried our luck at another check-in kiosk (using a machine); other people were there. We explained the situation, and to get through, we had to lie by saying that "the man at the counter had given us the green light." At that point, we were let through. Immigration and customs literally told us to run!

But when we arrived at the boarding gate, just a minute before departure, they categorically refused to let us board. The staff were there, on their phones, with no desire to help. One woman even pretended to call someone to tell us that "it's over, the doors are closed," before literally turning her back on us.

All this because of a delay by one of their partner airlines, and there was no flexibility, no consideration.

The result: we had to buy new tickets, this time with Emirates. And there, however, nothing to complain about‚Äîtop-notch welcome, professional service.
smelly toilets and again the majority is just plain rude. Hope the country heals.

This is the worst airport ever ! Messy arrangements and loads of useless staffs.
Will never come to Malaysia again.
The worst, very bad management, not enough air conditioning, too many checks, wasting time, the weighing is also bad, weighing one person at a time, making it crowded.

Inconvenience of the aero-train still out of action. The bus connection is not too bad though, not on a very hot day even though the buses have air-cond.
20 May 2025 update!!!
Aerotrain was meant to start in apr 2025 .. still 'no show'.

The organization is good, although there are few travelers. However, it's dirty and somewhat rundown.
The restrooms are okay. Lack of modernity compared to the modernism displayed in downtown Kuala Lumpur.
Needs interior design.
Old airport building, always crowded and not so many chairs provided in the boarding room.
Terrible. So out of date. Seating is l limited and passengers clearance and security area so bad.
The transit train is still not ready. The bus driver who drove between satellite and main terminal are reckless.
Good but big and very tiring to arrange

I gave it one star because I can't give it one... This is the worst airport I've ever flown through, and yet I've flown through quite a few around the world: Singapore, Jakarta, Surabaya, Bangkok; I've never seen such a bad airport. There's no signage, the staff is unfriendly and absolutely unhelpful. The organization is incredibly dismal. And no one does anything to make your life easier, not to mention the distances, which are unreasonable. Nothing in this airport, in fact, is either pleasant or makes your life easier; quite the opposite.
I know of a more expensive ticket, but above all, avoid going through this airport if you have the choice.
This is the third time I've flown through here, and I hope it's the last.
Customs was a bit slow and long queue, the men and women restroom are at either ends of the baggage carousel which is inconvenient when you're travelling with family or your partner
So-so

It's chaotic. There needs to be better guidance on the lineup of passengers waiting to depart to NOT obstruct the pathway for arriving passengers. Simple physical or visual delineation creating separation of the two groups would greatly improve traffic flow.
Also, in the pick up area, passengers shouldn't be allowed to go to the outside lane and obstruct all incoming vehicles. Vehicles blocking the flow should be ticketed or encouraged to continue moving. No stopping in the outside lane
Aggressive bus driver for no reason
The worst marked airport I've ever been to, the signs are misleading, it takes an hour to get out
Price of bottled water is real rip off. 6MYR (600ml) in the airport but 3MYR (350ml) in inflight.

It might be more appropriate to call it Kuala Lumpur Airport rather than 'International.' While the airport is generally clean and well-lit, the transit area is underwhelming. Wi-Fi connectivity is slow, and there are limited food and retail options. A significant upgrade or expansion is needed if the airport aims to keep up with other regional hubs.

Additionally, the transport pick-up experience at Terminal 2 was a nightmare. The poorly designed two-lane pick-up area created severe congestion, and we ended up waiting over an hour just to be picked up. It's unclear who was responsible for this layout, but it clearly needs a serious rethink

Instructions and signs are not clear, I have a premium ticket and we have to ask the staff to find the locket. We wasted 15 minutes looking for the right counter so we don't need to queue in the normal one which is sooooooo long. After dropping baggage, the immigration counter has 26 counters open not that many people but very slow! Slowest immigration I've been too! The coordination is bad. There are 2 queues. The first queue leads to 10 counters! The other queue only 2 counters! And I am in that line we couldn't see when we came because a lot of people, only realized when we're infront. No wonder our line is so slow and the other so fast. The staff should've seen and fixed it! The immigration staff is very slow too. It took 1 minute 30 second for 1 person to go through! In australia it only took 15 seconds! We came 3 hours early to enjoy the lounge. But just from luggage dropping to immigration it took us 1 hour and 30 minutes! My back hurts from standing too long. Please manage the airport better.

the officers were rude and unfriendly. It was my first time in Malaysia and I was very culture shocked by the service provided by the airport officers. When buying a bus ticket, the officer made it difficult for me to pay 62 ringgit while the receipt that came out was 26 ringgit, I was cheated by the officer. The officer was rude and didn't smile

I am writing to provide feedback on my recent experience flying to KLIA via Singapore Airlines.

While I generally appreciate the quality of service on Singapore Airlines flights, I was disappointed with the airport experience at KLIA, especially considering this was not a budget flight.

Although the airport is large and packed with many shops and eateries, there are a few areas that could be improved to facilitate smoother transit for arriving passengers.

- These include having clearer directional signs/ large screen and more readily available information.

Upon arrival, after disembarking from the plane, we were directed by a staff member..standing at the side, to go to Cxx for a transfer to the arrival hall.

- Wouldn't it be better to put up clear large signage at both sides of the walkway while  we disembarked?

- Would also suggest considering adjusting the volume of the announcement speaker with loud and clear information in English, Chinese, and Malay.

The signage for this bus transfer was also unclear, and it took us a while to find the area just to queue for a feeder bus.

Since this airport is named as an international airport, wouldn‚Äôt it be better to have a basic international ‚Äústandard‚Äù too?
Not sure if the timing we arrived is a peak season but that day itself,the no.of passengers is not a joke.
The situation worsened upon arrival at the arrival hall.
The area was extremely crowded, and people are in queue of 2 -3 lines in a row....resulting in a queue of over an hour just to clear immigration.
Very disorganized and messy, no one was there to manage the human traffic, which leads to all these mess.
Good thing is the officer trying their level best to clear the queue.

After clearing immigration, locating the correct baggage belt was another challenge.
The area was so crowded, and there were only three to four luggage belts where you are required to walk near the belt to check on the monitor screen showing which flight these belts are meant for.

The screen flashed so fast with so many people trying to catch a glimpse of the information, which was rather frustrating, especially when there are different groups of people surrounding the area....some was like lost souls looking for directions,  while some gather in between the way waiting for their friends, and you have those looking up and low for the right belt for their luggage.

We only found our luggage outside the luggage belt area, where there was a sign with the SQ Airlines logo on the floor.

There was quite a handful of luggage that was located there, which obviously most of those taking the same flight as us were still stuck in immigration.

Imagine the time taken from the moment we disembark from the plane and just to get out until our luggage was left outside and not at the belt....

This can be rather challenging, especially after coming a long "way" out from immigration üòë

Thought we are only required to transit to the arrival hall as a 1 time off thingy.

Who knows, we must go through the same things even for departure.

On our return flight, we were once again required to take a short bus to the departure hall.

Furthermore, there were no water dispensers available after passing through the inspection gate, which was inconvenient.

We have to endure our thirst till our flight takes off.

As a tourist, the airport gives the 1st impression for passengers and how they are organized.

Hope this feedback will be taken into consideration for future improvements.

It's a big airport with lots of amenities and shopping options. Food is limited to asian food. Very few veggie options. I did not find Indian cuisine anywhere. The security and check in were easy and the airline staff including the other airport staff were helpful. They could make it more intuitive right from the entry gate. The gates are not very well placed. Passengers will face discomfort as early arrivers won't be allowed to sit in the lobby
Arrival traffic...very, very disappointing...

Automatic passport gates are extremely laggy. You have to ride bus numerous times to get anywhere. Everything takes ages. Every single airport in the world has the security check before shops except for this one.

Avoid transfers here at all costs.
Gate directly after security check. Not a single option to buy water/drinks after security.

For some ridiculous reason they only place security for international flights just before the gate (gates C at least). This means you can't bring any water bottles on the flight - not even any that you just bought in the airport! And no chance to refill them post security either. So you have to rely on the plastic mini bottles they provide you during your upcoming 7+ hour flight. Wholly inefficient and wasteful in this day and age. I expected better from a modern hub like KL.

For the rest the main hall and transportation on site is fine.
Ground staff not friendly, service staff not helping much.

Immigration was extremely crowded for the flight arriving at 4pm in May after the end of the coronavirus pandemic.

By November 2011, it was back to normal.

Such a far walk to C5

Note to self: never take AirAsia again

The mini security check is such a cluster frog. Talk about disorder and lack of luggage baskets.
Security takes your liquids before entering the gate and there is no water refill station inside. Very inconvenient for long international flights.
This airport is quite good, but one problem is there are cockroaches in the bathroom, even though they are small, they still make it dirty.

One of the worst airports ever to exist.  Domestic terminal 2- delays, leading to long waits with a lack of facilities. Two rubbish places to eat which are dirty, smell, miserable staff.  More prayer rooms than toilets !
No normal water facility and forex inside departure gates
I've never seen a place where migration is so slow.

Getting out into the city after landing is quite a quest. I would never have thought that I would need to take a bus to another terminal to go through passport control and customs. The signs are extremely crooked üòÖ

Anyway, when I left, it was like I was in a different airport. A train running between the terminals (apparently at certain hours), everything is clean, tidy, the staff is helpful.

Mixed impressions‚Ä¶.

While leaving Kuala Lumpur Airport in Malaysia, the fearsome robber called the Malaysian police and checked my passport, checked me, took my $1200 and 5500 ringgit, said he would take me to the office, and took me to a ladder. When I asked for my ringgit back, he hit me, kept 900 ringgit and returned all the ringgit and dollars. I am in a panic and a terrible situation. I have been to three or four countries before, this does not happen. What kind of danger did I get into when I came here for three days?
airport is fine and everything works smoothly but there are too many announcements. very annoying and over stimulating
SYSTEM DOWN .. COLLAPES ALREADY ..

Disgusting airport, not only is the gate system not thought out and when you change gates you have to re-check in, it's a 20 minute run. There are no announcements. All the water you buy after the test you end up throwing away. The staff goons are not helpful at all. Half of the signs are not clear and it is easy to get lost. And yes, teach the airport staff to do alerts in English properly. It's just mockery. 5 alerts and not a word is understood at all. Too bad I can't give 0 stars

When I arrived at the airport and checked in, I thought it would be easy to get out of Kuala Lumpur. So I bought two bottles of water for 3,000 won each at a cafe~
Before boarding the plane, they thoroughly inspected the water again and I had to throw it away „Ö†„Ö†
There's no place to use cash~ There's no bathroom in the departure hall. This is my first time in a place like this.

Exhausting.. you need to have at least a year of airport work experience to just transit through this airport. It took nearly 2 hrs from landing to sitting down at our gate. So much is automated, and very few staff members to help, so when something goes wrong - like when the self bag-drop off machine stops working.. with one of our bags halfway through the conveyor, we were left for ages, not knowing what to do. So many more hurdles to jump such as filling in an MDAC, yes, we were asked to fill it in on-line at Siem Reap, but thought it couldn't possibly be for us as so many 'mandatory' boxes were irrelevant to us. However, at the airport, they insisted we filled it in with a bunch of false information, i.e. the address where we would be staying (had to put in an address that they provided.. which was the airport's address) a waste of time, as we felt we could miss our connecting flight. We also had to create our own baggage tags, then TWO separate baggage screenings - so unnecessary. There are so many options of queues without clear instructions, so many people, so much walking - it just seemed chaotic. It's not my favourite airport. If we weren't so tired.. we had been travelling all day, I would have said a pretty average airport.
My tung tung tung sahur was not happy that I have to wait 2 hours more

The organization is good, in departure mode, although there are few travelers. However, it's dirty and somewhat rundown.
The restrooms are okay. Lack of modernity compared to the modernism displayed in downtown Kuala Lumpur.
Needs interior design.
I didn't expect it to be like Singapore airport, but better nonetheless.

In arrival mode, it's indeed confusing ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è where's the luggage??? And if you're arriving from a two-hour flight and have a jet lag, it's very complicated.
Nothing or very little is written.

The taxis are all waiting to take you and charge you ‚Ç¨30 to get to the center; I'm surprised they pay that much.
In fact, I paid ‚Ç¨17 to get there via booking, and it was perfect üëç
Immigration officers are so rude and unkind without any reasons.

I fly international quite a bit. KL airport is one of the few that I've flown out of that does not permit you to fill up a bottle of water at a water dispenser in the airport and bring it on the airplane. This appears to be a rule just for international departures, because when I flew domestic out of KL I could fill up a bottle of water and board with it. Also, the security staff working at Gate C33, where I boarded, were a bit rude.

Extremely long waiting time at passport control!
For EU citizens there are automatic controls, but because of our stroller, we can't use them. Because of the stroller we were also told, we're not allowed to use the priority lane, despite one of our young kids being under 2 (which would be the requirement, according to the sign).
Only a handful of open counters (plenty more would be available, but aren't being serviced) are serving several long lines of waiting passengers.
It's been over 45 minutes for just over half the length of our line. Great fun with little kids...

First and Last Time!

It's my first time in Malaysia, traveling from Abu Dhabi. As a UAE resident, I take pride in the excellent regulations we have. However, I had a very disappointing experience at Kuala Lumpur Airport with a police officer named Azhar, who was checking baggage. He removed several of our items, including our shower gel, face wash, moisturizer, perfume, mouthwasher (almost finished the bottle)and even drinking water as well. My wife and I have never encountered such treatment at any airport before, and we were shocked to learn that these items are considered "non-carryable" on flights, the things cost more than 500 AED, very disappointed, and will never come again worst experience ever.

What an absolute useless airport, no buses to get to KL, only terminal shuttles. Also why in the world would you price the train to KL more than the price of a grab? Who runs this place? Btw, get rid of the Starbucks üáµüá∏

over years klia I & klia II has been quite the smooth transportation for flyers both domestic and international. unfortunately there also were some unpleasant experiences many flyers had encountered or witnessed. personally often noticed such unpleasant incidences happening, for example, 2 ineffectively handling at heavily heaving airline check-in counters ( a python long queue today),  on-going passengers at transit train between terminals ( in the mean time the sky train rosak that airport authorities addressed the issue with buses yet effective though), at the immigration (remember seeing poor innocent south asians were shouted to and treated with discriminative manners, rude and loudly likely a racial verbal abuse. it was a moment of unbearable injustice towards humanity), at baggage claim, at security checks or even at Whsmiths, ffs. today it was still leaving flyers compromising authorities were seemed proactively dealing with situation. Only One part still looking ugly and disgusting, most are from the people who occupied there, is the pick-up and drop-off area in front of arrival and departure terminal. what a marked down.

The customs officers were very serious and had a very bad tone! The immigration process was very, very slow... The signs for the shuttle bus after getting off the plane were unclear! Not a good impression of this airport!

The worst airport ever! The number immigration office officers are not enough to serve the passengers. So many passengers need to rebuy the tickets because they missed their flights!!! The immigration is so slowwwwwwwwww

This is the worst airport I have ever traveled (Had flight in March'25 from KL T1). Every eatery was closed at just 9pm, why? Security lady before boarding the flight was so so rude; screams at seniors, kids and everyone there for no reason. Definitely needs 'how to be kind' sessions! Made everybody throw their water before boarding the flight, where do we get water now?? Just opened all bags and ran her hands across everything for no reason. What was the point of going through passport control, security check if they just want to torture us before boarding the flight. Pathetic airport and their staff!!!
I actually remember the airport as being great. But it's not that way anymore. There's only one drinking water machine at the C Gates. And it's broken. The paths and signage have also gotten worse.
Pretty run down and be prepared to walk long distances as its train services have been down for many years now.

this is a beautifully designed airport with some not-so-beautiful features that mostly have nothing to do with it like people breaching no smoking pick up/drop off area rules :/ but i do have issue with the aerotrain only working once every 10 years

klia2 is okay i guess (so much better than perth take notes)

My recent experience at Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) was unfortunately extremely disappointing.

Firstly, the staff were generally unfriendly and appeared to have minimal understanding of English, which made basic communication difficult to impossible.
More critically, there was a noticeable general incompetence across various functions. Staff seemed unable or unwilling to perform their duties, such as overseeing passengers and maintaining order in the queues. An additional major point of inefficiency was the self-service process: I was directed to the scanner by immigration staff, only for the scanner to then instruct me to return to the immigration counter, causing further unnecessary delays and frustration.
I repeatedly observed an absolute lack of professional supervision, where people were simply allowed to cut in line or where queues dissolved into chaos without any staff intervention.
This combination of poor (and by times even disrespectful) customer service, language barriers, and failure to enforce basic operational procedures led to unnecessary stress and delays. It's clear that KLIA urgently needs to invest in significantly better training for its personnel, focusing on customer service, language proficiency, and core job efficiency.

If I could give 0 stars, I would!

Such a far walk to C5

Note to self: never take AirAsia again
Worst immigration que
Should‚Äôve implemented hand bidet in every toilet. No need to desperately trying to win the westerners by diminishing it. Promote our own culture, not fall into their style
Good facilities but the food really needs some improvement, very poor and bland vegetarian options.
Terrible queues at immigration counters. For international departure gates make sure to arrive at least 3-4 hours ahead of flight.
Aerotrain took years to maintain. MAHB why so slow?? To go to Terminal C, have to take bus from the MTB.
There is order in the chaos. Although it is not very new, it is generally okay. Only the location of the toilet is a bit inhumane.

Poorest airport of world; doesn't have anything and amenities. Not proper lounge.
They have lounge outside security checkü§¶, then they don't have any charging point at any location. They made one or two location but only two person can put two things on charge. After the security check there's one more security check on gates starts. Seating area opens only around 1 hour before the boarding, before than They keep close; They made trolley but it's not allowed in escalators. Washroom located in east and west and north and south so far with 4-5 person(max to max) can use.

I recently traveled to Malaysia with my family, including young children, and was extremely disappointed by the poor management at the airport upon our arrival.

After our plane landed, we had to wait for two full hours just to get through immigration. The lines were incredibly long, and there were no clear directions, very few staff members to assist, and an overall lack of organization in managing the arriving passengers. My children and elderly family members were forced to stand the entire time, which was both exhausting and unacceptable after a long flight.

I expected better from a major international airport. There was no prioritization for families with children, no proper communication, and very little effort to speed up the process. It felt like the airport was completely unprepared to handle the volume of passengers arriving.

My advice to the airport management: Please improve the arrival process by increasing staff at immigration counters, organizing separate queues for families, and providing clearer signage and communication. Travelers come to Malaysia expecting hospitality and efficiency ‚Äî unfortunately, this experience was neither welcoming nor efficient.

I hope my feedback will be taken seriously to ensure a better experience for future visitors.

While leaving Kuala Lumpur Airport in Malaysia, the scary robber called the Malaysian police and checked my passport, searched me, took my $1200 and 5500 ringgit, said he would take me to the office, and took me to the stairs. When I asked for my ringgit back, he beat me, kept 900 ringgit and returned all the ringgit and dollars. I was in a panic and a terrible state. I have been to three or four countries before, this has not happened. What kind of danger did I experience when I came here for three days?

The nation's pride and joy needs to be updated. It is looking really dated and tired compared to other international airports. There is very limited vibrance as compared to the rest.

Aerotrain is still out of order. Taking busses to the satellite building is like aged old way of moving in the airport. First and business class passengers have a separate bus which has larger and lesser seats. However, the exhaust is still an issue. Only MAS passengers get the i5 via the same place. Service however is good. The bus is at the G gates and there is a personnel who chaperones passenger to the busses. There are also coffee machines and comfy sofas at the bus area. Don't quite understand rationale for this as who ever that is already there will very likely want to get to the satellite building lounges quickly. Hence, no one can be seen there save and except for staff.

The local flight delayed by 3 hours and as compensation they provided meal, that too non veg. What about international traveller's who are pure vegeterian, nothing. Once you reach the gates there are no proper food options and then you keep everyone waiting for 3 hours. On top of that there was a gate change too and additional inconvenience.

Beautiful airport but everything is far apart and directional signage is not clear. I accidentally left my small bag at one of the many security checks (3 security checks with Xrays after arrival?? Why??) and the security guard meters away was not helpful at all. Sarcastic immigration officer. I will avoid using this airport again.
There should be 0.1 stars to press.

The airport is quite large and has all kinds of shops, but it's very far from the city. It takes between one and two hours to get there, depending on traffic. The signs also leave something to be desired.

The slowest passport control ever. Waited in a long queue to reach the desks only to be told to go out and register online. What's so unacceptable is the questions are basic form to fill that could have been registered in the desk with additional unnecessary info. Then you stand again in line for the passport control. Everyone seemed lost and there was no help at all from airport personnel, I wonder how terrible this is for old people or those who can't connect to the internet. Not the best start for tourism in Malaysia, let alone the additional charges added by the government for tourism.

Inconvenient airport:
1. there are no normal places to rest in the hall before going through passport control,
2. there is only one place where you can drink water for free (or rather, I found only one) and this water machine still needs to be found, there are no signs for it.
3. Incomprehensible navigation.

I must say is chaos, I was queuing at the counter and you see passengers jumping queue with the blessings of air Asia staff because she say their flight is going to depart. The best part the four passengers take up so much time and arguing with the check in staff that I don't think they are in a hurry. There is another four European passengers behind me keep jumping and cursing at the queue jumper. They scold the air Asia staff that that is the worst airport that they fly and the staff told him thank you. That make things worse and he got more annoyed. I am wordless.
Flying from Singapore to KL, the difference cannot be more stark. The KL airport experience consists of long walks, a bus ride to the main terminal, and an immigration line that takes forever.

One of the worst airports I have ever been to, extremely slow. We were told to wait for transit check in at 2am, 40 minutes later and everyone is still waiting in line. Why do we even have to stop here of all countries

Came here on the terminal 2, which is used only by air asia. The building and facility is great, no complaint about that. It is clean, bright and spacious. However, it seems that the staff are not quick enough or they are short staffed. Queuing line becomes very-very long, check in can be done with automated machine, however many of the passengers are confused and cannot do it properly. Imigrations are done manually, no automated gate for foreigners.

Water dispenser also almost all-empty, while walking to my gate, i came across about 4-5 water dispenser, and wished to refill my bottle, however all of it were empty.

Bad service,so this is how it goes,we were told to go to terminal 14,and after workers came,they started to tell us to re-cue again and started shouting loudly to us  bad service would never come again
Good, but the Identity checkers are not very friendly

More than 2 hrs waitung on Immigration.

I want to give zero star to this airport. My brother and his friends wanted to visit Malaysia. He booked a trip for 4 days with his friends. They had confirmed ticket for a round trip. The custom held their passports and are holding them at the airport and not giving them an entry. It‚Äôs been 2 days and they have been sitting at the airport. Very sad, like to let klia managmen know that, klia toilet is stinks. The foreign worker really can't perform the work. Needs interior design.
I didn't expect it to be like Singapore airport, but better nonetheless.

In arrival mode, it's indeed confusing ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è where's the luggage??? And if you're arriving from a two-hour flight and have a jet lag, it's very complicated.

Not opening the inner lane causes traffic congestion

The interior is dated, the traffic flow is complex, the staff are inconsiderate, the restrooms are filthy, the interior decor is dated, and the lighting is dim.

It's hard to imagine how a country like Malaysia could have such a poor and disgusting airport.

While walking through the airport, the shuttle bus honked several times, which was extremely unpleasant. If you're traveling with young children, they'll definitely be frightened and cry.

Rude staff during the security check. The airport should properly train courtesy to the security staff before scolding people. Worst experience for an international airport ever. Will avoid this airport again in the future.

The worst airport I've ever had. We were flying out of gate L and it was a nightmare. The air conditioning in the entire wing is practically non-functional - it's so hot, people aren't allowed into the waiting rooms at the gates behind the glass, they're empty. Everyone ends up sitting in the hallway and even on the floor because there aren't enough seats. You have to stand in line for half an hour to get to the women's restroom, and you end up in a stall with a hole in the floor and all covered in water. It's very surprising that such a progressive city has such a disgusting airport.
Friendly but there are a few toilets and water refills and some water refills are brokenüíî

I don't know if T1 is better, but flew off from T2 and the system really needs more work and thinking through.

Starting from the immigration gates, we were all directed to use the e-gates. There were Chinese tourists who were stuck, and they couldn't understand the error message that was in English. But there was not a single staff present? How can such gates be left unattended?
All other tourists behind were left stranded.

After the e-gates, our bags were scanned. So we emptied out all our water.

In the departure hall we spotted water coolers so we refilled our bottles.

As we were walking to the gate, there was suddenly another security screening?? And so we had to empty our bottles again??

Guess what, the water coolers at the boarding gate were not working.

Passengers at T2 are on budget flights with no beverages. We needed the water.

Also, the whole airport smelt of vomit and pee.

I don't think KLIA is anywhere near calling themselves an internationally recognized airport. Not by a long shot. If someone from KLIA is reading this, please take this feedback seriously to improve your airport.

Der langsamsten verplanteste Flughafen, wo wir jemals waren.
Legen jemals ihre Regeln anders aus.
Du kaufst Getr√§nke und musst sie dann am Gate wegsch√ºtten, genauso eine Kinderschere wegschmei√üen die davor durch 7 Fl√ºge auf dieser Reise ok war.
Das Personal war auch extrem unfreundlich vor allem bei der Immigration und dem Security Check. Leider das komplette Gegenteil zu Singapur.

It's still a great airport that meet the customers demand, but there are some run down facility and hardware, such as aged carpet with visible discoloration at the arrival hall, and some run down toilets with dim lamps.

However the immigration section has been improved to cater the huge crowd of tourists. That's a good thing. Nevertheless, the custom checkpoint no longer provide the green zone for people with light luggages to walk thru. Everyone has to queue up to pass thru the custom checkpoint, where the officers will randomly pick any large luggage to scan for taxable items. So, be prepared for that.

By the way, the departure hall do not have any water dispenser for you to refill your water bottle. You have to buy water with a sealed plastic bag (the bag is not free), in order to take it into the waiting hall. This is allowed by security check at the waiting hall.

The new aerotrain ride between the satellite building and main building was good. Albeit it is a new train, there were a few events of disruption due to technical glitch (via news portals), so be prepared to take the buses again.

Check-in takes ages, every passenger seems to be a problem. To get to the C4 gate, you need to take a bus (and you must hurry, because check-in takes ages), and then right before the gate there is a security check. If you have water in a reusable bottle, you have to go to the bathroom to pour it out. And it‚Äôs actually a good idea to go to the bathroom before the security check, because after you‚Äôre in the gate waiting area, there is no bathroom.
Worst experience ever.
Worst Airport.. No Basic Facilities like Drinking water filter üòï.. We Have to Take Water by Paying Huge Amt..
I was sitting at the corner waiting for my flight. The cleaner just push the cleaning cart towards me until almost hit me then he walked away.

Airport staff are really the worst here. All eligible countries that are allowed to use the e-gate were forced to use the immigration line, but there are very few staff at the immigration line to manage it. On top of that, when going to the nearest immigration counter the staff was rude and said "this one is only for business class" even though the line was empty. So you ultimately have counters that are over capacity cause they have implemented a e-gate system that doesn't work and a set of counters that have staff and no users cause they don't have the right "boarding pass". Airport itself is okay, but the operations are a disgrace to such a beautiful city. KLIA Do better. For anyone flying through, ensure you take extra time in case the airport is busy and systems are not working as expected.
so god damn disorganised
Terrible management

Had one of the worst experiences at KLIA . There are absolutely no restaurants while waiting for your flight. Also, the security check people have some weird rule of not carrying liquids more than 100 ml/gm as cabin baggage. Half the things which they sell in the lounge  are more than 250 gm/ml. Very badly run airport.

Feels average for an International airport. Certain areas looked run down, like the Eraman shops on the way to the gates, the baggage inspection section before the gates. The lighting at most area are quite dim, some not working ,and flooring looks bad ( chipping , and many reworked areas). On the good side, the staff is effecient with the large crowds.
The immigration customs was extremely slow, which proved that we had indeed arrived in a Southeast Asian country.

I flew Malaysian airlines, changing from the Malaysian Airlines international terminal to the domestic terminal and it took me 30 mins to get from one to the other because of a bus ride and customs.  On the way back, it took me 45 mins.

The whole experience was pretty stressful and I'd never want to do it with children in tow.

I've flown through other airports with tighter connections and the organisation of the arrival to departure gates was better considered and not nearly as stressful.

I love Malaysia, but the experience with the immigration department at KLIA1 was very disappointing. The staff were unnecessarily rude both on arrival and departure. It left a bad impression and needs urgent improvement. Malaysia is a beautiful country, and I sincerely hope this can be addressed to make the entry and exit experience more welcoming.
I am so surprised so many people queing for imigration. I have been queing for 1.5 hours. I think they have to add more staffs.
Crowded and waiting for more than an hour to get your passport stamped. The staff's behavior and mannerisms √ó
Disrespectful officers at TSA. The worst airport in the world! No proper restaurants

The worst experience ever.
So it is not possible to understand where to go, you need to stand in lines and ask when your flight might leave without you.

The worst transfer ever, is it so difficult to write signs ? Is it so expensive to let people know where they are?

The entry aisle is very long, the Chinese service is insufficient, and the service attitude of the staff is very good. The food in the departure hall has a low CP value, plus taxes and service fees. I bought duty-free cigarettes but felt the quality was not good.
Imegration very slow

Very bad service, organization and slow procedure, we had to wait 5 hours to get out of the airport because of the very long unlimited infinity line while doing the passports check even though we already had the visa application ready to go.
Please repair the Aerotrain a.s.a.p. The shuttles do not represent the Airport as a reputable International Airport. ‚òπÔ∏è

Everywhere long waiting times, including two separate security checks one at the gate, train ride, making it very stressful. Not well managed. Very few toilets. Even though I came very early I barely made the door and had to drop all liquids as the security check is done at the door and there is nowhere to poor the water, you have to walk back to far away toilet. Not a good experience in general

On June 16th, around 4pm: when I first landed on imagination gate, the passport checkers seemed don't know what to do their job. They asked us to go to this or that officer to check the passports. Like.... ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èwho do you want me to get my passport checked? They look unprofessional more like playful. Work on that!!!!

Oh, one more thing, I did say thank you wth a smiley face üòä after they handed me the passport but they be like üóø

Had a very unpleasant experience. The staff insisted I pour out my liquids in the toilet, even though the sign clearly stated to dispose of them in front of the scanner. Additionally, there was no water dispenser available in the waiting area.

Certainly this bin is for illustration purpose only.

Extremely rude and unprofessional immigration staff with a terrible attitude.
This is many tourists first impression and first point of contact with the people of the country they‚Äôre entering, and it is not ideal to be treated in such a manner here.
Make sure you have all your documents in line is all I can say, and if you‚Äôre traveling together be prepared to be yelled at to go to separate desks each.
What is the point of the mandatory digital arrival card when they ask you every single question 20 times again and ask for proof?
Had a great time in Malaysia otherwise but this certainly ruined our first impressions. Makes you less likely to visit again having to deal with this

On a side note - Beware of the scammy airport workers by bag claims from who I literally had to pull my own luggage away from because he wanted to scam me by 'helping' and undoubtedly asking for payment at the end. How the hell does management allow such people to work at the airport?
Painful experience using the computers to do a pre authorisation for entry! No people around to help you and you have to do it unless you did it already before you arrived!!

Such a beautiful country let down by such slow immigration, both arriving and departing. Each time the desks were only half staffed.

When leaving KL I'd suggest you arrive at airport at least 3hrs+ before leaving. The queue to get through immigration took over an hour!

Be warned! Water is removed from you at the departure gate!!! Not at immigration like all airports I have previously been at. So make sure you're well hydrated before your flight ‚úàÔ∏è

Check in process at klia for Malaysia Airlines is so slow. Long queue and yet only 2 counters open. It's crazy. You can miss your flight because they don't even announce that they are closing. Avoid MAS.

Super long Immigration lines with about 400 people in total and yet the immigration officers just log off, close the gate and go away for an hour randomly leaving only 2 officers to complete immigration.

No regard for fasting Muslims standing in excruciating lines with 10 kg weights on their backs while Muslim immigration officers take frequent breaks.

Shame on Malaysian government for allowing this behaviour.

Ridiculous security arrangements at the airport. When going through departure security it is a meaningless scan, with no checks on person or water etc. this means that if you buy any liquids in the duty free section, you cannot take them on the plane without a label - which is not offered in the shops automatically. This means that you have to leave any liquids you just bought. Ridiculous. Bags must be offered straight away.

Terminal 1 of KLIA is very disappointing. Being a rapidly growing global destination Kuala Lumpur deserves a far better airport. kLIA T1 lacks the glitter and glamour flaunted by other major airports. The immigration and baggage claim areas lacked room and felt claustrophobic, especially considering the volume of passengers handled by the airport. Neither the airport has any attention grabbing design language to it

Navigating within the airport was a bit tricky at the outset. Taxi pickup points are easy to identify and communicate

Overall the experience was just average. Again, KL deserves a far better airport
Very inefficient baggage handling. Received luggages only 1.5 hours after landing. Terrible quality of service compared to other international airports

The worst airport ever. Got hours early for flight check-in with an insane long queue. Then the immigration queue which is so ridiculously long with only few counters available. Finally the customs check queue. Total of 3+hours of waiting in those long queues. Noticed some people missed their flights and staffs not helping to give an express queue for those near-miss flights. I have seen lots of queues in other airports but not as slow as this.
Longest immigration process ever. Be prepared to wait over an hour since they only have one operator per line and their signage is not straight forward.

Worst airport in the whole world. Before boarding the flight you are forced to bin your water and there's no way to refill it. You'll have to rely on the airplane to provide you water throughout the flight. Why can't they hire smarter people to manage this place? The train has been out of order for years. Don't deserve any salary.

Worst airport I‚Äôve ever been at. When I landed I stood in line for 1,5 hours at immigration!! Landed in terminal 2 and my next flight was from terminal 1, the shuttle bus took 20-30 minutes. After I checked in for my next line I had to stand another hour  to get thru immigration??? I almost missed my flight, my layover was 3,5-4 hours and I still had to run to the plane when it was boarding!! People working at the airport are not helpful. Very ineffective airport!!
They need to get more people at work.

The Airport is Messy, Broken Plugs and Food Court, Burger king there was saviour. also no perfect signs for bus turminals/or transport. But the bathrooms were clean in main waiting area and departure but not in Food court. Need lot of Improvements.

There is a second security at ALL the gates and so you can't take water on board. Batik airlines forces you to buy water on the plane. This is a violation of human rights.

The airport is really loud in general and experienced sensory overload.

There is a lack of toilets so the queues are extremely long.

I will give an extra star because the shops and food choice are good.
Very crowded,Direction is unconvenient,

We recently traveled from Malaysia to Cochin via KLIA with AirAsia, and unfortunately, the experience with the ground staff was very disappointing. We wanted to check in our baggage directly at the counter instead of using the kiosk, and when we asked the staff about it, their response was rude and unhelpful. They just told us to either use the kiosk or pay cash and try another counter, with no intention to assist further.

At the ‚ÄúV‚Äù counter, a staff member initially told us to join the queue. But when we reached the front, the person issuing boarding passes and bag tags questioned how we got there and rudely told us to go back. Even when we explained that another AirAsia staff member had asked us to wait in line, she denied it outright, saying no one from their team would do that.

There was a serious lack of coordination, professionalism, and courtesy from the ground staff. It left a very bad impression on us. AirAsia should really consider training their ground staff better, especially when handling international travelers who expect basic respect and guidance.
The equipment is okay, but it is complicated to check the locks when entering and closing the phone, especially when entering the waiting room, and there is even no bathroom.

The luggage won‚Äôt pecah if drop or what? Then that abang answeredÔºö‚Äùif pecah then pecah lah‚Äù

KLIA1 Renovation: A Step Forward, But Where‚Äôs the Local Charm?

I‚Äôve traveled through KLIA countless times over the years, and it has always impressed me with its cleanliness, smooth check-in process, and efficient security checks. The architecture, inspired by Malaysian, Islamic, and natural elements, remains a stunning highlight. But what truly made KLIA special was its balance of international and uniquely local offerings- something that now seems to be fading.

With the recent KLIA1 renovation, I have to give credit where it‚Äôs due‚Äîthe new bathrooms are a huge improvement! Well-designed, clean, and dry. But the retail and dining experience has taken a disappointing turn. Many local options have disappeared, replaced by foreign goods. And once again, alcohol and tobacco seem to dominate the retail space‚Äîwhy so much of it? I was shocked to find just one shelf of Malaysian food products in the entire terminal 1. Malaysia is a food paradise‚Äîwhy isn‚Äôt KLIA celebrating this? Instead, the vibrancy of local flavors is being replaced by the bland sameness of foreign caf√© chains, croissants, and cakes. More AUTHENTIC local options would be a delight!- especially for those leaving home and craving one last nasi lemak or kuey teow or teh tarik or curried roti?

Once, travelers could enjoy authentic Malaysian dishes like kaya toast, prawn noodles, and teh tarik. Now, the F&B scene is overrun by global chains like Starbucks and Gloria Jean‚Äôs. Surely, KLIA can do better by making space for homegrown eateries that showcase Malaysia‚Äôs rich culinary diversity?

To add to the frustration, the monorail is still out of service (I‚Äôve lost count how long I‚Äôve waited), forcing travelers to rely on slow and inefficient shuttle buses. And when I asked an ‚ÄòAsk Me For Help‚Äô staff member for food recommendations, she barely looked up from her phone. Customer service should be better than this!

KLIA, let‚Äôs do better! Support local businesses and bring back the authentic Malaysian experience to travellers.

No proper place of disposal of water (there was a bin before the scanner but was scolded by the officer for disposing water in the ‚ÄúLiquid and Gel‚Äù bin ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è)

One of the worst airports I have ever been to. I had a flight on 24th August, 2025 from KUL to Chennai at 9.30PM. I went to the airport by 5PM and completed my check-in by 5.30PM. I then went to immigration and it took hours and hours to complete the immigration. There were 3 queues and only 2 officers per queue working at their own pace. The line kept on getting bigger and bigger as the time passed, but still the immigration officers didn‚Äôt show any responsibility in helping us fast track the process. I was literally waiting for more than 4 hours in line and even after requesting them multiple times about my flight timings they simply told ‚ÄúThis is how it is and if you are late you will miss the flight.‚Äù

It‚Äôs really a very poor management by Malaysian airport and I feel it‚Äôs something really serious which they need to address. If the queue is high, please manage it in such a way to add more officers in duty to avoid the commotion.

The airport is modern, spacious, and generally well-run. However, there were a few moments of confusion worth mentioning.

Upon arrival, the immigration process was not clearly marked. Passengers with Malaysian passports go through a different gate than those with foreign passports, but the signage didn‚Äôt make that obvious. Additionally, all international visitors must fill out a digital arrival form about their stay. There were enough computers available to do this at the airport, but the form isn‚Äôt very intuitive, and it requires knowing the exact address of your accommodation. It could definitely be made more user-friendly.

The departure experience was  quick, smooth, and without queues. However, just before boarding the plane, there was a second bag check, and surprisingly, you couldn‚Äôt bring any drinks on board ‚Äî not even those in your own bottles or purchased in the terminal. Only drinks sealed in security bags by the shop were allowed, and not all stores offer this option. Unfortunately, no one informed
us of this at the time of purchase, which was frustrating and once again showed a lack of clear communication.

This airport is quite impressive, but the distance to the next gate is really far, and I ended up pretty tired from walking. The international departure lounge is really small, disorganized, and lacks proper management.

The toilet maintenance is poor, and the cleanliness is not well-kept. Also, there are very few seats in the corridor before entering the waiting area, so a lot of people have to sit on the floor, almost like a refugee camp.

There are very few water dispensers and phone charging stations, and people have to wait in line just to charge their phones.

The immigration staff is unfriendly and treats passengers rudely. Overall, it was a pretty disappointing experience at this airport.

I don't know if it's under the responsibility of AirAsia or the airport management, but I traveled in a lot of countries (poor or not), and I never seen such poor airport management. 1. They let people outside the boarding room, with no seats, until 1h before plane take off. There was mother with kids sitting on the ground. My plane only open the waiting seats 40 minutes before the departure. Not a single country airport I've been (59 countries so far) do that. And when I tried to suggest politely to the worker there to tell her manager to improve the system, so old people and pregnant women can get the seat in advance, the security guy came to ask what was my passport (as a sign of threat - yet smoothly)
2. The positions of the seat are ridiculous (check picture), with no space for the legs at all.
3. There is 2 security check before boarding (better than Egypt on that point)

I won't describe here the mess between delayed plane and change of gate (see screenshot) that would be way too long. I will also not describe the fact that I queued 3 times to be able to print my boarding pass with AirAsia(print your boarding pass before coming and avoid human interaction at all cost)

My second trip through Kuala Lumpur International Airport was unfortunately just as frustrating as the first.

The customer service here is a huge problem. I asked multiple staff members for help with basic info, and every single one just shrugged, said "I don't know" and acted like it wasn't their job. There was zero effort to even try and find out. It's truly baffling.

Then there's the internal airport bus with no proper monitoring. We had our 5-month-old with us and we literally had to stand for a 5-minute ride between gates. The bus wasn't even packed but everyone was too busy hogging their spot to offer one up to someone struggling with a baby. The fear of losing balance and dropping our infant was terrifying. People just sat there watching us, completely uncaring.

To top it off, we saw a couple of electric buggies nearby, clearly for passenger assistance, but there was no one to drive them! We asked four different staff if they could help us get one, and each time, we got the same clueless "I don't know" response.

For an international airport, the lack of basic help and common courtesy is really poor. Traveling with a baby is already tough enough, and KLIA just made it worse. I'll definitely be trying to avoid this airport next time.

I've been in hundreds of airports, and I'm sorry to say, this is the most disorganised, poorly signed and stress-inducing airport I've been in outside of Africa. Malaysia is a wonderful country that I've visited before; it deserves a much better and more traveller-focussed airport.

Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) is huge, so be prepared for long walks between terminals and sometimes even bus rides to reach your connecting gate. If you have a connecting flight, plan extra time and check in advance which terminal you're flying from KLIA1 and KLIA2 are far apart.

Make sure to exchange currency in advance if you need to buy anything; US dollars might work at some counters, but it's better to have Malaysian Ringgit. The waiting areas are basic, mostly just chairs no proper couches if you‚Äôre trying to relax during a layover.

Overall, the airport is well-organized, but you need to be alert and prepared especially for tight connections.

I was assaulted by a female airport customer experience officer who attempted to physically restrain me without justification. Despite my repeated requests, the airport police refused to take my report and instead escorted me to the immigration department.

There, I was met by an aggressive and unprofessional immigration officer named Kamarudin. When I asked for his full name in writing, he refused and rudely pointed to his name badge, telling me to take a photo with my phone. The moment I did, he became enraged and began intimidating me‚Äîeven going so far as to take photos of me and my passport on his personal phone. This was a blatant violation of privacy and professional conduct.

**Malaysia‚Äôs airport authorities and immigration officers behaved in a disgusting, abusive, and unaccountable manner. Travelers beware: AVOID MALAYSIA at all costs!**

My recent experience at Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) was nothing short of frustrating.

The immigration officers are rude and disrespectful, making an already stressful experience far worse. To be honest, it felt like the staff were completely uninterested in their job, and some even seemed to resent being there.

In Malaysia, government jobs, including those at airports prioritize ethnic Malays over Indian and Chinese Malays. As a result, some government positions, such as immigration officers or airport staff, may be filled based on ethnicity rather than merit or qualifications. Due to this, individuals in these roles might lack the necessary qualifications or passion for the job, which can sometimes be reflected in their job performance and attitude.

What really stood out was the slogan displayed upon arrival: ‚ÄúWe hope you‚Äôve enjoyed our Malaysian Hospitality.‚Äù Frankly, this felt more like an empty promise than a reflection of the experience I had. A service should speak for itself, but in this case, it was clear that overcompensating with slogans only highlights the gap between what is advertised and what is actually delivered.

Given this experience, I will never fly with Malaysian Airlines or visit Malaysia again and I certainly won't be encouraging my friends or family to visit. Avoid countries that do not respect and appreciate tourist coming to help their economy!

I love Malaysia and have visited many times, but KLIA is honestly one of the worst airport experiences I‚Äôve ever had.

We arrived as a family with kids (8 months, 3, 7, and 9 years old). The ‚Äúfamily/elderly‚Äù lane was a joke ‚Äî the officer let some families with older kids go through, but told us only our 1 years baby can enter with his mother and the rest should go another Lane. When I asked why, he completely ignored me. It felt discriminatory and unprofessional.

Immigration was a nightmare: 75 minutes in line just for slow biometric checks, while our luggage was left unattended off the belt. On the return back home, an immigration officer told us our family was ‚Äútoo big‚Äù and refused to process all six passports, forcing us to split up. To make things worse: Batik Air check-in staff were rude and lied about baggage weight, and duty-free prices were ridiculously overpriced (almost 3x more than outside).

They can eat before that... Because there are more choices.

Unfortunately, my experience at Kuala Lumpur International Airport was disappointing. Here are a few points that struck me negatively:
1. Strict baggage control, but not consistent:
My hand luggage was accurately weighed, and even though it was only slightly over 6kg, I was told to pay extra. At the same time, the Malaysian woman in front of me, weighing almost 8 kg, was allowed to walk away - that felt unfair.
2. Poor Signage:
Some gates had no numbers, which was extremely confusing. It was difficult to find the right path.
3. Lack of seating:
There were no seats at the gate, which made the wait unnecessarily tiring.
4. Inadequate Toilets:
The women's restrooms were a mess - I waited in line for over 30 minutes and when it was finally my turn, they were dirty. The men apparently had enough toilets as there were no queues.

Unfortunately, the airport was the worst I've ever been to.
We transited at KL International Airport on our flight from Hong Kong to Jakarta, but we couldn‚Äôt find any single food court or restaurant. There was only one small caf√©.
Just to much fuss when in transit don't get all the need for needing a app for this bit confusing in where to go staff not much help too.

Horrible, just horrible!! The worst experience in my life, and I've been to many airports.
Automation of everything is disgusting!
Figure out for yourself why you can't go through the passport to go out into the city.
Figure out for yourself the form to fill out. (Like a visa on arrival)
Do the check-in yourself. (What if the phone is dead?) Although in my case there were problems with access to the Internet, also take this into account!
Check in your luggage yourself.
And if there is a problem, then figure out for yourself which line to stand in this time, and all the employees don't give a damn, even if you are seeing such automation for the first time!!

We wanted to stand in line to see a real person first, but the road was blocked by a tape and people were not allowed in, although the registration was still ongoing :/
Now I am sitting in this "wonderful" airport and I hope that I did everything right and my luggage will not fly off to where it should not
And for some reason another check before the gate, strange.
It was terminal 2, we will never get a visa run here again
