My advice to everyone who has not seen such automation "do it yourself" is to come for at least 3 hours, it's brutal

I am writing to provide feedback on my recent experience flying to KLIA via Singapore Airlines.

While I generally appreciate the quality of service on Singapore Airlines flights, I was disappointed with the airport experience at KLIA, especially considering this was not a budget flight.

Although the airport is large and packed with many shops and eateries, there are a few areas that could be improved to facilitate smoother transit for arriving passengers.

- These include having clearer directional signs/ large screen and more readily available information.

Upon arrival, after disembarking from the plane, we were directed by a staff member..standing at the side, to go to Cxx for a transfer to the arrival hall.

Rather than having a staff member saying  out to those passengers embarking, there might be a chance people will miss that important message.

- Wouldn't it be better to put up clear large signage at both sides of the walkway while  we disembarked?

- Would also suggest considering adjusting the volume of the announcement speaker with loud and clear information in English, Chinese, and Malay.

The signage for this bus transfer was also unclear, and it took us a while to find the area just to queue for a feeder bus.

Since this airport is named as an international airport, wouldn‚Äôt it be better to have a basic international ‚Äústandard‚Äù too?

The situation worsened upon arrival at the arrival hall.
The area was extremely crowded, and people are in queue of 2 -3 lines in a row....resulting in a queue of over an hour just to clear immigration.
Very disorganized and messy, no one was there to direct the human traffic, which leads to all these mess.

After clearing immigration, locating the correct baggage belt was challenging.
The area was crowded, and there were only three to four luggage belts where you needed to walk near the belt to check on the medium-sized monitor screen showing which flight these belts are meant for.

The screen flashed so fast with so many people trying to catch a glimpse of the information, which was rather frustrating, especially when there are different groups of people surrounding the area....some was like lost souls looking for directions,  while some gather in between the way waiting for their friends, and you have those looking up and low for the right belt for their luggage.

Literally, many passengers were visibly struggling to find their luggage, moving up and down, left and right.

We only found our luggage outside the luggage belt area, where there was a sign with the SQ Airlines logo on the floor.

There was quite a handful of luggage that was located there, which obviously most of those taking the same flight as us were still stuck in immigration.

Imagine the time taken from the moment we disembark from the plane and just to get out until our luggage was left outside and not at the belt....

Navigating the airport area to find a Grab was also confusing due to the signage, much of which was in Malay.

This can be rather challenging, especially after coming a long "way" out from immigration üòë

We thought maybe this is common for arrival passengers to encounter.

Who knows, we must go through the same things going back.

On our return flight, we were once again required to take a short bus to the departure hall.

Furthermore, there were no water dispensers available after passing through the inspection gate, which was inconvenient.

We have to endure our thirst till our flight takes off.

As a tourist, the airport gives the 1st impression for passengers and how they are organized.

This wasn't the kind of experience I was expecting from KLIA.

Hope this feedback will be taken into consideration for future improvements.

Aircon is not working in departure hall but working along the corridor to the toilet. Weird the departure lounge level 3 aircon is not working where all restaurant located. Corridor towards the gate is cramp when flight is delay. Restaurant mix are good
Budget extra time for departure immigration. Queues were crazy.

We flew with batik air. Check-in and the security checkpoint took minutes. Be aware that batik air seems to weigh your carry-on before boarding, and some people were stopped presumably to pay extra money for going over the maximum weight.

Interestingly enough, even though we also went over our limit, they let us pass without paying.

It feels inefficient for each gate to have its own security checkpoint, and it was confusing on whether we were boarding or not.

The most unhelpful staff I‚Äôve ever encountered. KLIA2 staff are more friendly. I lost my documents in customs and no one helped at all. They kept blaming me saying u forgot it at immigration, although I told them it must be in the scanning area.

Asked me to go all the way back to immigration carrying all my heavy bags.  I went all the way to immigration to look for it myself, they didn‚Äôt make any effort to call or find out anything.

Went all the way and then finally they called saying they found my passport somewhere, exactly where I said it was - they just didn‚Äôt want to check before. no apology at all and just asking where‚Äôs my location. No sympathy, rude tone - as if they didn‚Äôt tell me I had to go all the way to immigration to get my document.

Terrible way of acting and talking to customers, no sympathy at all. Staff needs training to talk to customers who are already distressed. They shouldn‚Äôt work in this industry
Slow and inefficient workers
Compared to KLIA2, the feeling is quite meh! Still

Not really. Very time-consuming, long waiting times, poorly organized.
Waited about an hour for the stupid entry stamp.

I recently traveled through KLIA and was quite disappointed with the overall experience. The ground staff were uncooperative and extremely slow ‚Äì it took me 45 minutes just to drop my luggage, which is unacceptable for a major international airport. There was a clear lack of urgency and coordination among the staff, which caused unnecessary delays and frustration.

The immigration process was no better. Officers were more engaged in chatting among themselves than assisting travelers. When it came to the facial recognition scan, there was no clear instruction on when to stop looking into the camera, leading to confusion and further hold-ups. Such negligence and poor communication from immigration staff are not what you'd expect from a facility that aims to be a gateway to the country.

Overall, KLIA seriously needs to step up its service standards. Staff training, efficiency, and customer interaction must be improved if the airport wants to compete with other major international hubs. I hope the management takes these issues seriously and implements changes soon.
Lazy security staff, no crowd management, rude passengers pushing in with no consequences. Many flight delays and gate changes at last minute
Avoid this airport if you can! Dirty, unusable toilet facilities, extraordinarily rude staff (not the restaurants) the airport staff. Hope to never have to go through there again!

Overall a nice airport but have to lower the rating due to the highly inefficient immigration process. The staff did not seem to care that there were 100s of people in line trying to catch their flights.

Not a pleasant experience. The satellite train is only available for first and business class. For economy passengers, one needs to walk a superbly long distance to take the coach to the main terminal. Why make such a change? No airports in the world make such inefficient decision for within airport to travel.between one terminal to another!!

People who are at safety check in front of gate C4&C2  are not polite, not responsible.
I went through the safety check. A few people were standing there chatting, laughing. No one helping moving stuff like other airports. Then after I passed and sat down. A woman came over asking us - a few people were here waiting - where we were going. Then told us ‚Äúout‚Äù, ‚Äúwait outside‚Äù. No sorry, no explanation, and the attitude was not good .
They didn‚Äôt check or ask before you went through the safety check. After you‚Äôve done everything - empty water bottles, take off the shoes‚Ä¶ - eventually went through, then kicking you out. You have to do that again later.
I have traveled a lot, been to many airports. These people here are the worst I have ever seen. Lazy and irresponsible people!

Had a very unpleasant experience. The staff insisted I pour out my liquids in the toilet, even though the sign clearly stated to dispose of them in front of the scanner. Additionally, there was no water dispenser available in the waiting area.

On the way back from our trip the airport was lovely and we had time to explore. However, on the way there. We had a short stop over because our flight was delayed.

There was a lady asking me a question from over 3 metres away and she was so soft spoken, I was also near the bag check line (sounds of the trays bashing down, people talk and zipping their bags, the roller conveyor belt). I gave her a puzzled look as I didn't hear her and she shouted the question at me and gave me an attitude (rolled her eyes). I genuinely did not hear her, this problem happened again with her voice later as she was announcing who could go on the plane and we were sitting near the door to exit (think again 3 metres away) and we could hardly hear her so people who were sitting all the way down the end if the waiting area were lining up randomly and she was getting annoyed at them for coming up when it wasn't their turn.

It's an airport, there is lots of hustle and bustle. You either need to be louder or use a microphone.

I've been to many airports, but this one is one of the worst.

I hate visiting this airport, but I frequently transit through Kuala Lumpur, so I'm always disappointed every time I have to.
Old fashioned airport. Landed at 6.30am after a long night flight and there‚Äôs super long queue at gate C waiting for bus transfer to the main arrival hall.

Poor experience from check in
assistant counter terminal 2.Male staff was so unprofessional.Was interfering with unnecessary issues around him keeps me waiting for a long time for a simple process(board pass printing for a missing person from self service counter)

Makes no sense and I wish there were signs about this prior to boarding. It means having to board the flight with nothing to drink which is not what you need on a long haul flight.

Automatic passport gates are extremely laggy. You have to ride bus numerous times to get anywhere. Everything takes ages. Every single airport in the world has the security check before shops except for this one.

Shameless and ridiculous airport KLIA 1. This deserved telur ayam ‚Äò0‚Äô kind of rating, not even a star. Even public toilet in Beijing gets higher rating than this from me.

No. It's been blocked, and Terminal 1 and Terminal 2 have been pointlessly removed. Poor routing. Too many shops. No logic. Lucky are those who managed to get to the gate on time.
rude employees. work very slowly. üëéüèªüëéüèªüëéüèª

This airport made me never want to come back to Malaysia. Who designed this place?!

First, the walk from the plane to immigration and baggage claim was unbelievably long. I‚Äôve traveled through many large airports, but I‚Äôve never had to walk this much just to reach my luggage. I could overlook that‚Ä¶ but what came next was even worse.

After collecting our bags and passing immigration, we were forced to walk through a mall to get to the exit. Yes, a literal mall where every airport in the world you'd be checking your transportation to finally leave. After a long flight, the last thing anyone wants is to be dragged through a maze of stores just to leave the airport. It felt like a cash grab, not a travel hub.

We finally made it out and were relieved to see Grab was available (we‚Äôre used to it from Thailand). But when we booked a ride, the wait time was 35 minutes! There was a huge, overcrowded Grab waiting area with screens showing incoming car plates, clearly, demand was way beyond what the airport could handle.

Tired and frustrated, we gave up on Grab, hoping to catch a bus instead. But we weren‚Äôt allowed to buy tickets until exactly 12 PM, which was also the listed departure time, because it's too late now to buy tickets (15 minutes ahead). We were told the bus would leave even after 12. The whole thing felt disorganized and unclear and the wait time seemed same as the Grab and the destination station is not even close to the hotel.

In the end, we paid over double the Grab fare to take a regular taxi, just to get the hell out of there.

This airport is a logistical mess and a terrible first impression of Malaysia.

Unlike the hospitality of the malaysian people, the Airport security and Police staff are the worst you can Meet.
Rude behaviour and irritating signs to tourists especially those from GCC countires. A Bad representitive of malaysia and its friendly people.

Immigration in the country took more than 1.5 hours and system was down so they had to do manual entries.

Welcome to KLIA2 (Terminal 2), one of the 2 terminal of KL International Airport - the proud home of AirAsia and every traveler who thought ‚Äúbudget travel‚Äù just meant a cheap ticket, not a 1.2km hike from immigration to Gate J22. Built more like a shopping mall that occasionally remembers it‚Äôs an airport, KLIA2 offers you the chance to buy bubble tea, sushi, and Crocs all before even hitting security.

Need retail therapy at 3 a.m.? You‚Äôre in luck. Need a quiet seat with a charging port? Hah, good luck.

Stat corner: Opened in 2014 to replace the low-cost LCCT terminal, KLIA2 is the largest purpose-built terminal for low-cost carriers in the world. It‚Äôs also a maze where time and boarding calls are mere suggestions.

Still, with AirAsia‚Äôs mantra of ‚ÄúNow Everybody Can Fly,‚Äù this terminal proves it , whether you‚Äôre a backpacker, a broke student, or someone who accidentally booked the wrong airport entirely.

Pro tip: ARRIVE EARLY, wear comfy shoes, and emotionally prepare for a shopping mall with a runway.

I am writing to provide feedback on my recent experience flying to KLIA via Singapore Airlines.

While I generally appreciate the quality of service on Singapore Airlines flights, I was disappointed with the airport experience at KLIA, especially considering this was not a budget flight.

Upon arrival, after disembarking from the plane, we were directed by a staff member, who was shouting, to proceed to Cxx for a transfer to the arrival hall.

Was thinking that perhaps our flight was scheduled to park in a ‚Äúfurther‚Äù lot due to multiple flights arriving around the same time.‚Äã
Personally, I wasn‚Äôt expecting to go through the hassle of having to transit from the plane to the arrival hall, taking into consideration that this was a direct flight.
Anyway, still went with the flow and follow those in front since we are told to....

This information could easily be missed if people are talking or focused on finding the nearest toilet.

Although the airport was large and packed with lots of shops and eateries, there are areas that could be improved to facilitate smoother transit for arriving/departure passengers.

‚ÄãWould suggest the following improvements:

* Rather than having a staff member shouting/giving instructions, ‚Äãcan consider placing clear, large signage on both sides of the walkway as passengers disembark.
* Provide more readily available information upon flight arrival‚Äã / departure.
* Consider adjusting the volume of the announcement speaker with loud and clear information in English, Chinese, and Malay.

Clear directional signs and information would make a big difference for first-time visitors like myself and would save a lot of time‚Äã especially when there are so many incoming/outgoing flights day to day.....

The signage for the bus transfer was unclear, and it took approximately 4-5 minutes to find the waiting point to queue for the feeder bus to the arrival hall.

Upon arriving at the arrival hall, it was another 2-minute walk to reach immigration. The area was extremely crowded, with queues of 2-3 lines in a row, resulting in an hour-long wait to clear immigration.

The process was very disorganized and messy, with no one managing the human traffic, possibly due to a shortage of manpower.
Although the officers were friendly and efficient in clearing the queue,
it would be beneficial to have crowd control/security to guide and manage the flow of passengers.

Locating the correct baggage belt after clearing immigration was another challenge. The area was crowded, and there were only three to four luggage belts, requiring passengers to walk near the belt to check the monitor screen.
This was frustrating, especially with different groups of people surrounding the area, some looking for directions, some waiting for friends, and others searching for the right belt.
We eventually found our luggage placed not far away from the luggage belt area near the exit, with a sign displaying the SQ Airlines logo on the floor.
Many unclaimed bags from our flight were present, as most passengers were still stuck in immigration.

The entire process, from disembarking the plane to retrieving our luggage outside the baggage claim area, was challenging.

I thought we were only required to transit to the arrival hall as a one-time occurrence. However, on our return flight, we were once again required to take a short bus to the departure hall.
Furthermore, there were no water dispensers available after passing through the inspection gate, which was inconvenient.

As a tourist, the airport gives the first impression for passengers, and its organization is crucial.

I hope this feedback will be taken into consideration for future improvements

Very clean and all, but the reason I rate it 1 star is because of how they treat my luggage. It is emirates airlines that treated my luggage bad and so as the airport. I would rate it 0 stars but there is no option for thatüòî

The most inconvenient airport I‚Äôve ever been to, with a very dirty environment. It definitely fails to meet the standards of an international airport.

One of the worst airport experiences I‚Äôve ever had. While the airport is spacious, the design is extremely confusing. Each level has two separate sides, and if you accidentally end up on the wrong one, you have to go back up and re-enter from another point ‚Äì there‚Äôs no direct way to cross over.

The terminals are connected by trains, but shockingly, you‚Äôre charged 2 MYR per person just to use them! Shuttle buses are available, but only from specific areas that take at least 30 minutes of walking to reach, with no clear guidance. There are no proper information desks, and you‚Äôre left to ask random staff who often give vague or conflicting directions.

To make matters worse, baggage trolley staff were communicating using loud whistles ‚Äì it was chaotic and very unpleasant. The AirAsia terminal (2) was particularly bad and felt extremely disorganized.

This experience alone is enough to make me reconsider visiting Malaysia again just to avoid going through this airport.

I am writing to provide feedback on my recent experience flying to KLIA via Singapore Airlines. While I generally appreciate the quality of service on Singapore Airlines flights, I was disappointed with the airport experience at KLIA, especially considering this was not a budget flight.

Although the airport is large and packed with many shops and eateries, there are a few areas that could be improved to facilitate smoother transit for arriving passengers.
These include having clearer directional signs/ large screen and more readily available information.

Upon arrival, after disembarking from the plane, we were directed by a staff member to go to C15 for a transfer to the arrival hall. Rather having a staff to shout ,wouldn't it be better to put up clear large signage at both side of the walk way while we disembark?

The signage for this bus transfer was also unclear, and it took us a while to find the area just to queue for a feeder bus.

Would also suggest considering adjusting the volume of the announcement speaker with loud and clear information in English, Chinese, and Malay.

Since this airport is named as an international airport, wouldn‚Äôt it be better to have basic international ‚Äústandard‚Äù too?

Situation worsened upon arrival at the arrival hall.
The area was extremely crowded,people are in queue of 2 -3 lines in a row....resulting in a queue of over an hour just to clear immigration.
Very disorganized and messy, no one was there to direct the human traffic which leads to all these mess.

After clearing immigration, locating the correct baggage belt was challenging.
The area was crowded, and there were only three to four luggage belts where you needed to walk near the belt to check on the medium-sized monitor screen showing which flight these belts are meant for.

The screen flashed so fast with so many people trying to catch a glimpse of the information, which was rather frustrating, especially when yiu have different groups of people surrounding the area....some was waiting for their friends while some was was looking for the right belt for their luggage.
Literally, many passengers were visibly struggling to find their luggage, moving up and down, left and right.

We only found our luggage outside the luggage belt area, where there was a sign with the Singapore Airlines logo on the floor. Quite a handful of luggage was located there, which obviously most of those taking the same flight were still stuck in immigration.
Imagine the time taken from the moment we disembark from the plane and just to get out until our luggage was left outside and not at the belt.

Navigating the airport area to find a Grab was also confusing due to the signage much of which was in Malay.
This can be rather challenging, especially after a series of such "events" we went through.
We thought maybe this is common for arrival passengers to encounter, who knows we must go through the same things going back.

On our return flight, we were once again required to take a short bus to the departure hall.
Furthermore, there were no water dispensers available after passing through the inspection gate, which was inconvenient.We have to endure our thirst till our flight take off.

As a tourist, I don‚Äôt enjoy it if I have to go through so much hassle. This was one of a kind of experience i wasn't expecting from KLIA...

Hope this feedback will be taken into consideration for future improvements.

The airport looks very fancy and all - at least Terminal 1. It is very unorganized though. We arrived extremely late from our first flight (thank you batik air) and only had 15-20min items to get our connecting flight. Normally airports would provide a shuttle services, picking you from a gate to bring you to your connecting flight in time. This was not the case here, we were only told the gate number of our connecting flight, which after running to for 10min, turned out to be the wrong gate. So instead we had to take the bus to another terminal, which obviously did not give us enough time to catch our flight, so we were stuck in KL for 1 night. Additionally it is ridiculous, that there is no smoking area in the entirety of terminal 1. So if you are stuck here for a while you have to go all the way to terminal 2, into one of the most disgusting smoking rooms I‚Äôve witnessed in my life (no ventilation at all, might as well just walk in and breath twice and you‚Äôve already passively smoked a carton of cigarettes). Really disappointing for such a modern (only t1) and large airport.

Arriving:
Immigration for arrivals took too long! The officers works so slowly and the poor internet connection in this area is not helping either. It took us long enough to complete immigration to the point that our bags were no longer in the conveyor belt/shown on screen. Pick up location of ride hailing (Grab) was easy at Level 1.

Departure:
Check in counters are spread out making it not too crowded/congested. Immigration for departure is quicker and easier. However, there's a security screening for customs departure that was separated with at-gate security check. I would say this is very inefficient as you need to check your bags twice and once you have cleared security you practically cannot go out to the retail area. In addition, the post-security gate is a nightmare with neither water stations nor proper toilet! There seems to be no signs of priority boarding based on group but rather by seats (not sure if this is an MH or KLIA problem). Retail space is decent with great tax-free goods options and decent restaurant selections. One thing to appreciate: the toilets (in retail & public) areas are clean and equipped with jet showers.

Arrived at Kuala Lumpur in the late afternoon, and the queue at immigration was very long. We got in and waited about 15 minutes, when we left there were 2-3 times as many people, so they must have waited for over 30 minutes.

There are not many officers. But the thing that annoyed the most, was the lack of transparency regarding the newly introduced MDAC that every foreigner needs to fill in. About 20% of the people in the queue wait for a long time, and then when coming to the immigration officer they did not fill in the MDAC and the foreigner is redirected to the back again to fill it in. It is a waste of time for people waiting, the immigration officers and for the people who did not fill it in.

It is very simple, put some signage to be clear at the start of the queue. "Did you fill in your MDAC?". If not, fill it in first. I literally filled it in in 2 minutes while I was in the long queue.

Sure, everyone needs to do their own research. But from a big airport like Kuala Lumpur, this is terrible organization and messes with people who have connecting flights.

Despite my repeated requests, the airport police refused to take my report and instead escorted me to the immigration department.

There, I was met by an aggressive and unprofessional immigration officer named Kamarudin. When I asked for his full name in writing, he refused and rudely pointed to his name badge, telling me to take a photo with my phone. The moment I did, he became enraged and began intimidating me‚Äîeven going so far as to take photos of me and my passport on his personal phone. This was a blatant violation of privacy and professional conduct.

**Malaysia‚Äôs airport authorities and immigration officers behaved in a disgusting, abusive, and unaccountable manner. Travelers beware: AVOID MALAYSIA at all costs!**

**Legal Analysis**
This conduct raises multiple violations under Malaysian law:

1. **Assault and Criminal Force (Penal Code Sections 350-352)**
The staff member's actions in grabbing my arms and physically restraining me without consent constitutes criminal force under Section 350. Case precedent (PP v. Mohd Anuar bin Abdullah [1994] 2 MLJ 261) confirms that any intentional use of force without lawful justification meets this threshold.

2. **Wrongful Confinement (Penal Code Section 340)**
The unlawful restriction of my movement within the clinic treatment room amounts to wrongful confinement. Malaysian jurisprudence establishes that detention without legal authority is punishable, particularly where no legitimate lien exists over the person.

3. **Official Misconduct**
The behavior of Immigration Officer Kamarudin in:
- Failing to properly address a criminal complaint
- Intimidating a complainant
- Improper use of personal devices to photograph sensitive documents
May constitute offenses under Malaysia's official misconduct provisions.

UPDATE: Malaysian Airport Management have promised a full investigation of this matter however no official response as of yet.

This airport made me never want to come back to Malaysia. Who designed this place?!

First, the walk from the plane to immigration and baggage claim was unbelievably long. I‚Äôve traveled through many large airports, but I‚Äôve never had to walk this much just to reach my luggage. I could overlook that‚Ä¶ but what came next was even worse.

After collecting our bags and passing immigration, we were forced to walk through (GET THIS!) A MALL to get to the exit. Yes, a literal mall where every airport in the world you'd be checking your transportation to finally leave. After a long flight, the last thing anyone wants is to be dragged through a maze of stores just to leave the airport. It felt like a cash grab, not a travel hub.

We finally made it out and were relieved to see Grab was available (we‚Äôre used to it from Thailand). But when we booked a ride, the wait time was 35 minutes! There was a huge, overcrowded Grab waiting area with screens showing incoming car plates, clearly, demand was way beyond what the airport could handle.

Tired and frustrated, we gave up on Grab, hoping to catch a bus instead. But we weren‚Äôt allowed to buy tickets until exactly 12 AM, which was also the listed departure time of the bus, "because it's too late now to buy tickets" (15 minutes ahead). We were told the bus would leave even after 12. The whole thing felt disorganized and unclear and the wait time seemed same as the Grab and the destination station is not even close to the hotel.

In the end, we paid almost triple the Grab fare to take a regular taxi, just to get the hell out of there.

And also, the airport wifi is not available once you finish immigration! I had such a hard time to book the Grab taxi and check information and chat with my airbnb host because there was no wifi after immigration, in any airport that's when wifi is needed!! But here there's a freakin' mall between the airport and the exits!!!

I've never had this much hastle and wasted time to manage to exit an airport, oh yeah, and the airport is so far away from the city it took us 90 minutes to reach the hotel (with zero traffic after midnight) knowing this, the designers still decided to add a mall to make your trip even slower!

This airport is a logistical mess and a terrible first impression of Malaysia. I've never thought an airport would affect my will to visit a country but here we are.

A more than bad experience... I arrived at the airport at 7:00 AM, and went directly to wrap my large bag. There were only two people in front of me, but the wrapping took longer than expected. When I got to the baggage check-in counter, I found the queue very long, and my turn didn't come until 8:15 AM!!! The flight gate opened... When I finished, I didn't know where to go to find the gate, so I asked one of the employees, and her response was very... When she left, she started mocking me in front of the shop owners, as she imitated the way I spoke in front of them. I didn't have time to stop her because this is a disrespectful way to treat tourists and guests in general... Anyway, when I finally got to the bus stop, I found another queue, and we went to the bus, thank God... But the surprise was that there was another inspection before boarding the plane!!!! This caused the backlog and queues again!!!! One of the worst airport experiences in my life. Unprofessional and slow employees, poor airport management and organization. Finally, the plane didn't take off after this chaos until half an hour after the official takeoff time, and I was forced to stand during these three hours because of the boring and tiring queues. A bad experience by all standards.

My recent experience at Kuala Lumpur International Airport was shockingly poor and has completely soured my view of Malaysia.  Arriving late at night, I was met with an appalling three-hour wait in the immigration queue.  With only two counters open, the already tired and frustrated passengers were subjected to rude and unprofessional behavior from the immigration officers.  One officer, who identified himself as Nizam, was particularly aggressive, yelling at passengers and making demeaning comments about their attempts to use the biometric scanners.  His dismissive attitude and condescending tone were echoed by other staff members, creating a hostile and uncomfortable atmosphere for everyone, including families with young children.
The situation worsened when, due to the extensive delay, our luggage was removed from the baggage carousel.  This added further stress and inconvenience to an already exhausting experience. It felt as though the immigration staff treated their positions as some sort of celebrity status, rather than a service role.
The impact of this disastrous airport experience rippled through my entire trip.  I had to cancel some planned tourist attractions due to the excessive wait times I encountered elsewhere, including another two-hour queue.  My children were exhausted, and our holiday was ultimately ruined.
As if the airport ordeal wasn't enough, our tourist vehicle was later stopped by police for a seemingly pointless immigration check, resulting in another hour-long delay.  This unnecessary display of authority felt like a final insult.
It's ironic that Malaysia's economy relies heavily on tourism, yet visitors are treated with such disrespect.  This entire experience was so negative that I will never visit Malaysia again.  It's truly a shame, as I had hoped for a much more positive experience.
Not a pleasant experience. The security officers are rude and the fact that the boarding gates are inside and not open to caf√©s makes it inconvenient when waiting for a flight early in the morning.

I am writing to provide feedback on my recent experience flying to KLIA via Singapore Airlines. While I generally appreciate the quality of service on Singapore Airlines flights, I was disappointed with the airport experience at KLIA, especially considering this was not a budget flight.

Although the airport is large and packed with many shops and eateries, there are a few areas that could be improved to facilitate smoother transit for arriving passengers.
These include having clearer directional signs/ large screen and more readily available information.

Upon arrival, after disembarking from the plane, we were directed by a staff member to go to C15 for a transfer to the arrival hall. Rather having a staff to shout ,wouldn't it be better to put up clear signage at both side of the walk way while we disembark?

The signage for this bus transfer was unclear, and it took us a while to find the area just to queue for a feeder bus.

Would also suggest considering adjusting the volume of the announcement speaker with loud and clear information in English, Chinese, and Malay.

Since this airport is named as an international airport, wouldn‚Äôt it be better to have basic international ‚Äústandard‚Äù too?

Situation worsened upon arrival at the arrival hall.
The area was extremely crowded,people are in queue of 2 -3 lines in a row....resulting in a queue of over an hour just to clear immigration.
Very disorganized and messy, no one was there to direct the human traffic which leads to all these mess.

After clearing immigration, locating the correct baggage belt was challenging.
The area was crowded, and there were only three to four luggage belts where you needed to walk near the belt to check on the medium-sized monitor screen showing which flight these belts are meant for.

The screen flashed so fast with so many people trying to catch a glimpse of the information, which was rather frustrating, especially when yiu have different groups of people surrounding the area....some was waiting for their friends while some was was looking for the right belt for their luggage.
Literally, many passengers were visibly struggling to find their luggage, moving up and down, left and right.

We only found our luggage outside the luggage belt area, where there was a sign with the Singapore Airlines logo on the floor. Quite a handful of luggage was located there, which obviously most of those taking the same flight were still stuck in immigration.
Imagine the time taken from the moment we disembark from the plane and just to get out until our luggage was left outside and not at the belt.

Navigating the airport area to find a Grab was also confusing due to the signage much of which was in Malay.
This can be rather challenging, especially after a series of such "events" we went through.
We thought maybe this is common for arrival passengers to encounter, who knows we must go through the same things going back.

On our return flight, we were once again required to take a short bus to the departure hall.
Furthermore, there were no water dispensers available after passing through the inspection gate, which was inconvenient.We have to endure our thirst till our flight take off.

As a tourist, I don‚Äôt enjoy it if I have to go through so much hassle. This was one of a kind of experience i wasn't expecting from KLIA...

Hope this feedback will be taken into consideration for future improvements.
The transportation and services are all very far apart from each other. This does not matter when the staff are rude and completely disrespectful.

My recent experience at Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) was unfortunately extremely disappointing.

Firstly, the staff were generally unfriendly and appeared to have minimal understanding of English, which made basic communication difficult to impossible.
More critically, there was a noticeable general incompetence across various functions. Staff seemed unable or unwilling to perform their duties, such as overseeing passengers and maintaining order in the queues. In this context, I repeatedly observed an absolute lack of professional supervision, where people were simply allowed to cut in line or where queues dissolved into chaos without any staff intervention.
An additional major point of inefficiency was the self-service process: I was directed to the scanner by immigration staff, only for the scanner to then instruct me to return to the immigration counter, causing further unnecessary delays and frustration.

Furthermore, the signage (wayfinding) was poor, often unclear, and lacked sufficient repetition throughout the terminal, making navigation difficult.

To top it all off, there was also a lack of seating at the airport itself, and the seats that were available were often taken up by a single person lying down across three seats, leaving people who wanted to sit with nowhere to go.

This combination of poor (and by times even disrespectful) customer service, language barriers, failure to enforce basic operational procedures and the lack of seating led to unnecessary stress and delays. It's clear that KLIA urgently needs to invest in significantly better training for its personnel, focusing on customer service, language proficiency, and core job efficiency.

If I could give 0 stars, I would!

It takes a lot of time to reach departure gates. Wi-Fi didn't work well & I had a 7-hr layover before taking my connecting flight to Ho Chi Minh City(SGN), Vietnam. Food and drinks are not cheap at all, pricy meals!!!

Substandard‚Ä¶. All the digital screens not working. Using white boards and useless humans to hold pieces of paper.

My second trip through Kuala Lumpur International Airport was unfortunately just as frustrating as the first.

The customer service here is a huge problem. I asked multiple staff members for help with basic info, and every single one just shrugged, said "I don't know" and acted like it wasn't their job. There was zero effort to even try and find out. It's truly baffling.

Then there's the internal airport bus with no proper monitoring. We had our 5-month-old with us and we literally had to stand for a 5-minute ride between gates. The bus wasn't even packed but everyone was too busy hogging their spot to offer one up to someone struggling with a baby. The fear of losing balance and dropping our infant was terrifying. People just sat there watching us, completely uncaring.

To top it off, we saw a couple of electric buggies nearby, clearly for passenger assistance, but there was no one to drive them! We asked four different staff if they could help us get one, and each time, we got the same clueless "I don't know" response.

For an international airport, the lack of basic help and common courtesy is really poor. Traveling with a baby is already tough enough, and KLIA just made it worse. I'll definitely be trying to avoid this airport next time.

This airport made me never want to come back to Malaysia. Who designed this place?!

First, the walk from the plane to immigration and baggage claim was unbelievably long. I‚Äôve traveled through many large airports, but I‚Äôve never had to walk this much just to reach my luggage. I could overlook that‚Ä¶ but what came next was even worse.

After collecting our bags and passing immigration, we were forced to walk through a mall to get to the exit. Yes, a literal mall where every airport in the world you'd be checking your transportation to finally leave. After a long flight, the last thing anyone wants is to be dragged through a maze of stores just to leave the airport. It felt like a cash grab, not a travel hub.

We finally made it out and were relieved to see Grab was available (we‚Äôre used to it from Thailand). But when we booked a ride, the wait time was 35 minutes! There was a huge, overcrowded Grab waiting area with screens showing incoming car plates, clearly, demand was way beyond what the airport could handle.

Tired and frustrated, we gave up on Grab, hoping to catch a bus instead. But we weren‚Äôt allowed to buy tickets until exactly 12 PM, which was also the listed departure time, because it's too late now to buy tickets (15 minutes ahead). We were told the bus would leave even after 12. The whole thing felt disorganized and unclear and the wait time seemed same as the Grab and the destination station is not even close to the hotel.

In the end, we paid over double the Grab fare to take a regular taxi, just to get the hell out of there.

I had the worst experience in this airport for travelling.  This looks fancy but very old school.

Very confusing direction or procedure. I was required to transferred here from overseas to KKIA (domestic) i was not required to take my lugguage while I gone through the customs here. I visited Malaysia recently to attend a concert. I queued at immigration for almost two hours. When it was my turn, the officer did not smile or greet me back, despite my polite greeting. She only said ‚ÄúTicket?‚Äù without explaining further.

I showed my concert ticket, but she gave no response and told me to go back and queue again. I explained that I had already waited for over an hour, but she insisted without reason. Her tone and facial expressions were unfriendly, making my first impression of Malaysia very disappointing.

Eventually, I showed all my documents and was allowed to pass. However, her attitude left a negative memory of the trip. I hope the management can provide proper training to ensure visitors are treated with courtesy.

I‚Äôve traveled through KLIA countless times over the years, and it has always stood out for its cleanliness, smooth check-in process, and efficient security checks. The architecture, inspired by Malaysian, Islamic, and natural elements, is a beautiful highlight. But what truly made KLIA special was its balance of foreign and unique local offerings.

With the recent KLIA1 renovation, I have to give credit where it‚Äôs due- the new bathrooms are a massive improvement! Well-designed, clean, and dry. But I can‚Äôt ignore the disappointing shift in retail and dining options. Many local options have disappeared, replaced by foreign goods. Also why is alcohol and tobacco taking up a large portion of the retail space every time? I was shocked to find only one shelf of Malaysian food products in the entire terminal 1. Malaysia is a foodie haven‚Äîwhy isn‚Äôt KLIA showcasing its rich culinary heritage and  diversity?

Gone are the great local options that once served authentic dishes like kaya toast, prawn noodles and teh tarik. Instead, global chains like Starbucks and Gloria Jean‚Äôs dominate the F&B spaces. Surely, there‚Äôs room for more homegrown eateries that represent Malaysia‚Äôs incredible food culture?

To add to the frustration, the monorail is still not working, and travelers have to rely on shuttle buses- slow and less efficient. And when I asked an ‚ÄòAsk Me For Help‚Äô staff member for food recommendations, she barely looked up from her phone‚Äîcustomer service should be better than this.

KLIA, we can do better! Support local businesses and bring back the true Malaysian experience.

over years klia I & klia II has been quite the smooth transportation for flyers both domestic and international. unfortunately there also were some unpleasant experiences many flyers had encountered or witnessed. personally often noticed such unpleasant incidences happening, for example, 2 ineffectively handling at heavily heaving airline check-in counters ( a python long queue today),  on-going passengers at transit train between terminals ( in the mean time the sky train rosak that airport authorities addressed the issue with buses yet effective though), at the immigration (remember seeing poor innocent south asians were shouted to and treated with discriminative manners, rude and loudly likely a racial verbal abuse. it was a moment of unbearable injustice towards humanity), at baggage claim, at security checks or even at Whsmiths, ffs. today it was still leaving flyers compromising authorities were seemed proactively dealing with situation. Only One part still looking ugly and disgusting, most are from the people who occupied there, is the pick-up and drop-off area in front of arrival and departure terminal. what a marked down. wish for the best.
Endless lines at immigration checkpoints. Unacceptable.

At the T1 departure gate of Kuala Lumpur Airport, you will check your luggage for the first time and then go to the duty-free shop (there is a toilet but the water dispenser has no water and it is not easy to go around). Then you will go to the boarding gate and check your luggage for the second time (boarding waiting area). No toilets, no drinking fountains), it really needs improvement.
This is the shittiest airport ever. Staffs are very rude and not helpful. We missed a flight and had to pay double bc of the their fault
The worst airport I have ever visited. We need to travel from different terminals with limited bus. The toilet is so horrible.

It might be more appropriate to call it Kuala Lumpur Airport rather than 'International.' While the airport is generally clean and well-lit, the transit area is underwhelming. Wi-Fi connectivity is slow, and there are limited food and retail options. A significant upgrade or expansion is needed if the airport aims to keep up with other regional hubs.

Additionally, the transport pick-up experience at Terminal 2 was a nightmare. The poorly designed two-lane pick-up area created severe congestion, and we ended up waiting over an hour just to be picked up. It's unclear who was responsible for this layout, but it clearly needs a serious rethink

Dear KLIA terminal 1 gate C officer,
I want to ask for help, how can I get back the jewelry that was left behind during the scan near departure Gate C? My sister left her jewelry near the scanning area. During the body scan, the officer asked her to take off her bracelet, but she forgot to put it back. Not a single officer issued an announcement about the items left behind. It's not certain if the item will be taken by the next passenger who scans it or the officer, please keep it. Arriving at the new destination country, my sister realized that she had forgotten to destroy the jewelry. We have tried calling the airport contact number and messaging on the website, but there is no response. Please help from the airport to help us. Thank You.
The hospitality is not good and not really child friendly, the immigration is so slow‚Ä¶
Dine in Nasi Lemak in the food court at KLIA Terminal 2.

One of the worst immigration counters.
Only two officers for three long queue of people more than 150.
And no response from anyone and no one for guidance. They(Malaysian Airlines) also allowed everyone at a time instead following the flight timings in the check-in.
Many things to change in KLIA Departure Terminal.

What a horrible airport.
The security check is just before the flight, so there is a major delay. They also don't have enough trays or a proper system, making it so much worse.
The washrooms are horrendous. Open pads with blood, tissue on the floor, no tissue rolls and extreme stench.
And the gates, extremely disorganised, without any queues and just people cluttering.

Thai airport needs changes and a better system.

I‚Äôve traveled for over 10 years, and I have NEVER seen anything as poorly managed as Kuala Lumpur Airport. We were already waiting in line at the gate, yet we STILL almost missed our flight. How is that even possible?!

Turns out, they check liquids right before the gate‚Äîyes, AFTER security, after duty-free, after everything. This is the most illogical, frustrating, and time-wasting system I have ever experienced. People were rushing, confused, and stressed, while staff moved at a painfully slow pace.

If you value your sanity, arrive ridiculously early or just avoid this airport altogether. Absolute chaos.

Absolutely absurd and harsh behavior by the immigration officer and immigration help desk. I forgot to print my visa for this only they made me wait for 3+ Hours and still no help. It all started well, it's a comfortable airport with nice staff. I don't like the service of the salesperson who is not educated towards visitors, their attitude is not used, please improve the salesperson's service so that it is comfortable, if there is a problem with flight service, okay.

The airport is very new and clearly marked. When I visited two years ago, there was no tram available. This time, it's been repaired, making it very convenient to take the tram directly to the departure area. There are plenty of shops, but prices are quite high. One downside is that once you enter the departure lounge, you have to check your carry-on luggage again. If you bought something in the duty-free shop or food court, you can bring it to the VIP lounge. You can't even bring water with you. It's really strange. You have to leave the departure lounge to use the restroom, which is really inconvenient.
Big airport but duty free shop is a bit disappointing. Make sure to get all items you need before coming to airport

So disappointed, my mom was transit to malaysia 2 days ago but the staff was so rude, they didn‚Äôt even smile. They told my mom to pay more because of her belongings weight or something like that, but the staff was so rude guys ‚Äúyou want to pay or not?‚Äù They even call me mom friend ‚Äúbikin susah, buat susah aja‚Äù because they can‚Äôt pay more, is that how you treat a tourist? Even tho they‚Äôre just transit there, but at least show some respect. I hope this is could help for your management, my mom didn‚Äôt deserve this.
In line with the rest of Kuala Lumpur city planning: unstructured, unorganized, inefficient. What a sad sad place
So complicated, guidance is not clear, immigration process is so slow

Messed up arrival , required digital data access or go through manual process ,  departures is archaic with all manual immigration check point then security screening , then a bus travel to gate then another security screen with one security screen allowing coke cans the last one doesn't allow it , why we need to go through 2 check points after the initial one is baffling unless your security is lacks in-between the airport itself.

Worst airport. They flow system is too messy and scattered, long line of queues everywhere - immigration, bag checking, then another bag checking before come inside the plane. Took us around 45 mins to queue at the immigration ONLY. Some of the staffs are lack of sense urgency.

The worst airport I‚Äôve been to. Staff are extremely rude and unhelpful. They had multiple signs up for check in, we reach through the security only to be told to go back because it‚Äôs a different flight. Second time going through, the staff at security are trying to rush people through handing out individual items like it‚Äôs an auction- as I try to get through the lady then yells to go back. I was doing what she asked‚Ä¶getting my belongings. A little bit of compassion, and helpfulness can go a long way for people who have been travelling a long time. One should completely avoid traveling from Kuala Lumpur International Airport. They don't open the gates where there are seats available as a result passenger sit on the floor and main seat around the gate remain empty.  Rude Staff as well. Lot of inconvenience!

Highly Unprofessional Staff ( at least the one i dealt with ) waited almost 1.5 hours in the line there was my friend ahead of me and i was next. The lady officer she didn‚Äôt asked him anything just held his passport and asked him to go to the immigration office ( He is a frequent traveller and has active visas for NZ and Uk ). I was next she saw me and told me to go too and doesn‚Äôt even let me to go closer to the counter.

We went to the immigration office and waited 6 hour for our number and when we were called the officer just asked me 2 questions literally 2 questions:
1 - How long you gonna stay.
2- Do you have a hotel booking.

I was so heartbroken to hear these questions which the first officer could have asked me at the first place.

I told the officer at the immigration about this whole scenario and she was shocked by herself and told me that she should not have sent me here and ask these questions by herself.

Literally ruined my whole day almost 11 hours at the airport. Really disappointed because i was not expecting this kind of behaviour by a country which i was very excited to visit.

If my review finds any person in charge please look into this matter. I know there are people who enters the country for illegal purposes like slipping or so but what about the legit tourists? There were hundreds of people dealing with the same thing.
It‚Äôs the job of officers to question and if they suspect something then send them for proper questioning. Don‚Äôt judge by the ethnicity or nationality.
The entry aisle is very long, the Chinese service is insufficient, and the service attitude of the staff is very good.

I rarely give 1-star reviews, but this airport truly deserves it. The boarding process is poor. The security machines are outdated and the taxis are old and dirty, showing no signs of improvement in decades. Even the so-called premium taxis are worse than budget taxis in many other countries. After a post-COVID renovation, they still use manual water taps. Isn‚Äôt contactless supposed to matter after COVID? Hard to believe this place gets 4 or 5 stars.
Some unfriendly immigration and custom staff - not truely Asia
One of the worst airport. Staff is useless and nothing works as it should be
Convenient, spacious, many brand name shops, but Starbucks is outside before check-in.

(Emerites specifically from KL).. KL is a beautiful airport, super clean, very convenient with English signs everywhere- with many options for drink and food land side before security - coffee, mcdonald‚Äôs, taco bell and high end malaysian restaurants. NOTE: the few Emirates flights that leave from here, despite what you may read, have NO bag drop, have no kiosks to print your bag tag or boarding pass, and if you are checking a bag you have to stand in the forever line with people going to Dubai with 5 giant suitcases. Not having an Emirates bag drop or kiosk is ridiculous. NOTE: Terminal C gates - the entire terminal stinks of cigarettes and the none care security has for looking at carry on‚Äôs is terrifying. Many didn‚Äôt even look at the screens, they were too busy dillydallying. Also note they don‚Äôt use AC, at least in the C areas going international; it‚Äôs so hot people are passing out, fainting, getting sick from the heat and no air. It‚Äôs stifling. There is no air circulating and it‚Äôs so bad, i‚Äôm even feeling nauseas.

One of the worst airports in the world. Incredibly rude and unhelpful staff. Security are very rude too.
A lot of money scams.
The logistics and location are too confusing and complicated.

2019 International departure, water dispensers malfunction. Passenger bridge no aircon under 2pm hot weather ! Poor management.
2025 whole domestic B adapter slot not working!
2025 lack of seats, aircon always not cooling even at night. After entering C gate, no water refill available?
A joke from Malaysia?

Worst airport of my life. Incompetent staff, I had a flight delay which made me miss my connection. When asking for information, I found myself going all over the airport because incompetent people who claim to speak and understand English directed me.

If you can avoid using this airport I would suggest in doing so.

I have been in and out of KL a few times and each time has been a terrible experience.

You will be charged fees you don‚Äôt need to pay, wait in long queues and be sent to multiple stations around the airport.

One particularly notable time recently was I waited so long to check in my baggage and we had told the staff our flight was soon. When I finally arrived at the counter the woman  was fussing about. I asked her five times if there was an issue, and after ignoring me all those times she eventually told me my flight was boarding, so I‚Äôd have to take the next flight. Once I asked her what the next time was she said 5pm, this meant I would have been stranded in Thailand with no accommodation as I needed to get a boat to where I was going. The last boat was at 6pm.

After having multiple arguments with the staff a lovely man did escort us to our gate.

There have honestly been multiple issues similarly at this airport, with unhelpful staff. This is coming from someone who is more than happy and patient to wait!

Absolutely pathetic airport.

Security is a disorganized disaster with rude staff who openly discriminated against Nepali passengers.

Toilets were filthy - no tissue, stinking, and clearly not cleaned.

Boarding gates were a joke: no system, no queues, just chaos.

KLIA is a complete embarrassment for an international airport.

Extremely below par experience at this airport. No area to charge devices, very limited shopping options, the staff everywhere generally seemed cold and miserable, and the only food that was available was old junk food, no options for vegetarians.

Need a gigantic effort to improve. Not user friendly. For example, need to carry your big heavy luggage for customs X-Ray to scan. Luggage belt info display not clear and can never be turn to advertisement.
Nothing really much to do there! Shopping is miserable. Though checking in is rather fast now!
It was my first visit to Kuala Lumpur there was a lot of delay at the emegration

All prices are more than double the outside. Restaurants are ridiculously expensive and souvenirs are usually 2-3 times more expensive. There is also a security check at the gate, so it is unsettling.
Some of the auto walker is in bad condition and creaking so bad -1, the staffs aren't kind and helpful -2

There is a second security at ALL the gates and so you can't take water on board. Batik airlines forces you to buy water on the plane. This is a violation of human rights.

The airport is really loud in general and experienced sensory overload.

There is a lack of toilets so the queues are extremely long.

I will give an extra star because the shops and food choice are good.

Need a gigantic effort to improve. Not user friendly. For example, need to carry your big heavy luggage for customs X-Ray to scan. Luggage belt info display not clear and can never be turn to advertisement.
Large queues at immigration. Only 1 officer to cover it. Been standing for almost an hour with no end in sight.

Worst experience ever, took us more than 3 hours just to do migration, super slow system that generates eternal queues. Terrible customer service.
Avoid this airport for connecting flights!
late flight, digital arrival card app not working, smart arse immigration officers, arrogant taxi drivers took me to the wrong hotel, not a nice welcome to KL.

It is not acceptable that you cannot bring a water which you bought in duty free zone on the airport. Where is no possibility to use a toilet when you do the final check-in...

When my girlfriend entered the customs checkpoint, she was stuck in it for two hours before she came out. The staff of the Customs Bureau had a terrible service attitude and a smelly face, and they didn't help the passengers solve their questions. üò§

I have seen maybe 50 airports by now. And i remember from before and again how over complicated Kuala Lumpur airport is. Its so dumb. It makes you wonder. I know its the Indonesian and Malaysian way of doing things that dont make sense. Bad design. Feels like its addons and the you realize that its just how they do it. No logical thinking. I hope you can change staff and fix it. But i doubt it. Best of luck Malaysia. But its why i think maybe i will not be back for that last 5th time. Only place worse is Ho Chi Minh City.
I found this airport very confusing, intimidating, and unimpressive.

A truly one star experience here. The bus service is erratic and poorly organised between terminals- even to the ‚Äúbusiness class‚Äù experience it‚Äôs really bad. Expect to sit in a bus 15 minutes - faster if you take the economy class bus

I wonder why airport offers kiosk for check-in without self-drop baggage site for some airlines which means nothing. The queue at check-in counter is terribly long and time consuming. This is the worst experience in my life compared to previous experiences here at KLIA.

I came twice to this airport 2023. 2025 and in both  cases i faced the same bad situation , crowded area's, not orginized properly, not wide enough, and rude officers, the way they are treating people very bad, i think they enjoy seeing people like this ,hundreds of people all waiting for passport processing, asking people to fill information in last moment in other place, and they work slowly and sometimes leave their duty, looking in to their mobiles, they do not care for how long you will stay in the yard in front of them 2, 3 hours no problem, it seems the airport management used to see this  situation as normal, but they have to know this is not normal, this is a big failure and sort of chaos, the officers and those who are processing passport need a lot of training how to deal with people respectly and how to perform their job Professionaly, really it was bad experience

As of today, floor level 5 entrance smells so bad. Please do something about the smell.

Terrible traffic management upon arrival at customs area, and car traffic at pickup points. Ada RELA dgn orang jaga pun takde point, duduk berdiri mcm tunggul je.

The immigration staff at 2 a.m. this morning had a very bad attitude. The Malay woman had a brown body and was covered in thick powder. I was traveling from Bali to Kuala Lumpur for a three-day vacation when the staff suddenly started using rude and impolite language. I was just standing there with my Japanese husband. Because Indonesian and Japanese passports are handled differently, I couldn't see her face. Suddenly, she said, "You're rude! Why are you looking at me like that? You're rude." The female staff member with a Malay face said that. I said, "I've been quiet, not talking to you, and I haven't looked at you. Why are you coming to me? My face is like this. I've only been looking at my husband." When I get back from Malaysia, I'll take a picture of that immigration officer. He was on duty with a woman wearing a headscarf. It's really unethical to have Malay staff like that. Their attitude is very bad. Please, if you have problems at home, don't bring them to work.
The female staff member with an Indian face is friendlier than the Malay one.

For such a major international hub, the airport felt a little confusing and chaotic. We ran into the same issue two times - once on arrival (for transit) and once for departure.

During arrival we wanted to switch from C Gates to A/B gates for domestic departure but it was confusing to find the directions.

Exactly at the same location, during departure, we had to switch to C gates but got confused. We later realised that one of the sign boards is actually wrong. It points to an escalator upwards that goes into the shopping area. Whereas the C gates entry is exactly in the opposite direction of the sign. For an international airport this is not acceptable at all. I dont have photos, but getting confused at the same place two times is not right. We saw a few others get confused too.

Apart from that there is no major security check and body scan before immigration. However this is done prior to boarding. This is not as per standard processes elsewhere wherein the detailed security check and body scan is done immediately at entry.

Somehow disappointed with the airport.

Poor arrival experience. We had to do like 30 minutes walking with no clear signs. Chaotic and dark. There are also unnecessary queues for custom luggage checks, we've never seen that before. We expected better from such a city...

Careful about scammers that try to get money with a sob story from you about how they need to change their ticket. The police should maybe have a bit more an eye open.

Also, the signage of the place is horrible and confusing. It needs more directions to places like toilets (why women only and no men toilet is close by?).

Signs to lounges seem also missing. It's a modern pretty airport, but the details really are lacking.

It's a terrible airport, the employees behave so badly, you can't believe it, we entered Bali because we got an online visa from Bali and the stamp wasn't stamped when we exited, we had problems returning from Malaysia because the stamp wasn't stamped, even though we explained the situation, they made fun of us and laughed at us, made us wait for an hour and a half, when they finished making fun of us, they said okay you can go, I definitely don't recommend it
Unfriendly officer
It's hot, there's very little seating. The restrooms aren't very good either. Immigration lines are too long.
Charging socket / points are very limited..

Male immigration officers if we do not know or are confused are patient and immediately take action to inform. Unlike female immigration officers, they are very impolite, they talk a lot and shout but take no action. KLIA is so huge, the potential clinical coldness of the facility is cleverly softened with what appears to be an atrium of greenery.
The once state of the art facilities of this Airport is marred by the breakdown of the Aerotrain system that used to provide a world class service between the terminals.
The Aerotrain gates have been hidden behind dark but colourful hoarding. Opposite the hoarding are lines of waiting passengers queuing to enter the various B gates, together with their various hand carry items. With poor lighting due to the height of the dark colourd hoarding,  this creates a somewhat long dark narrow somber passage that arriving visitors to Malaysia must navigate to reach the escalators to the ground level and transfer bus terminal.
Any negative impressions arising from negotiating past the queuing passengers with unsettled infants and the ocassional unrestrained child darting into the crowd flow is further accentuated as one reaches the ground level and confronted by the multinational crowd chaos at the
Satellite Terminal bus transfer gate.
The airport employees manning the area do a great job in moving the crowd in arbitrary groups onto the waiting buses. Despite the apparent crowd chaos, these Malaysian employees at various informal "gates" manage to prevent a crowd surge and create controlled access on to the buses. These lowly front line employees are the true heroes in this situation and are living examples of the "Malaysia Boleh" can-do attitude.  It's such a pity senior Airport management doesn't display a similar level of commitment in getting the Aerotrain system fixed and creating a positive first impression for international arrivals to Malaysia.

The plane was delayed 10 hours, and then it was changed to the next morning's flight. If we want to leave tomorrow morning, no baggage is allowed in, he said it was an unwritten rule... Who knows, it's hilarious.

I am writing to provide feedback on my recent experience flying to KLIA via Singapore Airlines.

While I generally appreciate the quality of service on Singapore Airlines flights, was disappointed with the airport experience at KLIA, especially considering this was not a budget flight.

Upon arrival, after disembarking from the plane, we were directed by a staff member, who was shouting, to proceed to Cxx for a transfer to the arrival hall by bus.

Was thinking that perhaps our flight was scheduled to park in a ‚Äúfurther‚Äù lot due to multiple flights arriving around the same time,which requires us to do a short transit.
Personally, I wasn‚Äôt expecting to go through the hassle of having to transit from the plane to the arrival hall, taking into consideration that this was a direct flight.
Anyway, still went with the flow and follow those in front since we are told to....

This information could easily be missed if people are talking or focused on finding the nearest toilet.

Although the airport was large and packed with lots of shops and eateries, there are areas that could be improved to facilitate smoother transit for arriving/departure passengers.

‚ÄãWould suggest the following improvements:

* Rather than having a staff member shouting/giving instructions, ‚Äãcan consider placing clear, large signage on both sides of the walkway as passengers disembark.
* Provide more readily available information upon flight arrival‚Äã / departure.
* Consider adjusting the volume of the announcement speaker with loud and clear information in English, Chinese, and Malay.

Clear directional signs and information would make a big difference for first-time visitors like myself and would save a lot of time‚Äã especially when there are so many incoming/outgoing flights day to day.....

The signage for the bus transfer was unclear, and it took approximately 4-5 minutes to find the waiting point to queue for the feeder bus to the arrival hall.

Upon arriving at the arrival hall, it was another 2-minute walk to reach immigration. The area was extremely crowded, with queues of 2-3 lines in a row, resulting in an hour-long wait to clear immigration.

The process was very disorganized and messy, with no one managing the human traffic, possibly due to a shortage of manpower.
Although the officers were friendly and efficient in clearing the queue,
it would be beneficial to have crowd control/security to guide and manage the flow of passengers.

Locating the correct baggage belt after clearing immigration was another challenge. The area was crowded, and there were only three to four luggage belts, requiring passengers to walk near the belt to check the monitor screen.
This was frustrating, especially with different groups of people surrounding the area, some looking for directions, some waiting for friends, and others searching for the right belt.
We eventually found our luggage placed not far away from the luggage belt area near the exit, with a sign displaying the SQ Airlines logo on the floor.
Many unclaimed bags from our flight were present, as most passengers were still stuck in immigration.

The entire process, from disembarking the plane to retrieving our luggage outside the baggage claim area, was challenging.

I thought we were only required to transit to the arrival hall as a one-time occurrence. However, on our return flight, we were once again required to take a short bus to the departure hall.
Furthermore, there were no water dispensers available after passing through the inspection gate, which was inconvenient.

As a tourist, the airport gives the first impression for passengers, and its organization is crucial.

I hope this feedback will be taken into consideration for future improvements

Lousy airport and in horrible shambles

I had a deeply frustrating and disappointing experience at Kuala Lumpur Airport due to the unprofessionalism and rudeness of the staff. Upon arrival, I realized I had accidentally left my luggage in the restroom near the baggage claim. When I approached the information desk to ask for help, I received conflicting and unhelpful instructions. Some staff told me to go to the second floor, while others asked me to use an invalid boarding pass to re-enter security (which was impossible since my ticket was for a domestic flight from Kota Kinabalu).

I ended up running back and forth between the second and third floors more than ten times, but no one took responsibility or provided any real assistance. Desperate, I approached a female staff member at the exit to request her help in checking the restroom for my luggage. Not only was she extremely reluctant, but she also glared at me in a hostile manner. After being persuaded by her colleague, she finally went to check the restroom. Within less than a minute, she came back and coldly told me my luggage wasn‚Äôt there, claiming to have confirmed with the cleaning staff.

However, this was simply not possible. Two hours later, left with no other options, I asked a passenger who hadn‚Äôt exited yet to help me check the restroom. In just three minutes, they returned with my luggage.

This experience was utterly unacceptable. The staff‚Äôs lack of professionalism, unwillingness to help, and outright rudeness made an already stressful situation even worse. An airport should prioritize assisting passengers, not adding to their frustration. I hope the management will take serious steps to train their staff to ensure such incidents don‚Äôt happen again.

Unfortunately, my experience at Kuala Lumpur International Airport was disappointing. Here are a few points that struck me negatively:
1. Strict baggage control, but not consistent:
My hand luggage was accurately weighed, and even though it was only slightly over 7kg, I was told to pay extra. At the same time, the Malaysian woman in front of me, weighing almost 8 kg, was allowed to walk away - that felt unfair.
2. Poor Signage:
Some gates had no numbers, which was extremely confusing. It was difficult to find the right path.
3. Lack of seating:
There were no seats at the gate, which made the wait unnecessarily tiring.
4. Inadequate Toilets:
The women's restrooms were a mess - I waited in line for over 30 minutes and when it was finally my turn, they were dirty. The men apparently had enough toilets as there were no queues.
Last but not least, our flight was delayed.
Unfortunately, the airport was the worst I've ever been to.

At the Batik Air baggage counter in Kuala Lumpur before flight OD171 to Denpasar, I was shouted at, threatened, and pressured into paying a baggage fee of 650 MYR, with the amount changing several times without explanation. First it was more, then less, then suddenly 650 ‚Äì it was chaotic and clearly unprofessional.

The staff member at the baggage scale used aggressive language, raised their voice, and intimidated me in front of other passengers. I felt unsafe and coerced. This was not a normal excess baggage fee ‚Äì it felt like extortion. I complied because I felt I had no choice.

I strongly warn other travelers: If you‚Äôre flying from Kuala Lumpur with Batik Air, be cautious at the baggage counter. Keep records, film interactions, and don‚Äôt let yourself be bullied.

I had two layovers at KLIA. The first time, everything went well: the airport was clean, well-organized, and especially a well-appointed prayer room, which is really appreciated by Muslim travelers.

However, the second time was a completely different story, as if it weren't even the same place. As soon as you get off the plane, nothing is clear: there's almost no signage for baggage claim. It's easy to get lost, you don't know where to go. And then, surprise: you have to go through security and immigration before claiming your baggage. Completely illogical. At least let me collect my bag peacefully first!

Once you're through immigration, you arrive in a huge crowd, with no smooth flow of traffic. Then you have to go through security again to get out. You board, you get off, you take a bus, you change buildings... frankly, a real hassle.

Another point: the baggage counter agents are extremely strict, sometimes even abusive. If you weigh 5 kg more than you need, you pay, period, no flexibility.

The prayer rooms? They used to be clean, now they're dilapidated, not maintained. Really a shame.

Finally, I had a three-hour layover, I barely had time to navigate the obstacle course to get to my gate. And guess what? 40 minutes into the flight, our gate was changed from 35 to 4. Great.

And then, as a Muslim, I felt uneasy. For a country I considered a brother, I had never felt so foreign. Clearly, Asian passengers are given priority. Sad to say, but I felt a real form of nationalism.

In short, very disappointed. I didn't find the welcome I was hoping for in a country like Malaysia.

The information about departure is confusing and unfriendly. Staff obviously is skiving and acting busy and lack interest in helping. The reliance of shutter bus than sky train simply sum up the  experience.

Travel Tips for Kuala Lumpur: Save Money on Airport Transfers
Avoid Grab e-Hailing, Especially Advance Bookings

Grab drivers, particularly for advance bookings, may overcharge or provide subpar service. Instead, use Bolt for a more affordable and reliable ride.

Bypass Airport Surcharges with Trains
To avoid high airport ride-hailing fees, take the Express Rail Link (ERL) to Salak Tinggi station. From there, book a ride via Bolt for a significantly cheaper fare.

Steer Clear of Airport Taxis

Avoid taxis waiting at the airport, as they often charge exorbitant rates (RM300‚Äì400). Opt for e-hailing services like Bolt, where fares to Kuala Lumpur should not exceed RM80 for a standard car or RM50 for a 4-seater.
Know Your Rights with E-Hailing

With e-hailing apps, pay only the fare shown in the app. If a driver demands extra payment, record their details (name, car plate number, and interaction) and report it to the nearest police station. Such behavior violates fair practices and harms Malaysia‚Äôs reputation.

Pro Tip: Always book rides through trusted apps like Bolt for transparency and savings. Safe travels!
