I am writing to provide feedback on my recent experience flying to KLIA via Singapore Airlines.

While I generally appreciate the quality of service on Singapore Airlines flights, I was disappointed with the airport experience at KLIA, especially considering this was not a budget flight.

Although the airport was large and packed with lots of shops and eateries, there are areas that could be improved to facilitate smoother transit for arriving/departure passengers. Personally, I wasn‚Äôt expecting to go through the hassle of having to transit from the plane to the arrival hall, taking into consideration that this was a direct flight.

Upon arrival, after disembarking from the plane, we were directed by a staff member, who was shouting, to proceed to Cxx for a transfer to the arrival hall. This information could easily be missed if people are talking or focused on finding the nearest toilet. I tried to console myself, thinking that perhaps our flight was scheduled to park in a ‚Äúfurther‚Äù lot due to multiple flights arriving around the same time.‚Äã
Anyway, just go with the flow and follow those in front since we are told to ....

‚ÄãWould suggest the following improvements:

* Rather than having a staff member shout instructions, ‚Äã you can consider placing clear, large signage on both sides of the walkway as passengers disembark.
* Provide more readily available information upon flight arrival‚Äã / departure.
* Consider adjusting the volume of the announcement speaker with loud and clear information in English, Chinese, and Malay.

Clear directional signs and information would make a big difference for first-time visitors like myself and would save a lot of time‚Äã especially when you have so many incoming/outgoing flights day to day.....

The signage for the bus transfer was unclear, and it took approximately 4-5 minutes to find the waiting point to queue for the feeder bus to the arrival hall.

Upon arriving at the arrival hall, it was another 2-minute walk to reach immigration. The area was extremely crowded, with queues of 2-3 lines in a row, resulting in an hour-long wait to clear immigration.

The process was very disorganized and messy, with no one managing the human traffic, possibly due to a shortage of manpower.
Although the officers were friendly and efficient in clearing the queue, it would be beneficial to have crowd control/security to guide and manage the flow of passengers.

Locating the correct baggage belt after clearing immigration was another challenge. The area was crowded, and there were only three to four luggage belts, requiring passengers to walk near the belt to check the monitor screen.
This was frustrating, especially with different groups of people surrounding the area, some looking for directions, some waiting for friends, and others searching for the right belt.
We eventually found our luggage placed not far away from the luggage belt area near the exit, with a sign displaying the SQ Airlines logo on the floor. Many unclaimed bags from our flight were present, as most passengers were still stuck in immigration.

The entire process, from disembarking the plane to retrieving our luggage outside the baggage claim area, was challenging.

I thought we were only required to transit to the arrival hall as a one-time occurrence. However, on our return flight, we were once again required to take a short bus to the departure hall.
Furthermore, there were no water dispensers available after passing through the inspection gate, which was inconvenient.

As a tourist, the airport gives the first impression for passengers, and its organization is crucial.

I hope this feedback will be taken into consideration for future improvements

There's no Wi-Fi in the airport. You'll have to pay a lot for a drink in a restaurant to use the restaurant's Wi-Fi. This is very inconvenient when your layover lasts for hours.
The few electrical outlets available aren't international...
Be careful in the restrooms too. The water coming out of the taps has more pressure than a fire hose.
Security guard named Ahmad should be fired immediately for acting immature and just straight up yelling at everybody without knowing his manners. The rest of the airport is good though

Beware of Batik Airlines, who flys out of this airport. They are an absolute scam, and conduct predatory behavior at the gate. I was shaken down for nearly 600 dollars worth of fees. On a multi leg trip, I had 0 issues; then Batik found every single excuse they could to squeeze money from me, at the gate, at the checkin, and during the flight.

I honestly don't know how these people sleep at night with such predatory behavior, and I'm surprised a respectable airport like KUL allows them to run thier racket out of this airport. What a disgrace.

I‚Äôve traveled through KLIA countless times, and it has always impressed me with its cleanliness, smooth check-in process, and efficient security checks. The architecture, inspired by Malaysian, Islamic, and natural elements, remains a stunning highlight. But what truly made KLIA special was its balance of international and uniquely local offerings- something that now seems to be fading.

With the recent KLIA1 renovation, I have to give credit where it‚Äôs due‚Äîthe new bathrooms are a huge improvement! Well-designed, clean, and dry. But the retail and dining experience has taken a disappointing turn. Many local options have disappeared, replaced by foreign goods. And once again, alcohol and tobacco seem to dominate the retail space‚Äîwhy so much of it? I was shocked to find just one shelf of Malaysian food products in the entire terminal 1. Malaysia is a food paradise‚Äîwhy isn‚Äôt KLIA celebrating this? Instead, the vibrancy of local flavors is being replaced by the bland sameness of foreign caf√© chains, croissants, and cakes. More AUTHENTIC local options would be a delight!- especially for those leaving home and craving one last nasi lemak or kuey teow or teh tarik or curried roti?

Once, travelers could enjoy authentic Malaysian dishes like kaya toast, prawn noodles, and teh tarik. Now, the F&B scene is overrun by global chains like Starbucks and Gloria Jean‚Äôs. Surely, KLIA can do better by making space for homegrown eateries that showcase Malaysia‚Äôs rich culinary diversity?- take a page out of Jakarta or Singapore airport.

To add to the frustration, the monorail is still out of service (I‚Äôve lost count how long I‚Äôve waited), forcing travelers to rely on slow and inefficient shuttle buses. And when I asked an ‚ÄòAsk Me For Help‚Äô staff member for food recommendations, she barely looked up from her phone. Customer service should be better than this!

KLIA, let‚Äôs do better! Support local businesses and bring back the authentic Malaysian experience to travellers.

P.S. if you‚Äôre ever at the Satellite building of KLIA terminal 1, I highly recommend checking out the Jungle Boardwalk üòÑ I always look forward to visiting it if my Gate is located there. üå¥üå≥üå¥

"I don't speak Chinese"
That's what staff first come out
But how come I know English

Narrow, crowded and dimly lit departure hall. Due to inadequate seats, passengers either stand or sat on the floor. The hall is also lined with eatery shops, exacerbating the overcrowding as passengers queue up to order food. It‚Äôs a pity that so little thought is given to the design and flow of the airport even though malaysia is rich in resources and land space. The only saving grace is the kind and hardworking staff.

A large, modern, yet manageable airport.
Unfortunately, I have to give it only 3 stars because immigration and passport control took a very long time. After a 10-hour flight, queuing for another two hours at passport control is very, very tiring.
I should also mention that we had already queued for the aromatized immigration, and after about 20-30 minutes of waiting, we had to go to the other counter...
There were about 5 officers working for a few hundred people (processing time per passenger between 3 and 10 minutes).
I'm not used to this in Asian metropolises, and I wish the airport administration could come up with something here.
Clean and modern, but very poor signage and chaotic processes.  Security at boarding is a nightmare. Needs to do better given other airports in SEA do much better

The airport is huge. From Airline 1, you need to take a shuttle bus to Airline 2, but the bus goes incredibly fast and there are no handrails, so be careful.

We were stuck in the line with the human linemen when we went through customs, so we had to wait in the line again when we returned home. Unfortunately, the human linemen were incredibly slow and inattentive, so the wait was incredibly long. So, we had to go through the machine at customs.

It was also very crowded when we went inside to eat. I thought fast food would be faster, but the line at Burger King, ordering and picking up, can take an hour. It's not even fast food!? In the end, we didn't have time to eat and had to take it to go. There wasn't a single store in the airport that we could explore.

The inspection process here is also very unique. You can bring water through the first checkpoint, but you have to go through the X-ray machine again before boarding the plane. You can't bring water this time. You're directly on the plane. There's no place to fill up your water or use the vending machines. My throat was really sore before the in-flight meal arrived.

If you want to enjoy a leisurely stroll and eat, it's recommended to arrive 3-5 hours early. We arrived 3 hours early and were still in such a mess.

I‚Äôve travelled through many airports, and unfortunately, this one stood out for all the wrong reasons. The staff were generally rude and condescending, which made the experience unnecessarily stressful.

KLIA Main Terminal is definitely looking tired now. Arrivals process is laborious, through a dark Immigration area (with a long queue almost always) into a dingy baggage claim area. Then prepare to run the gauntlet of taxi hawkers. Toilets are filthy. Car rental area is in an even dirtier forgotten part of a car park, well away from the terminal. Horrendous and frightening journey for single females to negotiate to. At least LCCT has Car rental booths actually in the terminal at arrivals.

Update January 2023 and nothing has improved about KLIA 1.
The car rental office area is nothing short of a discusting, hot & humid, car fume filled enclosed area. Staffed by people who need to be motivated away from their phones to serve you.
That just completes the whole slow, painful experience of a dark and miserable KLIA and a sorry welcome to Malaysia.
A national disgrace that needs to be addressed from the miserable gate staff, immigration & customs officials, to the customer facing staff throughout.
Unfortunately people like myself have no choice but to suffer KLIA regularly.
SYSTEM DOWN .. COLLAPES ALREADY ..
Poor immigration and security check services. The officers don't want to work and don't bother about delays.
SYSTEM DOWN .. COLLAPES ALREADY ..
Joke priority lane

Absolutely unacceptable experience at Kuala Lumpur International Airport. More than 4 hours waiting at immigration ‚Äî no water, no access to toilets, no place to sit. Hundreds of tired travelers standing in line for hours. As a country that wants to attract tourism, this is shameful. Instead of enjoying Malaysia, we were stuck in an endless queue. Truly inhumane and disappointing.

Transit from terminal 1 to terminal 2 is very confusing
Also cashless policy brings a lot of inconvenience
Immigration is slow, the AC isn't cold, the room is smelly while waiting in line.
No enough seats or toilets

Terrible experience with staff at the xiamem airlines check in not understanding visa free policy even with business class and staff having no idea about where any shops are and being totally not understanding of people with asperges.

Be careful, not a modern airport, does not have normal security checks.
They scan bags at the entrance, then you happily buy overpriced liquids,
Then again a bag scan at the gate.
So you can throw away your overpriced liquids.
The transfer from Malaysia Airlines to ANA is in a different terminal and requires a bus. The sign was so big that it took me a while to notice.

Spacious airport with lots of shops but it is unacceptable and dangerous not to have the possibility of buying a bottle of water after going through security or access to a drinking fountain or toilet while waiting for the plane. You have to leave the platform to drink/go to the toilet, go through security again before returning. In addition, Etihad only provides a few mini glasses of water during its 7-hour flight, and there is no possibility of buying a bottle on the plane either. We were on a flight without air conditioning and without a bottle of water with the plane on the ground for 2 hours due to a technical problem followed by 7 hours of flight with only a few glasses of water to keep going. In other airports I was always able to buy a bottle after going through security.

Overall is just average. Two stars are off due to these 2 things. First one, transferring to satellite terminal which makes passenger so tired. Second one is for arrival, MDAC is kind of confusing. Perhaps, improvement to make things easier is better.

Absolutely useless passport control and rude custom officers who come to work late. First you wait 2 hours in the queue to find out you have had to complete a MDAC form and be turned back to the end of the queue and wait for another 2 hours.
30 people in front of me were turned back but the customs staff still didn't guess to make an announcement for the whole queue and just waited in the end of it to turn everyone back one by one. USELESS

Few seats/ places to sit/charge devices / activities for those transitioning to intl flights. Zero vegan food (only vegetarian options and most of them are not suitable for vegans, and the staff doesn‚Äôt understand what vegan is). At least they had plant milk for coffee but it‚Äôs expensive. The staff at security checkpoints doesn‚Äôt help with anything (not even ensuring the luggage line runs smoothly). It‚Äôs clean (except for some toilets) and but that‚Äôs about it.

Train breakdown to satellite building terminal.  Those travelling overseas be sure to go as early as possible to avoid jam at immigration counter and queue for bus to satellite building. MAB had not done so despite promising to deliver be end January
The gate is very small, there are only a few seats, this is the worst airport.

Unwelcoming staff who don't explain anything, you are left to your own devices without any explanation.
Few information signs.
Formalities that can be done in advance, without anyone telling you.
The country is literally to flee.
I have never seen such badly behaved people.
No politeness or kindness.
They only say thank you when it's a question of money.
Took so much time just to pass the immigration gate, took another much time just to leave the airport since you have to scan your bag again near the check out area.

A 2 hour waiting time at arrivals to go through immigration, people on wheelchairs and young children had to wait in this long line.
A half an hour waiting time for the toilet at departures.

Terminal 2 dont' need to take bus ( Scoot )
Terminal 1 has to take bus ( SIA )
Busses are a major quality drop. Confusing signage when entering T1. Now not anywhere near as good as Dubai, Changi (but still better than Bangkok) Needs TLC and investment.

Probably the worst airport I've ever visited...
We stood in line at immigration for over three hours, even though we'd filled out everything, so the E Gate should have been working.
Two LAZY officials were in charge of several hundred people, and they didn't even seem to care that we weren't wasting a single day there.
I've never experienced anything like this before, and I already want to fly home before I even enter the country.
One star is too much for this.

Good airport, reasonably clean and well maintained but the design of having a full security check for each gate makes things very difficult when a gate change occurs at the last moment. Furthermore, the waiting area past the security check has no restrooms either. If a flight is delayed, there could be no access to food, water or restrooms for a long time. Will avoid this airport as much as possible in the future.
An okay airport but the staff here at most stores is quite rude, unfriendly, and bothered by a customer. Especially at the chocolate shop.

Great airport with plenty of stores, but what I didn‚Äôt like is that the security check is located just before the gate. This means if you‚Äôre unaware and buy food or drinks to enjoy while waiting to board, you won‚Äôt be allowed to bring them (liquids) through the checkpoint.
All the main restaurants and caf√©s are before the 2nd security check. This is ridiculously user unfriendly. Airport is huge but not pretty. Very well connected though with the KLIA Express train

No vegetarian options in most places and no where served non-dairy milk options. This seems quite outdated to me considering how many people don‚Äôt eat meat or drink dairy. I am lactose intolerant.

You go through security once and think you‚Äôre good to go, so we bought food and water for the flight, as we were next to our gate. We then proceeded to enter our gate to be told we weren‚Äôt allowed water or food through. This was quite annoying considering we had just spent money on them and had already gone through the main security. We then entered the gate and realised there was no water given and no toilets. We had over an hour wait for a flight. I don‚Äôt understand the point of this?

They make you check in at one terminal only to have you board the plane at another. They make you throw away your bottle of water at the boarding gate and make you wait for over an hour before boarding the plane without access to water or toilets. A very uncomfortable situation.
Very inconvenient for senior citizens and children. Have to walk a long up and down zigzag corridor to reach immigration check point. There is undue delay at the

Security check at the very end. The final waiting room doesn't even have access to a toilet. I don't understand why they don't have the security check earlier like most other airports. You either have to wait bc you cannot open the sealed plastic bag with water or you have to throw it away after you opened it.

There are many things to improve at this airport.

There are twice as many security checks, passport checks, and boarding passes as at a Western airport. Just to give an example, the security process (where they check your water and all that) is right in front of the boarding gate.

This means that once you've passed through security, you can't buy anything, including the toilet, water, etc.

Aside from the inconvenience for travelers, it means underutilization of the machines for the airport, because they're only used when there's a flight at that gate, and fewer sales opportunities, because you're confined to that room for at least an hour and a half before the flight departs, waiting to actually board.

They have a lot to learn from their neighbors in Singapore, a little further south.

This airport made me never want to come back to Malaysia. Who designed this place?!

First, the walk from the plane to immigration and baggage claim was unbelievably long. I‚Äôve traveled through many large airports, but I‚Äôve never had to walk this much just to reach my luggage. I could overlook that‚Ä¶ but what came next was even worse.

After collecting our bags and passing immigration, we were forced to walk through (GET THIS!) A MALL to get to the exit. Yes, a literal mall where every airport in the world you'd be checking your transportation to finally leave. After a long flight, the last thing anyone wants is to be dragged through a maze of stores just to leave the airport. It felt like a cash grab, not a travel hub.

We finally made it out and were relieved to see Grab was available (we‚Äôre used to it from Thailand). But when we booked a ride, the wait time was 35 minutes! There was a huge, overcrowded Grab waiting area with screens showing incoming car plates, clearly, demand was way beyond what the airport could handle.

Tired and frustrated, we gave up on Grab, hoping to catch a bus instead. But we weren‚Äôt allowed to buy tickets until exactly 12 AM, which was also the listed departure time of the bus, "because it's too late now to buy tickets" (15 minutes ahead). We were told the bus would leave even after 12. The whole thing felt disorganized and unclear and the wait time seemed same as the Grab and the destination station is not even close to the hotel.

In the end, we paid almost triple the Grab fare to take a regular taxi, just to get the hell out of there.

Oh and did I mention that the airport wifi is not available once you finish immigration? I had such a hard time to book the Grab and check information and chat with my airbnb host because there was no wifi after immigration, because there's a freakin' mall between the airport and the exits!!!

This airport is a logistical mess and a terrible first impression of Malaysia. I've never thought an airport would affect my will to visit a country but here we are.

I'm giving it 1 star for the following reasons:
T1-> the security check only takes place immediately before boarding. This means that if you buy drinks before then (which you take with you on long-haul flights), you have to return them! Which is completely pointless! Furthermore, there's nothing to eat after baggage drop-off and passport control (which you want to get through as quickly as possible). Furthermore, there are no restrooms after the security check, so you'll wait about an hour for boarding plus a good 45 minutes until you're in the air to use a restroom... I've never seen anything like it, and I've been to many countries/continents.

This is one of the most confusing airports as it has many platforms and different gates & the distance between those gates are actually a bit long as you go by walking so that's why you must make sure to be on time at this airport otherwise you might miss your flight

Low efficiency. There is insufficient counter to deal with so many  travellers. And the planning is the quite weird that I hv to go through customs to check my belongings twice.
I was told at customs counter that I have to do self- order service to check out so I have to queue up again.becoz of these tedious process, I almost late for boarding

EU passport holder. Arrived 2:10 hours prior to flight and got hit with a massive queue for check-in that took 1 hour to pass. After barely passing at immigration their Passport gate didn‚Äôt work for me even though I am EU passport. Staff told me
It‚Äôs not their fault their system didn‚Äôt work and as I was going to miss my flight I rushed to the priority lane where I was not allowed to pass. Finally I found someone who gave me a number to call, where I had to pay 108 ringit as punishment for arriving 2:10 hours in advance for flight and to be able to catch my flight.
It's small, with not much to do. But it's well signposted.

This airport made me never want to come back to Malaysia. Who designed this place?!

I've never had this much hastle and wasted time to manage to exit an airport.

This airport is a logistical mess and a terrible first impression of Malaysia. I've never thought an airport would affect my will to visit a country but here we are.

Not even worthy of 1 star
Already booked a flight from JEDDAH to JAKARTA transiting to MALAYSIA with BUSINESS CLASS facilities but passengers were left to slump on the floor and wait for 4 hours, after waiting for 4 hours they were told the plane was full, Told to take the next flight! Already entered at gate C6 but told to re-check at gate C2! Those who should have gotten BUSINESS CLASS WERE MOVED TO ECONOMY! Very bad service, SOP IS NOT CLEAR, and OFFICERS are very unfriendly, when asked they always don't know the answer!
Toomuch crowd and complicated for first timer
Very good but very tight immigration for some counties unfortunately.

It ok but the a huge issue I saw we fly from Kuala Lumpur to Manila.  At the ticket counter there were only (4) points to check in your baggage. We waited close to 30 mins. Then you went through an immigration security check point.  You waited another 20 mins.

Then you were bused to an other building then you walked to the gate.  At the gate you went through another security checkpoint, where I had to drank my water I just purchased, removed my watch.  After this checkpoint I just wanted to charge my phone for the Grab ride back to the condo, could not bring water on the plane.

No restroom in that area after the checkpoint.

Very annoying!

There Airport look clean good Wi-Fi we found a place to eat on the way to the gate.  It‚Äôs seemed like there could be improvement on immigration they did have a full staff and the wait was to long.
Stupid designs and lazy officers
Spacious and clean airport but don't have water filter in waiting hall

The worst airport I have ever visited in my life. Although I have visited more than 30 airports around the world, this was the worst. The employees were absolutely rude, and the lines at passport control and inspection were very long. A very, very bad airport.

I'm writing bad review, on behalf of my younger brother who experience difficulty on this flight. He had to purchase new ticket because miss his flight, due to the tagging print took too long. And when he got there to check up his bag, they say the bag check up is already closed at 11:40. The tag done printing at 11:50. He's flight is at 14:20 I search up the airport check in for bag time said before 60 minutes of take off policy bag should be check in. Earlier the better, and pretty sure 11:50 is still consider early. And because of that his ticket burned and had to buy new ticket. This is ridiculous, bad service. Even other airport didn't have issue.
Charging Station is to slow, no water refill in waiting room
In line with the rest of Kuala Lumpur city planning: unstructured, unorganized, inefficient. What a sad sad place

Hi  Assalamualaikum &Good morning,
I believe to respective management Go Hub Airport Taxi.pls give briefing for the staff that working at KLIA 1 at level 3,working as a cashier and also marshall( two ladies) to be nice during handling passnger,the cashier take payment with a wrong destination that after made payment they are asking to add on money.By the way in  today morning they vr unprofessional and vr rude,Tq
After security checks, passengers do not have access to water.
Expect 3hr immigration lines ...

The worst airport! The staff are unhelpful and have no solution for the overcrowding. Their slow service made us miss two consecutive flights that were booked directly from the airport. By far the worst experience and the worst airport ever

Terminal 2, specially L black is wrost experience. I booked air asia flight and L section of terminal 2 looks like a 50 years old airport with high volume of crowd. Not enough seating area, even just one water vending machine was working and around 20 people was waiting in line to refill bottle. Really a cheapest experience of my life.

This airport is a disaster no empathy towards people they are clearly useless they are always talking to each other there is not even a clear sign to direct us. In short, this airport is very poorly done, it is the first and last time. Worst airport I've seen in my life and yet I'm done a lot.. My flight was delayed by 6 hours.. And I had to go around the airport for hours to get information I have the impression that even the workers do not know their airports and they are very unpleasant. And I didn't receive any attention. I was very furious!

One of the worst airports I‚Äôve ever experienced‚Äîand I‚Äôve travelled to 77 countries and over 100 cities.
‚Ä¢	Check-in and bag drop took 26 minutes, a process that‚Äôs often seamless or even unnecessary in many other countries.
‚Ä¢	The entire system is chaotic and disorganised. You‚Äôre sent back and forth between different check-in zones‚Äîfirst X, then V, then back again‚Äîwithout any clear guidance.
‚Ä¢	AirAsia was the absolute worst. The check-in staff were completely ignorant and clueless. I was forced to repack my bag or pay 2,000 MYR for just 0.3kg over the limit‚Äîno flexibility, no professionalism.

Avoid this airport if you can.

Free Shuttle bus KLIA1 to KLIA2 only drops off passengers at KLIA 2 outside the main road to Tune hotel. Drivers do not enter and drop off passengers at the designated stop. All passengers have to pull their luggage across the busy bus route on the way out and it is very inconvenient and very unprofessional. The incident occurred on 4/10/2025 at 6.50pm. Please be advised that free shuttle bus drivers should be warned to drop off passengers at the designated place. Please be informed. Tqvm Malaysia Airport Berhad.

Unarguably the most flaws design airport. Even India's small airport like Rajahmundry have better flow than this airport.

The don't have toilet inside the boarding gate. We have to back and forth to go to toilet and scan boarding pass.

I already told the imbecile staff that it's no need to do that. He tried to scanned it again and the light go red (stated already board). Even though he already do something wrong, he did the same mistake to my son behind me. What a waste a time and energy. Imbecile.
Very crowded, was fine

Edit: upon arrival as of June 2025, they removed auto entry now for foreign passports and only locals can go through them- what a waste of automated gates!

KLIA is a massive airport, but as of December 2024, it‚Äôs still undergoing some upgrading works, so not everything is fully operational (has been going on for the past year). Shops and dining options are still quite limited despite the airport's large size, which is a bit disappointing for travelers looking to explore or relax before their flights.

On the positive side, for certain passport holders, the biometric scanning at immigration makes the process quick and efficient, which is a welcome convenience. However, the baggage scanning process remains tedious‚Äîyou‚Äôre required to scan your bags multiple times, such as when entering immigration and again when heading to your gate. Personally, this feels unnecessarily repetitive, but there‚Äôs little travelers can do about it.

Overall, KLIA has potential, and hopefully, the ongoing upgrades will bring noticeable improvements to both the facilities and passenger experience in the near future.

Merryhhhhhhh with people who want to travel to see His greatness üõ´

People now travel by plane like they take a bus. There are so many people üî•

Last night I had to queue up because the flight was full and people arrived at the same time
Nice airport but a lot of rush.

Some staff are professional , some are not. Arrival bus transportation from the aircraft to arrival hall is efficient, I think it‚Äôs an above average airport. On arrival deck, airport Pickup lanes are a bit chaos though
Spacious.couldn‚Äôt see much as we reached by 3am and was pretty dark. But found something nice.

The toilet and seats were superb but there were no restaurants in the domestic departure only five were on the map but the some restaurants were never there. Overall I would give 5 to the atmosphere. üëç
The airport is clean and well marked. I don't understand why the security check is only at the entrance to the plane - they will even take away the water you bought in the "duty-free" zone
The procedures are slow and the employees don't know how to smile. What a beautiful country where passport and airport employees greet you with a smile.

I spent two hours in the immigration queue; if you only have one day to travel to Kuala Lumpur, that would consume 10% of your vacation time, not including transportation to the city.  Kuala Lumpur's immigration process makes Ho Chi Minh City's seem quite pleasant.
Neat and clean Airport but duty free is expensive as compared to Mumbai airport, no offers, difficult to find vegetarian food options.

Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) in Malaysia is a major aviation hub known for its modern infrastructure and significant passenger capacity. It features two main terminals: KLIA1 (Main Terminal) for full-service airlines and KLIA2, which is the world‚Äôs largest terminal dedicated to low-cost carriers. Both terminals provide extensive amenities such as check-in counters, retail outlets, duty-free shops, lounges, and a range of dining options.
Despite its impressive size and facilities, passenger experiences at KLIA show a mixed picture. Some travelers appreciate the airport‚Äôs efficiency, particularly with business class services that offer quick access to lounges and smooth security checks. The connectivity is good, with efficient transportation options like the KLIA Ekspres train linking the airport to Kuala Lumpur city center in under 30 minutes, plus taxis and buses are readily available.
However, there are notable complaints that affect the overall impression. Passengers frequently cite poor staff behavior, long queues, and confusion during boarding and baggage checks, often describing staff as unfriendly or inattentive. Some criticize the immigration process, mentioning inconvenient requirements and poor assistance, especially for transit passengers. Food and beverage options, particularly in KLIA2, have received negative reviews for being limited, expensive, or insufficient for the passenger volume. Seating areas can be inadequate during peak times, and the indoor climate control sometimes falls short, making waiting uncomfortable.
In terms of infrastructure, KLIA offers modern and clean facilities, with well-organized terminals and a spacious layout. The addition of automated train systems within KLIA1 and a skybridge in KLIA2 has improved passenger movement. The airport continues to be recognized for service quality by industry bodies, but in practice, staff performance and customer service remain areas needing improvement.
Overall, KLIA is a modern and strategically important airport that provides extensive amenities and connectivity but is let down by inconsistent service quality and operational challenges that impact traveler satisfaction.Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) in Malaysia is a major and modern airport serving millions yearly, with two main terminals: KLIA1 for full-service airlines and KLIA2 dedicated to budget carriers. Both terminals feature extensive amenities including retail outlets, duty-free shops, lounges, and various dining options, supported by advanced infrastructure like automated trains and skybridges for smooth passenger transfers.
While the airport excels in its size, facilities, and connectivity‚Äîoffering quick transportation options like the KLIA Ekspres train to Kuala Lumpur‚Äîit has garnered mixed overall reviews from travelers. Many praise KLIA1 for efficient and smooth security and boarding processes, especially for business class passengers. However, there are widespread complaints about staff attitude, with reports of unfriendly and inattentive personnel, chaotic queues, and confusing procedures that dampen the experience.
Other common issues include limited food and beverage options, especially in KLIA2, overcrowded seating areas, and inconsistent indoor climate control, making waiting uncomfortable during peak times. Some travelers also find the immigration and transfer processes cumbersome, with poor assistance and odd paperwork requirements for transit passengers.
Despite these challenges, KLIA maintains a clean and modern terminal environment with generally well-maintained facilities. It has received industry awards for its infrastructure and immigration service, but passenger experiences suggest that improving customer service and operational management is needed to match the airport‚Äôs world-class status.
In summary, KLIA offers comprehensive facilities and good connectivity as Malaysia‚Äôs primary international gateway but is hampered by service inconsistencies and operational issues that impact passenger satisfaction.

I used Terminal 2 (KLIA2), which is mainly used by low-cost carriers.
There are many restaurants just outside the arrival gate, and many of them are open 24 hours a day, which is very convenient. There are many seats where you can charge your phones, and some stores have Wi-Fi.
The food court a little further back to the left of the arrival gate has very cheap prices.
The supermarket called JayaGROCER is also cheap.

When you arrive, you can get to the city center by taking the KLIA Express, a limited express train, which is cheap and fast. However, there are restrictions on departure times, so if you want to get around easily, you should use the car dispatch service "Grab" or a taxi.
The cheapest option is by far the bus.

There is a luxurious lounge that accepts Priority Pass (3-hour system) at the back of LEVEL3, where the boarding gate is located, to the left.
I saw a few people sleeping on the ground on the boarding gate floor at night.

However, the downside is that it is a very long walk to the boarding gate.
After the initial simple baggage inspection, it takes about 20 minutes to walk to the gate.

KLIA is a massive airport, but as of December 2024, it‚Äôs still undergoing some upgrading works, so not everything is fully operational (has been going on for the past year). Shops and dining options are still quite limited despite the airport's large size, which is a bit disappointing for travelers looking to explore or relax before their flights.

On the positive side, for certain passport holders, the biometric scanning at immigration makes the process quick and efficient, which is a welcome convenience. However, the baggage scanning process remains tedious‚Äîyou‚Äôre required to scan your bags multiple times, such as when entering immigration and again when heading to your gate. Personally, this feels unnecessarily repetitive, but there‚Äôs little travelers can do about it.

Overall, KLIA has potential, and hopefully, the ongoing upgrades will bring noticeable improvements to both the facilities and passenger experience in the near future.

Kuala Lumpur International Airport, also known as KLIA. In addition to the main airport building, there's a separate, cross-shaped airport building for arrivals and boarding. If you use this building for departures and arrivals, you'll need to take the free shuttle train for immigration and boarding. For Koreans, this system is similar to Incheon International Airport. You can purchase and board the KLIA Express, a popular option for travel into Kuala Lumpur. Be sure to prepare your MDAC (Malaysian Declaration of Arrival) in advance. The facilities are clean and there are plenty of duty-free shops.

It is the largest airport in Malaysia and one of the busiest airports in Asia. The airport was built at a cost of up to 3.5 billion USD and was inaugurated on June 27, 1998.

Japanese architect Kisho Kurokawa designed this airport. The airport is 50 km from the capital Kuala Lumpur. In 2009, this airport served 29.6 million passengers (lower than the expected 35 million passengers). This airport has a 130 m high air traffic control tower, the second highest among air traffic control towers (only after the tower at Suvarnabhumi International Airport in Bangkok) with 2 runways 60 m wide and more than 4,000 m long, capable of serving 120 flights/hour.

According to the plan, this airport will have 4 runways. Terminal capacity in phase 2 to 2012 is 35 million passengers/year and in phase 2 to 2012 is 45 million passengers/year.

The airport is very large. Arrivals on a Tuesday evening were relatively smooth. Famous restaurants like Hua Yang and Hai Jiao Ren are located at the airport. I highly recommend checking them out first, as the lines at restaurants downtown are incredibly long. Departures on Saturday morning were a bit more chaotic, with incredibly crowded people and numerous check-in counters. They weren't divided by flight. From previous travel experience, children can't check in at the check-in counter. So, initially, we kept looking for a human check-in counter. We asked three staff members, each with a different explanation. This wasted a lot of time. It just so happened that our flight was delayed by an hour, otherwise we might have missed it. The restaurant in the airport lobby was incredibly crowded. After finally getting a table, it took another 30 minutes. We later discovered there were still many shops and restaurants after customs. Furthermore, baggage screening at customs required two checks, and the distance from customs to the boarding gate was quite long. On the way back, I recommend exploring and eating at the gate. You don't have to crowd the outermost area; the restaurants inside are just like the airport lobby. Best of all, they were less crowded, allowing you to leisurely wait for your flight. We had some fast food recommended by a local. The cola looked like root beer, served from a machine that looked like draft beer. It was quite interesting. The pancakes were surprisingly delicious‚Äîlarge, crispy, and generously prepared.
Take level 1 ,cheap & fast. Take premium only 100plus

KLIA is a decent and well-maintained airport, with clear signages and good connectivity to the city via the KLIA Express. The airport offers a range of facilities, shopping, and dining options, and generally handles immigration and security procedures efficiently.

However, compared to airports like Singapore‚Äôs Changi, I find KLIA lacks a certain warmth and polish. The overall design feels a bit dated, and some areas can be quite empty or underwhelming in terms of atmosphere. While functional, it doesn‚Äôt offer the same level of comfort, innovation, or world-class amenities that Changi is known for.

Still, for travel in and out of Malaysia, KLIA does its job well. It‚Äôs just not my favorite airport in the region.

The airport is clean. When you get off at Terminal 1, follow the arrivals signs and continue walking until you reach the terminal where you must take the elevator. You must take the elevator to get to the main terminal. There are many duty-free shops nearby. It might seem strange because it's different from Korea, but don't worry. Just keep going straight and take the elevator. Once you get off, go straight for a bit and then descend to the basement. You'll need to go down to the arrivals hall. The problem here is that the wait for immigration can sometimes exceed an hour. The line for complete immigration is incredibly long. You'll need to pass through here to collect your luggage and exit. It can be a little confusing, but just remember that you have to take the elevator, walk a bit, and then descend to the basement. Have a nice trip.

Edit: upon arrival as of June 2025, they removed auto entry now for foreign passports and only locals can go through them- what a waste of automated gates!

KLIA is a massive airport, but as of December 2024, it‚Äôs still undergoing some upgrading works, so not everything is fully operational (has been going on for the past year). Shops and dining options are still quite limited despite the airport's large size, which is a bit disappointing for travelers looking to explore or relax before their flights.

On the positive side, for certain passport holders, the biometric scanning at immigration makes the process quick and efficient, which is a welcome convenience. However, the baggage scanning process remains tedious‚Äîyou‚Äôre required to scan your bags multiple times, such as when entering immigration and again when heading to your gate. Personally, this feels unnecessarily repetitive, but there‚Äôs little travelers can do about it.

Overall, KLIA has potential, and hopefully, the ongoing upgrades will bring noticeable improvements to both the facilities and passenger experience in the near future.

Information for Turkish friends: After disembarking on August 7, 2025, it took us about an hour to get to the Grapla hotel. These procedures include going through passport control, collecting luggage, converting money, and going to Gate 5 on the lowest floor. When you arrive, you first fill out a form using a QR code. This information is sent to your email address. Then, when you go through passport control, you fill it out and you enter the country without any problems. I recommend getting training before you arrive. The airport's Wi-Fi works very well. It's very easy to get to the Grapla city center or your hotel. It's not very practical to exchange money at the airport. You can exchange $20 if you have a small amount of cash with you. Grapla is level 1, door 5.
If you‚Äôre transferring from Gates H to Gates C for a connection, you need to take a bus! Even though it‚Äôs the same terminal. Other than that it‚Äôs good!

Passport autogate supports 65 countries so check on the internet if yours is included, indications there are not correcr, to avoid the queues.
Luggage arrived immediately. After getting out at the far left luggage storage starting at 17 Myr/4usd per day. Take elevator go on 1st floor (down) and catch express train for city at 55myr/12usd. Make sure you go into the right direction cause it's tricky

The time was May 28th last year, I arrived at the airport at 3 am, but the problem was that when I left the airport, 36 hours had passed. The experience I had that day in the crowd of thousands of people was beyond words, but the atmosphere at the airport was very beautiful.
Developing to a certain level. The shops accept only Malaysian money. There are places to change money.

OK lah airport. Immigration has very long lines especially during afternoon and evenings. Early Morning flights have a short immigration line only. The Gates are Superb though! Especially the C Gates (Satellite Terminal)! Overall Decent Airport.

Expensive..
Good for a 2 Day tour..

Transit and everything was good. However, please train your female  "police". They gave a really rude and lazy attitude, and most of them weren't even helping. They were on their phones. Please hire someone that doesn't look like they were forced to be here. At least the male police were strict firm polite and know what their job is to do. I am not being s3xist but this is just an improvment for the security area.
Transit 3 hours, quite a walk from end to end

Hello, on May 23, 2025, Miss Sofea Ainul, who works at the Malaysia Airlines Lounge, met me at the airport to give her some duty-free products and some USD for her.
This person used her badges to access the airport while she was not working.
I was surprised and concerned to facilitate her entry to the airport while she was off duty.
There is a problem with badge checks for airport staff.
I would like to report this for the safety of the airport and travelers.
Have a good day, Dr. Taleb Ahmed.
superlong queue to access departures just to weight your luggage. Very unrespectful
It's airport inside a mall.
It‚Äôs a pretty ice airport . There is a little rainforest inside of the airport.
Seems less organized and is chaotic for both transfers and departures. The arrivals is a different experience though. There's a lot of stores where you could do some shopping.

Very nice airport with a great viewing area.
Plenty of food places and the souvenir shops sold items at good prices. They were of course higher than at shops, but for an airport, they were good.
The baggage drop for British airways took a very long time. If flying with Malaysian airways and some other Asian airlines, there was practically no queue as it was self service.
Then there was immigration, which opened up to more shops. After immigration, the bags were kind of scanned, but this wasn't security. This then opens up to more shops and restaurants. Only 1 out of the 4 water fountains worked at this point and the water was only for consumption in this area, because you then pass through security when the gate opens. After security, there are just seats. No water and no toilets.
I found there to be a lot of walking around to the next point, but there many shops making it a good experience

Wasn't really my cup of tea but more than adequate. Not sure why people are complaining though - not every airport is 5 stars. The terminals are split between buildings but at least the transfer buses are always available and the distance is short.

There is ample lighting in the terminals and the areas that are dim are perfect for sleeping in.

Gates are clearly signposted and the amount of walking is not too challenging.

Not a lot to do here as shop selections are really minimal. Interestingly, KL was the place to shop back in the 1980s. Not sure what happened over the years but I'm suspecting the main flow of passengers transit through the Middle East (eg Dubai).

The only irritating thing I found was unruly children banging on the piano in terminal C. 1 star for the parents!
I think it's pretty good, but there are too few people eating out in Building 1. Building 2 has more

The departure terminal has a rather traditional design with no distinctive boarding gate experience and a limited number of stores, although prices are reasonable for an international airport.
It‚Äôs best to check in and drop off your luggage, then take some time to walk around or enjoy shopping before proceeding to immigration.
Everything is good except the emigration process
Big and beautiful, it is considered good, but there is congestion when stamping the passport, whether entering or exiting. If you return, I advise arriving early due to the traffic congestion.
Fairly efficient airport. The train service between mail building and satellites still closed for repairs; the busses used instead are not so good and hard to board.

Thank you to SYUKRI at international departure customs immigration counter who helped me join my 2 small children and husband when my passport didn‚Äôt scan.
Very Rude service from business departure customs immigration. He only wanted to stamp business class people passport even though no business class customers there. One boy asked me to leave my small children and go to counter 47. There is no counter 47! SYUKRI at counter 37 helped me. Thank you!
Just had staying of my flight

1. The structure is unique.

2. The structure where entry and exit meet at the duty-free shop.

3. Because of this, security checks are done in front of the gate.

4. The duty-free shop sells various things, but there is no price merit.

5. There are many cafes such as Starbucks and Coffee Bean and places to eat light meals.

6. There is a smoking room near C31 in Terminal 1. It is very poorly ventilated.

7. The smoking room in C11 is less crowded and more comfortable.

So first of all: the airport is big!!!
The usual recommendation to be at the airport at least 3 hours before departure should be strictly adhered to.

There are multiple floors and the terminal with Gates C is outside and requires an additional bus ride.

Positive: There is a large selection of warm food and drinks in the Arrival Hall early in the morning.

The Departure Hall is on the top floor and is very cluttered and full of people.
It's important to stay calm and ask for the airline at the information counter.
The signage at the counters is small and you would have to look through all of them until you find the right one. (If you fly with Etihad Airways... it's counter A.)

It's best to check in online... it saves time. There were initially only a few counters open and some passengers had a lot of suitcases that were all weighed and labeled. The same thing happens with hand luggage.

As soon as you have got rid of your checked baggage, it is best to go to immigration without hesitation and then you can stand in line again.

Then you go through the first check where only hand luggage is checked. Positive: This happened very quickly.

Anyone who has one of Gates C on their boarding pass now goes to the bus transfer.
Short queues, even shorter bus ride.

Arrived at Gate C, last chance to go to the toilet or get something to drink.

Then stand in line at the security checkpoint. But it goes quite quickly even if there are a lot of people waiting in line.
Negative: Arriving passengers have to go through those waiting when they get off the plane.

You wait for boarding in a cool but relatively comfortable environment without a toilet or the opportunity to buy something to drink or eat.

Addendum to entry: Arrive at Gate C, then take the bus to the main terminal with little delay. Immigration went very quickly, but there was nothing going on in the morning. However, the wait for the luggage took longer again. In the Arrival Hall there are clean toilets, ATMs, food including Burger King and various options to buy a Malaysian SIM card that is really worth the money.

Arrival and departure airport - KL Sentral quickly and without pro
It's airport inside a mall.

KLIA 1 Airport is quite big and beautiful, but the design is a bit old-fashioned. I got Gate C for International Departures and had to take another bus to get there because this airport is so big. Luckily the road signs are quite clear, and the bus also comes quickly. It's just a bit risky if you want to arrive close to the departure schedule. The rules at this airport are quite strict, especially in carrying liquids which must be less than 100 ml, when it comes to baggage, I observed that it was safe, there were no significant problems.
All good except route signs are confusing.
Country is great. But the IMMIGRATION too damn slow. Its not so crowded yet need to queue for about 60 mins.

KLIA has room for improvement in several areas. The air conditioning was not cold enough, making the airport feel quite stuffy. The water dispensers were not functioning, which was inconvenient for travelers looking to refill their bottles.

Signage is another major issue, particularly for McDonald's. While there's a visible kiosk near Jamie Oliver, the other McDonald's outlet is poorly marked and easy to miss, hidden behind people and lacking clear directions. The KFC location is also not well-indicated, making it difficult for first-time visitors to find.

On a positive note, the toilet cleanliness is commendable. The cleaning staff are diligent, ensuring the facilities are spotless after each use. This level of hygiene is definitely appreciated and sets a good standard for airport maintenance.

Great airport. Very clean, many toilet already refurbish. Most of the process are automated with less human interaction after the pandemic era. One thing that can improve is it's will be better if airport management provide more seating area.

Update: I think it's the time to expand the airport. Very crowded especially in the early morning.

The staff was consistently unfriendly‚Äîfrom check-in to security personnel. Security measures were minimal, making me feel unsafe due to the lack of thorough screening. On the way to the gates, only cursory checks were conducted, and there was another, equally minimal, check at the gates. I was glad to be able to leave the airport.

Disappointed with KLIA1‚Äôs Renovation ‚Äì Where‚Äôs the Local Flavor?

I‚Äôve traveled through KLIA countless times over the years, and it has always impressed me with its cleanliness, easy check-in process, and efficient security checks. The architecture, influenced by Malaysian, Islamic, and natural elements, is a highlight. But what made KLIA truly special was the presence of local food, beverages, and products.

With the recent renovation of KLIA1, I have to say I am very pleased with the new improved bathrooms- better designed, clean and dry :) But I‚Äôve noticed a disappointing shift‚Äîmany local offerings have been replaced by foreign goods, with alcohol and tobacco dominating the retail space. I was shocked to find only one shelf of Malaysian food products in the entire terminal! Malaysia is a foodie paradise with so much to offer- why isn‚Äôt KLIA showcasing it?

Previously, there were great local caf√©s serving authentic Malaysian dishes like prawn noodles and teh tarik. Now, all I see are global chains like Starbucks and Gloria Jean‚Äôs. Can‚Äôt there be more homegrown F&B options for travelers to experience real Malaysian flavors?

To top it off, the monorail is still not working (shuttle busses are the alternate) and my  attempt to ask an ‚ÄòAsk Me For Help‚Äô staff member about food options was met with disinterest‚Äîshe was too busy scrolling on her phone to assist me properly. KLIA, we can do better! Support local businesses and bring back the Malaysian experience!
Good airport but still a lot of improvement can be done by adding more facilities

Malaysia will celebrate Merdeka Day at the end of August 2025. The airspace around KLIA (Kuala Lumpur International Airport) will be temporarily closed from 8:00 AM to 12:00 PM daily from August 26th to 31st.

Flights departing or arriving during this period may be adjusted! ‚ö†Ô∏è
To this end, Malaysia Airlines has announced on its website that departure and arrival times for certain flights will be adjusted. For details on affected flights, please visit their website; I've only captured a partial screenshot! I think other airlines will be affected to some extent, so please check in advanceüí™

Malaysia will celebrate Merdeka's Independence Day at the end of August, and the airspace around KLIA (Kuala Lumpur International Airport) will be temporarily closed from 8 am to 12 noon every day from 8.26 to 8.31. The small partners who leave/arrive during this time, the flight may be adjusted! To this end, Malaysia Airlines has indicated in official website that the departure and arrival times of the corresponding flights will be adjusted. You can go to their official website to check the specific flight tips, and I only took a partial screenshot! ! ! I think other airlines will be affected to some extent. Please confirm in advance.

For Arrival: Singapore Airlines, from Singapore, arrived at Gate C.
Gate C zone -> Aerotrain every 10 minutes (~ 4-5 staff there) to Immigration counter/ Gate ABGH ->
Many long queues for foreign passport holder, and prepare MDAC (Malaysia Digital Arrival Card) -> Luggage claim-> simple luggage X-rays Check -> leave Airport restricted area -> buy SIM cards / money exchange  -> transportation.

For Departure: Singapore Airlines to Singapore. Immigration e-channel or Counters (special Counter for business/first class) -> security check -> Aerotrain to Gate C -> (Lounge/ Eat/shopping) -> security check to enter the assigned boarding gate.

Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) is more than just a travel hub ‚Äî it‚Äôs a complete experience that blends efficiency, comfort, and a touch of Malaysian hospitality. From the moment you arrive, the design of the airport stands out. The main terminal building is bright, spacious, and airy, with a modern architectural style that still feels warm and welcoming. The satellite building, connected by the Aerotrain, adds to the sense of scale and convenience, making it easy for passengers to transfer between terminals.

In terms of navigation, KLIA is well signposted, with clear directions in English and Malay. Even for first-time visitors, it‚Äôs relatively simple to find immigration, baggage claim, and onward connections. While the airport is large, the layout is intuitive, and staff members are friendly and ready to assist if you ever feel lost. Immigration and security checks are usually smooth and efficient, although during peak travel hours there can be queues ‚Äî nothing unusual for an airport of this size.

The facilities here are excellent. There is a wide variety of food and drink options catering to every budget, from local Malaysian dishes (which I highly recommend if you have time) to international fast food, coffee shops, and sit-down restaurants. Shopping is also a highlight ‚Äî the duty-free selection is extensive, with everything from cosmetics and electronics to Malaysian souvenirs and delicacies.

If you‚Äôre in transit or have a long layover, KLIA makes the wait comfortable. There are plenty of lounges, seating areas, and even a capsule hotel where you can book a few hours of rest. The airport also has prayer rooms, child-friendly facilities, and smoking zones, which shows that it caters thoughtfully to different types of travelers. Free Wi-Fi is available, though it can sometimes be a little slow, so it‚Äôs good to have mobile data as backup.

Getting to and from the airport is extremely convenient. The KLIA Ekspres train is one of the best features ‚Äî it takes just under 30 minutes to reach KL Sentral in the city center, and it‚Äôs fast, comfortable, and reliable. Taxis and ride-hailing services are also widely available, and buses provide budget-friendly options.

One thing to keep in mind is that the airport is quite large, so be prepared to walk a fair bit between gates or from security to boarding. For some travelers, this can be tiring, but the clear signage and moving walkways help a lot.

Overall, KLIA is a world-class airport that balances efficiency with comfort. It‚Äôs clean, modern, and well-maintained, but it also has a distinct cultural touch that reminds you you‚Äôre in Malaysia. Whether you‚Äôre arriving, departing, or transiting, KLIA leaves a positive impression and sets the tone for a great journey.

I am extremely grateful for their outstanding service and support. Thank you to the amazing team at KLIA for ensuring such a smooth and reassuring experience!

Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KUL) is a major international airport serving Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. Here are some key points about the airport:

Airport Information
- *Location:* Kuala Lumpur International Airport is located about 45 kilometers south of Kuala Lumpur city center.
- *Terminals:* The airport has multiple terminals, including Terminal 1, Terminal 2, and the KLIA2 terminal for low-cost carriers.

Amenities and Services
- *Dining:* The airport offers a wide range of dining options, including restaurants, cafes, and snack bars.
- *Shopping:* There are various shops selling duty-free products, souvenirs, and other items.
- *Currency Exchange:* Currency exchange services are available at the airport.
- *Transportation:* The airport offers various transportation options, including taxis, buses, trains, and car rentals.

Airlines and Destinations
- *Malaysia Airlines:* Kuala Lumpur International Airport is the hub for Malaysia Airlines.
- *International Flights:* The airport offers flights to various international destinations in Asia, Europe, the Middle East, and Oceania.

Tips for Travelers
- *Plan Ahead:* Arrive at the airport with plenty of time to spare before your flight.
- *Check Flight Status:* Check the status of your flight before heading to the airport.
- *Know the Airport Layout:* Familiarize yourself with the airport's layout to make the most of your time.

üá™üá∏‚ô•Ô∏èüá≤üáæ A seamless experience at KLIA, one of the best airports in Southeast Asia‚ô•Ô∏è

Traveling through Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) is always comfortable and efficient. From the moment you arrive, you're greeted by a modern, clean, and well-organized facility, where it's clear that passenger comfort and overall smooth operation are a priority. ü§ûüèª

Passport control is very streamlined, especially if you're eligible to use the automated e-gates (it's worth checking if your passport is listed). The entire process is quick and hassle-free, which is a great start to any international trip. üëçüèª

Once you clear immigration, the airport is spacious and very well-maintained. The gates for Area C are easily reached via a regular shuttle train that departs after passport control. Everything is well signposted and easy to navigate.

There are tons of options for both shopping and dining, so you'll never feel bored while you wait. From duty-free shops to local and international restaurants, there's plenty to discover before boarding.

A helpful tip: KLIA is approximately 45 minutes from downtown Kuala Lumpur (KLCC) if you travel early in the morning when there's no traffic. During the day, it's a good idea to allow between one and one hour and ten minutes, depending on congestion.

We traveled from Terminal 1, which serves many major international airlines such as Etihad (A), Emirates (B), Turkish Airlines (M), and several others. It's advisable to check your gate assignment in advance, as it can change shortly before departure!

We had the opportunity to try Illy coffee near Gate C13. Although there was quite a line, service was quick once the order was placed. The staff was friendly and helpful. However, the coffee left something to be desired. The Americano and cappuccino had a strange taste, somewhat resembling burnt marshmallows. Still, the sourdough bakery selection was quite good, with fresh and satisfying options for pre-flight snacks.

Overall, KLIA is an excellent international hub. Clean, efficient, and well-thought-out. If they improve the coffee quality a bit in some areas, it would be near perfect. Still, I would definitely transit or depart from KLIA again. Highly recommended for both frequent travelers and first-time flyers.

üá¨üáß Smooth Experience at KLIA - One of Southeast Asia's Best Airports!

Traveling through Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) is always a comfortable and efficient experience. From the moment you arrive, you're met with a clean, modern, and well-organized facility that clearly prioritizes both passenger comfort and operational efficiency. ‚ô•Ô∏è

Passport control is a breeze, especially if you're eligible to use the automated e-gates (check if your passport is listed beforehand). The process is quick and fuss-free... a great start to any international journeyü•∞

Once you pass immigration, you'll find the airport impressively spacious and well-maintained. The departure gates at Concourse C are accessible by a smooth and regular train shuttle after passport control; very simple with clear signage throughoutüëçüèª

Retail and dining options are abundant, so you'll never feel bored during your wait. From duty-free shops to local and international eateries, there's plenty to explore while waiting for your flight.

A small note on timing ‚õàÔ∏è KLIA is located around 45 minutes from KLCC (city centre) early in the morning when traffic is light. However, during daytime hours, I recommend allowing at least 1 hour to 1 hour 10 minutes for the journey, depending on traffic conditions!!!

We flew out of Terminal 1, which handles many major international carriers including Etihad (A), Emirates (B), Turkish Airlines (M) and several others. It‚Äôs worth double-checking your gate assignment as signage can sometimes be updated close to departure...
It's a beautiful airport

‚úàÔ∏è Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) ‚Äì A Major Asian Hub with Smooth Connectivity | Travel Consultant Review

As a travel consultant, I often recommend KLIA as a transit point or entry to Southeast Asia. Here's a breakdown of the experience:

üåü Highlights:
‚úÖ Modern Infrastructure
KLIA is clean, spacious, and well-designed. The terminals‚ÄîKLIA (Main Terminal) and KLIA2 (Low-cost Terminal)‚Äîare efficiently connected via train and shuttle.

‚úÖ Connectivity
Excellent connectivity via ERL (Express Rail Link) to central Kuala Lumpur in just ~30 minutes. Clear signage in English and Malay makes navigation easy for international travelers.

‚úÖ Immigration & Security
Immigration can be quick during non-peak hours, but delays are possible during busy times. Security is generally smooth and well-organized.

‚úÖ Shopping & Amenities
KLIA offers duty-free shops, premium brands, local crafts, and great food courts. Muslim prayer rooms, child play areas, lounges, and clean restrooms add to the comfort.

‚úÖ Hospitality & Help Desks
Friendly and professional staff. Help counters and digital info kiosks are helpful, especially for first-time visitors.

‚ö†Ô∏è Things to Keep in Mind:
KLIA2 is separate and caters mostly to AirAsia and budget carriers‚Äîplan accordingly if you have a connecting flight between KLIA and KLIA2.

Transit times between gates can be long; allow extra time, especially for international connections.

üß≥ Consultant‚Äôs Tip:
Use the Plaza Premium Lounge for long layovers‚Äîit‚Äôs affordable and well-equipped. Download the Malaysia Airports app for real-time updates and gate information.

Overall Rating: 8.5/10
A world-class airport that balances efficiency with Malaysian hospitality‚Äîideal for smooth international transit or as a gateway to explore Malaysia.

Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) is located in Sepang, Selangor, about 45 km from the capital city. This is the largest and most important airport in Malaysia. The project officially opened in 1998, serving both domestic and international flights. KLIA has two main terminals: Terminal 1 and Terminal 2 (klia2). Traveling between terminals can be done by Aerotrain or shuttle bus. From Kuala Lumpur to the airport, passengers often choose the KLIA Ekspres train with a travel time of about 28 minutes. The space inside the airport is modern, spacious and clean. The signs are clear, convenient for finding the gate and doing procedures. This is a major air gateway, welcoming millions of visitors to Malaysia every year.

Kuala Lumpur Airport (KLIA)** is Malaysia's main international aviation hub and one of the busiest airports in Southeast Asia. Located in Sepang, Selangor, about 50 kilometers from Kuala Lumpur city center, it offers modern facilities and convenient transport links.

KLIA is divided into a main terminal (KLIA1) and a low-cost terminal (KLIA2), which serve traditional and low-cost airlines. The main terminal is elegantly designed and fully functional, integrating modern architecture and Malay cultural elements. It has a spacious waiting room and natural lighting to make passengers feel comfortable and relaxed.

The airport offers a variety of convenient facilities, including a variety of restaurants, duty-free shops, gift shops and premium brand counters to meet the shopping and dining needs of travelers.

Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) is one of the most convenient and well-organized airports in Southeast Asia. It serves as Malaysia‚Äôs main international gateway and is located about 45 minutes from the city center. Whether you‚Äôre arriving, departing, or just on a layover, KLIA offers a smooth and pleasant airport experience.

The airport is spacious, clean, and well-designed with clear signage and friendly staff ready to assist travelers. One of the things people really appreciate about KLIA is the wide variety of food options. If you‚Äôre in the mood for a quick bite, you‚Äôll find familiar names like Burger King, perfect for grabbing fast food before your flight. There are also other caf√©s, local eateries, and international food chains to suit every taste.

KLIA is also a great place to do some last-minute shopping. There are plenty of duty-free stores, offering everything from snacks and souvenirs to premium items. For those who love fragrances, you‚Äôll find perfume shops from various global brands, all neatly arranged and reasonably priced.

Whether you‚Äôre traveling for business or leisure, KLIA provides everything you need ‚Äî from comfort and convenience to dining and shopping. It‚Äôs a great first and last impression of Malaysia, and a reminder of how far the country has come in terms of global connectivity and modern infrastructure‚Ä¶

Pampers with luxe lounges (try Plaza Premium for a nap pod!), while KLIA2 keeps budget travelers happy with AirAsia‚Äôs dominance and cheap eats like Nasi Lemak Wanjo. Pro tips: Breeze through immigration with the new biometric e-gates if you‚Äôre a frequent flyer register on arrival! The KLIA Ekspres (28 minutes to KL Sentral) is your wallet-friendly escape from taxi touts. Grab a SIM from the Tune Talk kiosk for instant 5G, and hit the revamped Eraman Duty-Free for local gems like Boh Tea or durian chocolate (yes, it‚Äôs a thing). Hungry? Myeongdong Topokki in KLIA2 serves spicy Korean bites to fuel your layover. Free Wi-Fi‚Äôs solid, but download the MySejahtera app for seamless travel updates. Watch out for peak hour crowds (mornings are manic). KLIA‚Äôs a smooth operator, blending efficiency with that Malaysian charm, just don‚Äôt linger too long at the chocolate stalls! Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) is one of the most modern and efficient airports in Southeast Asia. From the moment you arrive, it offers a clean, organized, and traveler-friendly experience.

Pros:

‚úÖ Well-Designed & Spacious ‚Äì The terminal layout is intuitive with plenty of signs in multiple languages. The ceilings are high and the design is elegant, giving a sense of openness and calm.
‚úÖ Immigration & Security ‚Äì Generally smooth and well-managed, especially for Malaysian passport holders. International travelers may experience a short wait, but the staff are polite and efficient.
‚úÖ Facilities ‚Äì Plenty of clean toilets, prayer rooms, baby care rooms, and seating areas. Charging stations are available in key waiting areas.
‚úÖ Shopping & Dining ‚Äì A good range of duty-free shops, restaurants, and local Malaysian food options. Prices are reasonable for an international airport.
‚úÖ Transport Options ‚Äì KLIA Ekspres train to the city is fast and reliable (just 28 minutes to KL Sentral). Taxis, e-hailing (Grab), and buses are also readily available.
‚úÖ Free Wi-Fi ‚Äì Stable and fast for short browsing or communication.

The transit experience was seamless, and the airport's clean and modern facilities made the journey comfortable. Malaysia Airlines also provided excellent service, adding to the overall positive experience.

Overall, KLIA is a well-managed international hub, and I would definitely prefer transiting through here again.

Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA)** is Malaysia's main international aviation hub and one of the busiest airports in Southeast Asia. Located in Sepang, Selangor, approximately 50 kilometres from Kuala Lumpur city centre, it offers modern facilities and convenient transport links.

KLIA is divided into a main terminal (KLIA1) and a low-cost terminal (KLIA2), which serve traditional and low-cost airlines. The main terminal is elegantly designed and fully functional, integrating modern architecture and Malay cultural elements. It has a spacious waiting area and natural lighting to make passengers feel comfortable and relaxed.

The airport offers a variety of convenient facilities, including a variety of restaurants, duty-free shops, souvenir shops and high-end brand counters to meet the shopping and dining needs of travelers.

KLIA Main Terminal: Designed by Japanese architect Kisho Kurokawa and opened in 1998, its architectural style combines modern technology with tropical rainforest elements.

Skybridge and Transfer Design: The main terminal and satellite terminal are connected by a high-speed train (Aerotrain), creating a seamless flow of traffic.

Nature Integration: The satellite terminal even features a tropical rainforest sanctuary in its atrium, allowing passengers to enjoy a stroll during their layovers‚Äîa rare feature worldwide.

This year, airport services have improved significantly compared to all previous years.

For countries that do not require a visa, you can enter through the electronic gates, such as Malaysians.

But when entering through these gates, your passport is not stamped, and you do not deal with any employee. You just put your passport on the gate, then look at the camera, and within seconds you enter Malaysia üá≤üáæ.

Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) is undoubtedly one of the most modern and efficient hubs in Southeast Asia. The facilities are spacious, clean, and well-signposted, making travel easy, even for those unfamiliar with the area. Connections to the city center via the KLIA Express train are fast and convenient, allowing passengers to reach the capital in just 30 minutes. The dining scene is also varied, with local and international options available in both the arrivals and departures areas.

The security and customer service staff are generally friendly and helpful, and immigration controls are usually relatively smooth if you don't arrive during rush hour.

However, one of KLIA's major weaknesses is the limited number of rest areas for passengers in transit or with long layovers. Although there are some VIP lounges and capsule hotels with a fee, the airport doesn't offer enough comfortable public areas for reclining or sleeping, something that is sorely lacking when it comes to overnight waits or long connections. Improvements in this area would make the overall experience much more pleasant.

In short, an efficient and modern airport, but one that needs to consider the comfort of travelers in transit more.

Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) is one of Southeast Asia‚Äôs most impressive airports. It‚Äôs clean, well-organized, and offers plenty of services for both international and domestic travelers. The airport is split into two terminals: KLIA (main terminal) for full-service airlines and KLIA2 for budget carriers like AirAsia. A free shuttle bus runs between them frequently, which is super convenient.

The main terminal (KLIA) is spacious with high ceilings and even includes a small indoor rainforest‚Äîa really unique touch! Immigration and customs can be slow during peak hours, but the staff are generally friendly and helpful. Signage throughout the airport is clear, and it‚Äôs easy to find your way around.

KLIA2 is more modern in terms of retail options, offering a wide variety of shops, restaurants, and lounges. It has more of a shopping mall feel and is perfect if you have a long layover. However, walking distances can be long, so plan accordingly.

The KLIA Ekspres train makes travel to and from downtown Kuala Lumpur quick and easy (about 30 minutes), which is a major plus.

Some downsides include occasional delays at immigration and certain gates that require shuttle buses, which isn‚Äôt ideal for tired travelers. Still, overall, KLIA is a great airport‚Äîefficient, comfortable, and a solid first impression of Malaysia.
